HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
A Spec Office Builder Near Princeton Thinks Bigger

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: WEST WINDSOR

 BODY:
THIS month backhoes will begin tearing into 17 acres here for an office building that, like others in recent years in the flush office market along the Princeton Route 1 corridor, will be built on speculation.
But the new building, University Square, is unlike the others because of its size. With 316,000 square feet on five floors, it will break from the pattern of low-slung corporate boxes, averaging 100,000 square feet, that line the 20-mile corridor stretching from New Brunswick to Trenton. The developer is the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Melville, on Long Island, with offices in New Jersey. 
 Commercial brokers say an aversion to risk is one reason other developers are not putting up larger buildings. Financing for speculative construction, they add, is still tight and will keep such projects to a modest size.
Moreover, "the bread-and-butter tenants" in the Princeton market need 25,000 square feet and are well served by the smaller buildings, said J. Douglas Petrozzini, a senior vice president at the Edison office of Grubb & Ellis, the commercial real estate services company.
Many larger tenants in the area, he added, typically build their own space or have it built for them. Merrill Lynch is building, in phases over the next year, 1.25 million square feet of office space in eight buildings on some of the 450 acres it owns at Scotch Road and Interstate 95 in Hopewell. The project, which sparked fierce resistance from some local residents, could grow to 3.5 million square feet.
And RCN, a cable company, will soon begin building the first 610,,000-square-foot, four-building phase of its planned 135-acre, 1.5 million-square-foot campus at Princeton Pike and I-295 in Lawrenceville, said Robert T. Morford, a principal at the Garibaldi Group, a real estate services company in Chatham that represented RCN.
Jeffrey Schotz, senior vice president and managing director of Reckson's New Jersey operation, said University Square was designed for tenants who wanted large blocks of space "and until now had limited options." He said his company was financing the $45 million project with internal funds.
University Square is the first building Reckson is constructing in New Jersey since it entered the state in 1997. Since then, the company has acquired land on which it could build some 1.6 million square feet of space, as well as older office buildings it has renovated.
Brokers said the construction of University Square, while unusual, was not surprising. In the last two years, there has been two million square feet of speculative offices built in the Princeton market, according to Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate services company.
AND projects totaling 710,000 more feet are under way or about to start. In addition to University Square, they include a 140,000-square-foot building planned at the Carnegie Center office park in West Windsor. A 70,850-square-foot building is rising and another with 100,000 square feet is planned on land sold to separate developers by Princeton University. The buildings are part of the 2,200-acre Princeton Forrestal Center, which straddles Plainsboro and South Brunswick Townships.
That production pace has some real estate executive concerned about overbuilding. But brokers say that will not occur as long as lenders keep the lid on financing and the state's economy and job growth continue to stoke tenants' demand for space and their desire to be near Princeton University.
"The Princeton market," said David Knights, marketing director at Princeton Forrestal Center, "is supported by three legs: the pharmaceutical, financial services and telecommunication industries. And with the economy the way it is, all three legs are growing -- and aggressively."
With that demand, most of the two million square feet of speculative space built in the last two years has been leased. The corridor's vacancy rate fell to 9.8 percent in the second quarter of this year from 10.4 percent a year earlier, according to Cushman & Wakefield. Average asking prices for prime space remained stable at $28.87 per square foot a year.
The demand is coming mostly from current tenants who are expanding, said Peter W. Hamburger, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield. "If businesses continue to grow at a modest rate of 3 percent a year," he added, "that will generate a demand for 360,000 square feet a year."
As a result, he said, the market should be able to absorb the next crop of speculative buildings.
And the space RCN and Merrill Lynch will vacate for their new buildings as well, said Mr. Morford of the Garibaldi Group. RCN is said to occupy 100,000 square feet in Carnegie Center
Merrill Lynch is building the Hopewell buildings "to meet our immediate growth needs," said Joseph M. Cohen, a company spokesman. He said 6,000 employees who provided support services for the company's brokerage operations would occupy the buildings.
They will relocate from leased space mostly in central New Jersey, including 250,000 square feet in the Princeton market, Mr. Cohen said, adding that those leases expired in 18 to 36 months. A 1.2 million-square-foot building the company owns in Plainsboro will be retained, he said.
Mr. Schotz, of Reckson, said that University Square, which will rise at the corner of Route 1 and Alexander Road, represented "an opportunity to get in on a fast-growing market." To satisfy what his company believes is tenants' unmet need for large blocks of space, he said, the building's five floors, each with 60,000 square feet, will be marketed to users needing at least half that amount of space.
Though the building could accommodate tenants wanting 5,000 square feet, "that is not our intent right now," Mr. Schotz said. Initially, rents will be $32.75 a square foot, with tenants paying for their own electricity, and will rise during the course of construction to $34.75. Completion is set for the fall of 2001.
Boston Properties expects to start construction by year-end on a 140,000-square foot, five-story speculative building at its 450-acre Carnegie Center office campus. Half of the park's eventual four million square feet is built and leased.
Since the company bought the park in 1998, it has built four more buildings, on speculation or for specific tenants. All 600,000 square feet in those buildings also are leased, keeping the park at full occupancy, said Micky Landis, a vice president and regional manager at Boston Properties.
"We put up one building a year," Mr. Landis said, "But right now. there is more construction in the market and frankly that should concern any developer who has memories of the mid-80's." The question, he said, is "how many other developers will try to take advantage of the market."
STILL, he said, Carnegie Center has the advantage of offering a campus environment. Another factor is that the park's current tenants continue to grow, he said, adding that such tenants filled the previous buildings "and are likely to fill the new one" as well.
Rents at the park are $31 to $36 a square foot, he said, adding that those at the planned building, while not yet set, would be in that range.
In Plainsboro, the Patrinely Group, with offices in Houston and Princeton, last week started construction on a 70,850-square-foot speculative building. It will be the second such building for the company, which in 1998 agreed to buy, in pieces, 100 acres from Princeton University to build the Princeton Corporate Campus, an office campus of up to 1.2 million square feet on both sides of Route 1 in Plainsboro. It is part of the Princeton Forrestal Center.
The first building, with 154,000 square feet, is leased, said Walter F. Thomas, a senior managing director for new development at the Patrinely Group. "The depth and breath of the demand is greater than we anticipated," he said, adding that lease proposals were out for all but 24,000 square feet in the second building. Rents in that building will be $31.50 a square foot, with tenants paying for their own electricity.
The first two buildings will complete development on the southbound side of Route 1 and Mr. Thomas said his company "is pushing forward with dispatch for approvals" for the one million square feet it could build on the north side of the highway.
Five buildings of 160,000 square feet each are envisioned there.. But Mr. Thomas said the plan was flexible, allowing his company to build larger or smaller buildings to meet market demand.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
KeySpan Ponders the Future of 500 Riverhead Acres

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
KEYSPAN ENERGY, the giant gas and electric concern formed two years ago by the merger of Brooklyn Union Gas and the Long Island Lighting Company, is preparing to divest itself of more than 500 acres of farmland, woods and Long Island Sound shorefront in the Town of Riverhead, potentially with an eye toward preservation, its officials said.
In an unusual turn for a publicly traded corporation, KeySpan officials said they were looking beyond the land's enormous development potential to explore ways to preserve much if not all of the holding in its current state, provided a method could be found for fair compensation. 
 The property, where Lilco proposed building two nuclear power plants in the 1970's, is among the largest remaining privately owned open expanses on eastern Long Island and would be worth tens of millions of dollars if sold for development. Farmland currently sells for $25,000 an acre in the area, and prime shoreline lots near bluffs on the property's northern boundary, with spectacular views over Long Island Sound, would sell for more than $300,000 an acre, real estate agents said.
The land is currently zoned to allow industrial use, but could also be used for expensive housing, condominiums or a private or public golf course with town permission. But residents of the North Fork of Long Island and all of Suffolk County have repeatedly voted for programs to preserve farms and open space.
Farmland, farm stands and vineyards are also crucial to the traditionally agricultural North Fork's appeal to tourists and weekend visitors, many of whom come from densely suburban western Long Island. Voter-approved land protection programs have been slowed, however, by a lack of willing sellers.
KeySpan said that while no final decisions had been made it was considering a number of preservation approaches for the property, including transfer of development rights to Suffolk County, sale of the land to New York State for a park, and other types of purchase or preservation plans that combined state, county, local and even Federal financing sources.
KeySpan's senior vice president for corporate affairs, David J. Manning, said the challenge for the company was finding harmony with environmental and public interests while protecting shareholders.
"We have been in discussion with local politicians, state officials, community leaders, environmentalists and developers," Mr. Manning said. "There are a number of people who are interested in the potential for the property in all directions." Mr. Manning said that KeySpan considered the site too remote for a power station.
The land is in an agricultural corridor along Sound Avenue in the eastern part of Riverhead. A small portion is within the Town of Southold. Keyspan currently leases 230 acres to two farmers who grow potatoes, corn, squash and other crops, but the leases expire at the end of this year.
The Hallockville Museum Farm and Folklife Center, a not-for-profit historic preservation group, owns eight acres of land and historic buildings contiguous to the KeySpan property. The museum's name is derived from the Hallock family, who were among early English settlers of the North Fork. The Hallock homestead, restored to interpret farm life a century ago, is open to the public and is on the National Register of Historic Places.
KEYSPAN officials said they hoped to make a good impression on Long Islanders by being sensitive to preservation sentiment and the goals of the museum.
"We're just trying to do the right thing," Mr. Manning said.
Company officials inclined toward preservation, however, must contend with possible investor backlash, Mr. Manning said, if KeySpan passes up likely offers from private developers willing to pay large amounts for the property.
But KeySpan officials said they would also risk severe approbation from environmental and civic groups as well as some elected officials if the company took a more conventional path and sold the property to the highest bidder regardless of future use.
Under a takeover plan carried out two years ago, Lilco sold its electric transmission and delivery system to the Long Island Power Authority but retained power plants and other assets, including the Riverhead land, which passed to KeySpan after the merger.
During the 1970's, Lilco had sought federal and state permission to build two nuclear power plants on the property, but a state board rejected the plan in 1980 and said that only a coal-powered generating station would be permitted. The coal-powered station was never built, and the property -- though deeply scarred on a section of its shoreline where another former owner, Levon Corporation, mined large volumes of sand and destroyed coastal bluffs -- has remained undisturbed since then.
As KeySpan edged closer to divesting the property, there were many suggestions about how the company should proceed.
John Eilertsen, the executive director of the Hallockville Museum Farm and Folk Life Center, said the group was requesting that KeySpan donate 50 acres of farmland to the museum to restore the Hallock farmstead to its size of 100 years ago. He said the group wanted the remainder of the farmland preserved in some way and favored public access routes to the Sound.
"With more and more of the farmland disappearing, the land is becoming a greater and rarer asset," Mr. Eilertsen said. "It should be a resource for all of Long Island." The nightmare, he said, would be "an intensive housing development with little or no preservation or another golf course."
In the last five years, several Riverhead farm owners have converted fields into public golf courses. One developer, William Talmage, ignored offers from Suffolk County to acquire an environmentally sensitive wooded area on the Talmage farm and cleared fairways for an 18-hole course on 286 acres of fields, woods and Long Island Sound bluffs shortly after the town board approved the controversial project.
Two environmental groups, the Long Island Pine Barrens Society and the North Fork Environmental Council, are suing the town for allowing the project, but lost a lower court ruling last month.
Preservation groups were eager to avoid a repetition on the KeySpan property. "We have certainly expressed our interest in helping KeySpan," said John Halsey, the president of the Peconic Land Trust, a not-for-profit group that promotes farm and open space preservation on Long Island's East End.
Mr. Halsey said a plan could include limited development on a portion of the property in an area set back from the bluffs but also away from farm fields. "It would also be nice if there was a gift component," Mr. Halsey said. He said such a gift would carry substantial tax benefits for the company.
Others said preservation of all of the nearly last-of-its-kind parcel was warranted. "We have told KeySpan they should make the property available for acquisition in total," said Richard L. Amper Jr., the executive director of the Long Island Pine Barrens Society. "There should be no partial development. We are asking them to do the environmentally correct thing."
Joseph M. Gergela, the executive director of the Long Island Farm Bureau in Riverhead, where the largest remaining farm area on the East End is situated, said the bureau "would love to see if there is some way to save that farmland."
Mr. Gergela said he recommended cutting the farmland into several sections, transferring the development rights to the government and selling the remaining rights to the highest private bidders.
In development rights programs, used by Suffolk County since the late 1970's as a tool to save working farms, the county or another government buys and holds the development rights in perpetuity, lowering the price and taxes for land that remains available only for agricultural uses.
George Gatta, the deputy Suffolk County executive for economic development, said the county was prepared to participate with New York State in a preservation plan for the KeySpan property. Mr. Gatta and state officials said the property had been recommended for a state open-space list, enhancing chances of state financing for a purchase. One possibility would be for some or all of the property to become a state park that provided public access to Long Island Sound. Roads on the property's western and eastern borders connect Sound Avenue to the shoreline.
John Atkins, the president of Save the Sound Inc. of Stamford, Conn., a group leading a coalition promoting federal legislationthat would set up a Long Island Sound reserve, said KeySpan would perform an immense public service by preserving the land and allowing shoreline access.
Senator Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut, the Democratic candidate for vice president, has said he would consider introducing a bill creating the reserve. Mr. Atkins said the bill could lead to federal financing for purchase of lands along Long Island Sound, where public access is limited.

HEADLINE: OPINION;
The Cost of the American Dream

BYLINE: By CARLOS SANDOVAL; Carlos Sandoval, a lawyer and writer, lives in Amagansett.

 BODY:
BANDAGED and bruised, one of the two Mexican immigrant workers from Farmingville who were recently lured to an abandoned building and then attacked was afraid to show his face. "I guess that's the price you have to pay for the American dream," he was quoted as saying about the attempt to murder him.
As a Hispanic, my stomach heaved: I was angered by his sense of resignation, but I understood it, too. As an American, I was shocked that anyone would think that the risk of murder is the price of entry into my country. As an East Ender, I realized he was right. 
 It's simple economics. Many of us on the East End are feeling flush these days. We want to perfect our American dream, but on the cheap. So we hire immigrant labor to build the decks on which we barbecue, the pools we play in and the family rooms we gather in. We pay them a low wage -- they seem to be satisfied -- and we consider the transaction complete when they disappear.
But it's not. In economic terms we haven't captured all the costs.
In the case of immigrant workers, most communities on the East End have avoided the full costs associated with maintaining this cheap labor pool. We (or our contractors acting as our agents) want the convenience of disposable labor, people we can hire in the morning and push out of sight after a long day's work. The most efficient way of accomplishing this labor transaction is the same way you buy a quart of milk. You go to a market and select the product you want off the shelf.
And so it's evolved that day laborers congregate in certain highly visible spots to form "shape-up lines" and ply their wares -- themselves. But because there is no affordable housing in the communities where the laborers actually work, they generally live and gather in communities far away from those of us who hire them. It's as if you hired a gardener and then forced your brother to take him in. The gardener may pay rent, but your brother is going to resent the intrusion.
This is, in essence, what we have done to working-class hamlets like Farmingville. We have shifted the burden of the housing and dispatching of immigrant labor to them. Formerly homogeneous suburban communities have suddenly seen their lives disrupted so that we can afford to enhance ours.
This is not to excuse the hate unfurled in recent months by groups like the Sachem Quality of Life Organization. These groups argue that the shape-up lines and the immigrants' crowded housing conditions create health and safety hazards. If this were their real concern, these groups would have accepted the proposal to establish a hiring hall, a proposal backed by Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, among others. Instead, these groups have tried to pervert American values in pursuit of their racist ends.
They argue that hiring halls offend their civic sensibilities because they condone the illegality of immigrants who have slipped into this country. Yet in pursuing this argument these groups have nurtured another illegality: attempted murder.
And in a scene more appropriate to a totalitarian regime than to our Rockwellian vision of small-town American democracy, this same element drowned out a Hispanic witness at a town meeting by chanting the Pledge of Allegiance while marching out of the meeting.
Working from fear rather than fact, they cited a nonexistent crime wave in order to convince the Suffolk County Legislature to sue the Immigration and Naturalization Service to initiate a witch hunt in which I, a sixth-generation United States citizen, could easily have been rounded up. To its shame, the Legislature almost bought into the ploy, barely defeating the measure by a lone vote.
The atmosphere of hate that some citizens of Farmingville have fostered cannot be excused or tolerated. But neither can we excuse ourselves from our role in creating it. We have to recognize that Farmingville, and communities like it, are subsidizing our "not in my backyard" views, because they are being forced to house a disproportionate number these workers.
It's not enough to dismiss Farmingville with a liberal "tsk, tsk." We in surrounding communities must absorb the full cost of the labor that makes it possible to build our McMansions. At minimum, this means establishing hiring halls and evenly distributing them among various communities.
But more important, we must put an end to the Nimby complex. We must create affordable housing in communities throughout the East End including -- or perhaps most especially -- in overheated real estate markets like the Hamptons. It also means accepting these workers as neighbors in our communities after the workday ends rather than carting them off as chattel to pens in other communities each night.
The American dream is about more than economic opportunity. It's about creating a textured land in which people of various colors come together as a community. That's our great experiment and strength. While we may need to be ready to die in defense of that dream, we cannot tolerate the murder of anyone seeking to join it merely because he is willing to build our own American dreams at a discount.

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK;
The Trials of 'Branding' Locally Grown Produce

BYLINE: By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
WENDING her way through the Hayground Market in Bridgehampton one recent afternoon, Kathi Cavanaugh stopped to scoop string beans into her plastic bag. "I always pick fresh produce here, rather than going to the supermarket," said Ms. Cavanaugh, who lives in Sag Harbor. She was standing beneath a handwritten sign proclaiming "Local String Beans."
Ms. Cavanaugh said she preferred locally grown produce for a couple of reasons. "I believe it's fresher, for one thing," she said. "And it supports the local farmers, which I think is highly important." 
 Finding fresh local produce in Suffolk County is not a demanding chore this time of year. Roadside stands now proudly display the bounty: armies of plump pumpkins, tangles of speckled cranberry beans, waist-high piles of unshucked corn.
Selling locally grown produce is mainly a homespun affair on Long Island, despite the success other areas have had in using regional labels. In New Jersey, where farmers compete directly with Long Island farmers for wholesale customers, the long-running New Jersey Farm Fresh campaign is considered a classic example of agricultural branding, as the field is known. New York State operates its own program, as do many other states and regions.
In Riverhead, a similar campaign was developed 15 years ago by a farmers' organization called the Long Island Farm Bureau. Under the banner of "Grown on Long Island," the campaign was initially greeted with high hopes. A logo was designed -- it was free, the winning entry of a Suffolk County Industrial Development Authority competition -- and signs for farm trucks and stickers for produce boxes were prepared. But the project stalled.
"We haven't gotten much cooperation from supermarkets, who are more interested in buying by the price," said Joseph Gergela III, the group's executive director and a member of an old Riverhead farm family. "And to be fair, our farmers have been reluctant to participate as well for reasons of their own, which are mysterious to me."
The campaign did make some inroads. About 150 signs with the campaign's verdant logo -- the outline of Long Island surrounded by the slogan in curvy letters that seem to be sprouting at the top -- were handed out and actually used, Mr. Gergela said. A number of growers affix labels with the logo on produce boxes, although Mr. Gergela said he did not know how many.
This year, the bureau is trying to revive the campaign. One reason is farmland preservation. The thought is that if farmers are prospering, they will be less likely to sell their land to developers. Progress in establishing a local farmers' market, a quixotic dream of long standing that finally received start-up money from the State Legislature last year, is another.
"The campaign is an effort to give a regional identity to the produce grown on Long Island," said Lyle Wells, a Riverhead farmer and longtime Farm Bureau member. Drawing on a $70,000 promotion budget, up more than 40 percent over 1999, Mr. Gergela has attended about a dozen local trade shows this year, double the number he went to last year. The money comes from the bureau, whose 5,700 members pay dues of $80 a year.
While Suffolk County farmers -- as individuals -- may appreciate the marketing power of the word "local," they have by and large paid only lip service to the campaign. One reason why they are lukewarm is that roadside selling is often more profitable. To sell a "Grown on Long Island" deal to supermarkets, "we have to lock into prices and volume, and not everybody wants to do that," said Phil Schmitt, a fifth-generation lettuce grower in Riverhead.
Another stumbling block has been the issue of quality standards. No wilted green beans, no bruised zucchini, no black patches on the cauliflower. Supermarket buyers enforce those standards; roadside customers may overlook a few imperfections.
Another problem is economic. Establishing a serious marketing campaign is going to cost quite a bit more than $70,000, and absent government largess, the money will need to come out of members' pockets. "I don't know that they'll be willing to support that," Mr. Gergela said.
Another issue is marketplace economics -- read: retail consolidation. Supermarket produce buyers, never the most romantic of souls, have become even less susceptible to regional appeals. "When Waldbaum's was a Long Island store, we could go to the warehouse and sell directly to them," Mr. Schmitt said. "We sold every day to them for 40 years. When they sold the store to A.&P., everything changed. The A.&P. buyers didn't care if we came from Long Island or Timbuktu. Every big store's the same; they buy on price."
Still, people see the television commercials venerating produce from New Jersey -- they appear on "Good Morning America," right after Martha Stewart, for goodness' sake -- and may well wonder why Grown on Long Island remains a struggling seedling. The campaign has its critics, some of whom say it fails to establish a strong emotional connection between consumers and Long Island produce.
Joseph Friedman, a senior partner in Friedman, Ellis, Nielsen & Rogan, a Hauppauge firm that specializes in marketing and branding, contends that the campaign should be redesigned. "Freshness means so much to people when it comes to produce, yet the campaign doesn't seem to get that message across," said Mr. Friedman,whose client roster includes Galluccio Estate Vineyards in Cutchogue. "The region has panache - -- its popularity is growing in leaps and bounds. The farmers have to make clear in the campaign that local equals fresh."
How could they do that? "They could," he said, "hire me."
Another branding consultant, Peggy Ehlers of Riverhead, said she feels "enormous frustration" at the campaign's pace. "Look at Napa Valley," she said and went on to describe that California landmark northeast of San Francisco as an agricultural marketing benchmark. "I happen to think this region actually has more going for it than Napa Valley, but we aren't anywhere near them in branding," she said.
The problem, in her view, is that the Farm Bureau's campaign misses the agri-tourism boat. "People are looking for freshness, of course, but even more they're looking for something emotional," she said. "They want a connection to the land, to the farmers, to the heritage. Grown on Long Island doesn't work because it just doesn't tap into the emotional reasons people buy produce."
Some 18 million people live within a day's trip of Riverhead, she said. Reaching only a fraction of those people could create a market for local farmers and preserve the region's farmland from development.
"We need to connect the various industries that are dependent on agri-tourism," she said. "There are all these cottage industries, bed-and-breakfast accommodations and, of course, the vineyards. They're all part of the visitor's experience, but they've been left out of the picture here."
Inclusiveness and outreach have not been campaign hallmarks, it seems. "Grown on Long Island?" said Harold Watts, the Long Island Wine Council's president. "Haven't heard anything about that."

LENGTH: 1520 words

HEADLINE: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL;
Shredding the Concept of 'Deadbeat Dads'

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER; E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
PAY, pay, pay. That's what divorced fathers are forced to do, said Sari Friedman, a matrimonial lawyer in Garden City with a mostly male clientele. Even divorced fathers who are nurturing, devoted and involved with their children's lives. They, too, are sometimes treated like wallets.
Just ask Kasey Blake, a stay-at-home mom from Setauket. Mrs. Blake does not think she's a victim. She's just a second wife. 
 Mrs. Blake 39, has been married to Kevin Blake, 39, an office manager, for 10 years. They have a 6-year-old son. Mr. Blake also has a 13-year-old daughter from his first marriage. He dotes on both his children. But his ex-wife, who has remarried, has custody of their daughter.
Mr. Blake says he has always paid his child support on time. His daughter stays with him on alternate weekends, and he has never canceled a visit. Mrs. Blake said she loves her stepdaughter as her own. Yet there is friction. Demands concerning visitation. Not letting Mr. Blake see the girl. Requests for more money.
"It's like a wound that never heals for anybody," Mrs. Blake said. "It's always there and we are married a long time. It shouldn't be like that, especially when you are doing the right thing with the kid. You love the kid. You embrace her in the family, you pay the child support. You are there all the time to be with her. What is the problem? It's such an adversarial thing. People are so locked in anger and it really hurts the kids so badly. It's like an open wound."
Mrs. Blake said that many first wives use family court for revenge, as a tool against their ex-spouse, especially if he is happy with someone else and getting on with his life, just to keep making trouble. "To me, if someone is paying their child support and visiting the child, what else is there to do?" she said.
Surfing the Web, Mrs. Blake found other second wives and stepmothers struggling with the same issues. To empower blended families, find peaceful solutions to the anger and bickering, put the children first and improve the image of divorced dads, Mrs. Blake started an organization, Women for Fatherhood. She brought in Ms. Friedman, 43, her husband's lawyer, a staunch advocate for divorced fathers and general counsel to the Fathers Rights Association of New York and the Fathers Rights Association of Long Island, to help.
"People are so keyed into believing fathers are these huge villains," Mrs. Blake said. "What happens to all the guys that are good guys? What happens to all the guys who have other families? The system was designed to try and protect people but in the process other people are getting hurt."
Over the past three years, membership in Women for Fatherhood has grown to 1,000. There are chapters in North Carolina, Maryland and Ohio, bulletin boards and links to resources on the organization's Web site, www.women4fatherhood.org. The first live meeting of the flagship Long Island chapter will be held on Thursday at 7 p.m. at the Emma Clark Library in Setauket.
"Because so many people have this perception about fathers, it's always assumed that because my husband is a non-custodial father that he's bad," Mrs. Blake said, asserting that the moniker "deadbeat dad" need not always apply. "I felt that there was a skew in the public perception of fathers and a total lack of regard for subsequent children from second marriages."
Part of the problem, Ms. Friedman said, is that even though 50 percent of marriages end in divorce, unless it is arranged privately out of court, joint custody is not an option under New York State law.
"This concept that only women know how to be nurturing and its something that's biologically instilled in you is just incorrect," said Ms. Friedman, 43, of Oyster Bay Cove, who has been married for 20 years and considers her husband, Ken, an actuary, a co-parent to their two daughters. "Fathers can be as nurturing as mothers if they are allowed to be," she added. "It's what society allows them to do. The concept of what a mother is and what a father is from years past, from the 1960's when we had shows like 'Ozzie and Harriet' telling us that Ozzie went to work and Harriet stayed home; it's just not reflective of society today."
Ms. Friedman contended that fathers are often treated as second-class citizens by the courts when it comes to rights and decision-making with respect to their children. If they lose their jobs or have been downgraded, they still have to pay. Paralegal support systems and resources offered to divorcing mothers are not readily available to men. And she claimed that statistics show that non-custodial mothers are more often delinquent in child support payments than fathers, yet don't seem to get a bad rap.
Mr. Blake said he had to go to court to stop his ex-wife from moving out of state. She took him to court to raise support payments. But his ex is working, her new husband is working and as custodial parents, they get the tax write-off for their dependent.
"The means for the children of her family are greater than the means for your family," Mr. Blake said, begrudging the system, not his child. "I have a responsibility to help support and raise my daughter, but she has all the designer clothes and she is not lacking anything whereas I can't provide that for my son who lives with me. I'm glad she has all those things, but the economic status of the two is not the same."
Years ago, Mrs. Blake recalled, when she griped about another increase in the child support her husband would have to pay, a lawyer told her that if she wanted her own child to be considered, she should divorce her husband.
While society as a whole has shifted, Mrs. Blake added, in the divorce arena, women are pretending it hasn't. "We want equal pay and we want to be on all equal terms with them on everything else but not on this," she said. "We still want the men to pick up the slack, leave the child rearing to us and give us the money."
 
Poetry for Sale
When it comes to hawking her poetry, Carolyn L. Miles of Huntington Station can be relentless. At the gas station and the Laundromat, she hands out her "Poems on the Go" business card. When she takes her two daughters to the doctor, she pitches her verse. And she has knocked on doors from Port Washington to Riverhead selling customized rhymes.
"I can put other people's happiness and sadness into words," said Ms. Miles, 41, who describes herself as a former crack and cocaine addict and recovering alcoholic who was on welfare for nearly 12 years.
"Every time I write a poem it eases the pain of someone else. It brings me peace to shed light on someone's else's pain."
Determined to write her way off welfare, Ms. Miles turned to written-to-order sentimental verse three years ago. Since then, she has composed 142 poems.
Ms. Miles's poems are published in the Women's Center of Huntington newsletter every other month. One was included in the latest issue of Creations magazine, published every two months in Sea Cliff; two were included in books published by the National Library of Poetry in Owings Mills, Md.; and others have appeared in three anthologies.
This is an excerpt from her poem "Out of Sadness":
She climbed a mountain of broken childhood memories
Searching for her emerald dreams
Stopping now and then to mend
Stones of sadness that did descend
Under a blanket of snow
White diamonds of hope
That once lay silent
Came to life
Crystal tears of children
Rested upon golden leaves
Of make believe
Ms. Miles hopes to be able to write full time someday, but in the meantime, she works as an electrical inspector at Comtech PST in Melville.
Ms. Miles's inspirational verses, printed on scrolls and tied with red bows, have been sold to 22 Long Island businesses, including delis, bagel shops, pet shops, banks and gas stations, where they are handed out instead of calendars.
But her forte is custom poetry. "You can't go into Hallmark and say, 'I just lost my son.' You can't go into Hallmark and say, 'I love my mother so much,' " Ms. Miles said.
So she listens to the tales people tell her, then writes odes to their estranged or deceased children, memorials to their parents, in-laws and beloved pets. Framed, her customized verse runs $80; laminated memorials to pets are $85. In bulk, 100 unframed copies run $70.
As a child, Ms. Miles said, she was sexually abused and shuffled around among aunts and uncles. By age 22, she was addicted to drugs and alcohol, she said. Through the ups and downs over the past 17 years, she has worked in electronics, been counseled at Seafield Alcoholism Treatment Center in Melville and lived at Haven House, a shelter in Huntington.
"My life growing up was sad," she said. "I had no friends, no one to talk to. I used to go into a corner and write all the time."
Recently, Ms. Miles was able to move into a two-bedroom apartment. And she is selling her poetry at local craft fairs. "Poetry fills in the blanks for the words that don't get said from parent to child," she said. "People keep telling me I have a gift. Everything I write just hits home."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1204 words

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Delayed? Take Out Frustration at the Airport Gym

BYLINE: By LAURA KOSS-FEDER

 BODY:
LUCKY GOLD, who makes 30 or more business trips a year, says that being able to work out using a treadmill and free weights while on the road is crucial to his well-being.
So when Mr. Gold's job as senior vice president for business development at the Marvin Group, an aerospace company in Inglewood, Calif., takes him to Boston, as it does at least once a month, he doesn't race out of Logan International Airport the minute he arrives. Instead, he stops for an hour or so at a health club on the airport grounds, at the Hilton Boston Logan Airport hotel. Sometimes he even catches an earlier flight than necessary, to allow time for exercise before his meetings in the city. 
 "Having this facility right at the airport is so handy," Mr. Gold said. "Working out helps me stay mentally fit and better prepared for any meeting I'm going to, or any presentation that I'm making. And if I wind up getting delayed at the airport for any period of time, then the health club becomes even more important."
As the air travel system becomes ever more congested and prone to delays, airports are adding ground services to meet the needs of business travelers or to simply help them pass the extra time. These include more stores and restaurants, but also creature comforts like gyms and health clubs. Some, like the one that Mr. Gold frequents in Boston, are in airport hotels; others are in the terminal itself or in freestanding facilities on airport property.
"Nobody looks forward to a three- or four-hour layover, but it is a major stress reliever for business travelers to do a little shopping or get a quick workout while they're waiting at the airport," said Randy Petersen, publisher of Inside Flyer, a magazine for frequent travelers. Mr. Petersen himself expects to spend 200 days on the road this year for business.
Airlines depend on business travelers -- who fly more often and pay much higher fares than tourists -- for 46 percent of their revenue, according to the National Business Travel Association, which represents corporate travel managers. Airport authorities and airlines alike have an economic stake in making airports as appealing as possible to these road warriors.
Of course, many harried business travelers, when faced with a long delay or layover, are not looking for any distractions, just a quiet spot to catch up on work or reading. "There are those times when I just want to return a few calls and look over some materials before a meeting while waiting at the airport," said Ira Birns, treasurer of Arrow Electronics, a components distributor in Melville, N.Y., who travels about 25 times a year for his job.
But for those who do want a break from the laptop and the cell phone, a growing number of airports are helping to soothe frazzled nerves by offering on-site gyms, like the Airport Fitness Center at Pittsburgh International Airport. Mark Knight, regional director of BAA USA, which operates shopping and other concessions at the airport, said the center included exercise equipment, showers and sauna, and had workout clothing available for sale or rent. A single day's visit costs $9.99; a one-year membership is $420.
In March, McCarran International Airport in Las Vegas added a branch of the 24-Hour Fitness health club chain, the chain's first at an airport. The club offers aerobics classes in addition to the usual exercise facilities, and employs a sports nutritionist who will pack healthy snacks for business travelers to take along on flights.
Airport hotels are also trying to tap into the growing pool of the stranded, by marketing their facilities to airport passengers beyond their regular guests. Like its sister hotel in Boston, the Hilton Chicago O'Hare Airport regularly distributes fliers at information booths throughout the airport encouraging business travelers to buy $10 daily passes to its health club, which includes a pool, whirlpool, exercise machines, sauna and showers, according to the club's manager, Steven Andos. Tanning beds and a personal trainer are also available.
About 100 of the 800 people who use the health club on a typical day are not hotel guests, Mr. Andos said, and roughly 15 percent of the 500 regular members are travelers who pass through O'Hare regularly without staying at the hotel. The club at the Boston hotel, which charges $9 to $15 for a day, gets about 20 percent of its traffic from nonguests.
"Some of these people don't even mind that much being in the airport for a few hours between flights, since they know they can have a good workout, take a shower and leave feeling refreshed," Mr. Andos said.
A chance to work up a sweat is not the only amenity that airports, big and small, are offering to between-planes travelers. T. F. Green Airport in Providence, R.I., has just 22 gates in its terminal, but passengers can get a 15-minute massage there for $15. Last month, the airport added express manicure and pedicure service.
The massage service at Nashville International Airport proved a godsend for Jerry Daly, who owns Daly Gray, a public relations firm in Herndon, Va., and who threw out his back on a recent trip.
"Seeing those massage chairs was like finding an oasis in the desert," said Mr. Daly, who paid $15 for a 15-minute massage just before heading home from a business trip. "I was in so much pain, and this made me feel somewhat better. This is a great service to have at an airport."
Other airports, like Orlando International, have in-terminal salons where travelers can get haircuts, massages or manicures.
And the number and range of retail stores and restaurants in airports growing, too: In the Airmall at Pittsburgh International, many of the 105 stores are specifically aimed at business travelers, including a Staples office products outlet. "As many as 10 percent of business travelers we've surveyed have said that they will purposely try to connect through Pittsburgh rather than somewhere else, just to use our shops and services," Mr. Knight said.
For what ails some travelers, though, exercise or pampering or shopping may not be enough. Kennedy International in New York, for example, provides services for which there is no substitute. The airport's chapel offers a setting for quiet prayer and a chance to speak with a priest, minister or rabbi. And when the pain gets really bad, there is an on-site emergency dentist.
 
Finding Treadmills In the Terminals
IT is not always easy to know in advance if an airport you will be visiting offers a health club or other services.
Most airports have Web sites, but they vary greatly in content and organization; some offer extensive details about services and concessions, while others offer little or none. Facilities at airport hotels are generally not included on airport Web sites, though many hotels have their own sites.
A good source is the airport's information desk, which generally can be reached by telephone, or its administration office. Travel agents and corporate travel planners may also be familiar with specific airports; many customer-service representatives of airlines can answer questions about their hub airports, and have the advantage of being reachable most hours of the day.

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 8; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 921 words

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
The Selling of New Jersey, and Its Difficulties

BYLINE: By ANITA DENNIS

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK

 BODY:
The inflatable rabbit robot cruised the aisles at the Hyatt Regency playing an electronic version of "It's A Small World."
Unfortunately for the visitors, the furry bundle of electrons did not have much trouble negotiating its way around the smattering of people in the exhibition area. 
 For three days last month, a delegation of 150 Chinese businesspeople from 52 companies came to New Jersey to try to raise interest among New Jersey companies in trade and investment opportunities in Zhejiang Province.
"Mainly they are looking for guangxi -- relationship building," said Albert Chu, a consultant from Randolph who coordinated the China Zheijiang 2000 Economic and Trade Fair, held at the Hyatt Regency.
So far, Mr. Chu said, textiles and garments had been the province's most successful export items. And indeed, booths at the fair were splashed with silks and other fabrics as well as ready-to-wear clothing. He noted that in the past, businesses in the province had supplied such American manufacturers as Ann Taylor and Liz Claiborne. Other exhibits touted small electronics items, appliances, tea, Christmas lights, biodegradable food containers and toys.
Gao Yuzhi, vice director general of the Foreign Trade and Economic Cooperation Bureau of Zheijiang Province, said through a translator: "We came not only to sell. We have over 100 investment projects that are looking for investors," particularly in the pharmaceutical, chemical and health-care industries.
For the past several years, the province -- which has a population of more than 40 million -- had exhibited at the Jacob Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, and on this day the Chinese seemed a bit stunned by the difference between the two locations.
"We're happy with the reception we've received in New Jersey," Wang Huifen, an exhibitor, said through a translator. "But we would have preferred seeing more people here." About 300 came the first day, but traffic slowed to a trickle on the second and third days, and walking into the Hyatt seemed like entering a hotel in Beijing, since Asians far outnumbered Americans.
Despite its disappointment at the small turnout, the delegation, which met with Governor Whitman during its stay, was determined to pursue trade with New Jersey because of the state's economic influence.
New Jersey has the eighth largest economy in the country, and a gross state product of $327 billion, the governor's office said. If it were a country, New Jersey would have the 16th-largest economy in the world.
In addition, the Chinese province has a long relationship with the state and with Union County. Zheijiang and New Jersey are sister states, and Wenzhou, another city in the province, has been a sister city with Union County for the past 19 years -- though there has been little trade between them. Mr. Chou said Chinese officials had hoped to hold the fair in Union County, but they were unable to find a place that would accommodate the delegation.
To be sure, many Chinese provinces have trade fairs in the United States. "It is one of the ways to promote Chinese manufacturers and products," said Zhang Jie, third secretary of the commercial office of the Chinese Embassy in Washington. "It enhances the friendly exchange between the United States and the provinces and helps to publicize Chinese products."
As for Zheijiang, Ms. Gao said her province and New Jersey had much in common. Like New Jersey, Zheijiang is neighbors with a large and influential city -- its main city, Hangzhou, is about 100 miles from Shanghai. The province's economy is ranked fourth in China, Ms. Gao said. The United States is the province's top exporter, buying $2.4 billion in products last year, or nearly 19 percent of its total export volume. In turn, Zheijiang bought $579 million in goods from the United States last year. The delegation listed General Electric, Motorola, Pepsi and Merck among the companies that have done business in the province.
When it comes to business, however, the differences between the two cultures remain significant, said Mr. Chu, who is involved in training efforts in China, directed by Kean University under the sponsorship of Union County.
"They need help not only with language, but also with professional and management skills" for business and government officials, Mr. Chu said.
Still, Ms. Gao of the trade bureau said that economic reforms under way would certainly help sharpen her nation's business acumen because the Chinese now have the money to pay for training. Moreover, she said, China's recent entry into the World Trade Organization would accelerate the pace of business modernization.
"One point of this visit is to expose people to America," Mr. Chu said. "Many of these people have never been out of the country before, and don't know what to expect." He said the visitors needed to learn more about Westerners, even seemingly small details like the fact that smoking is far less acceptable here than in China.
While some companies at the fair were government-owned, there was also a mix of privately held businesses as well as several joint ventures. Provincial officials said they hoped that fairs like this one would spawn new companies.
Ms. Gao said she and her colleagues were determined to return to New Jersey. "Through this exchange, both sides can win," she said. "We have had good meetings with the New Jersey governor and with New Jersey businesses." Looking around the near-empty lobby, she added, "But it is far from New York."

LENGTH: 2475 words

HEADLINE: Location, Location, Commutation

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
ABOUT the time Lisa and Michael Gallo began thinking seriously about starting a family, they also thought about moving to the suburbs from their rental apartment on the Upper West Side. Since both worked for securities firms in Manhattan, they were looking not only for an affordable house in an attractive community but also for a convenient commute.
They found what they were looking for in Summit, N.J., an upscale residential city 25 miles from midtown Manhattan. That was four years ago, in October 1996 -- four months after New Jersey Transit inaugurated express service from Summit directly into Penn Station, instead of ending in Hoboken, where Manhattan-bound passengers had to change to PATH trains. 
 That new service, Midtown Direct, lopped about 20 minutes off the previous 70-minute trip from Summit. The round-trip saving, 40 minutes a day, has made a big difference to the Gallos.
"I don't think we would have moved here if it wasn't for Midtown Direct," said Mrs. Gallo, who commuted for two years before their twin sons arrived 16 months ago.
The Gallos were more or less prepared for sticker shock when they decided to move to Summit, a six-square-mile community where a single-family house costs an average of $645,000 and some houses sell for seven figures, according to Lois Schneider Realtor.
"We knew they weren't giving houses away in Summit before Midtown Direct arrived," Mrs. Gallo said, "so we knew we were going to have to pay extra once the service came in here."
Lois Schneider, the head of the realty firm that bears her name, said it is hard to quantify the impact of improved transportation on real estate, especially in a booming housing market. But she estimated that Midtown Direct by itself had raised housing prices 15 to 20 percent. In a town that has long been a magnet for commuters to Manhattan, "Midtown Direct increased the pool of prospective buyers," she said, "and when that happens, it pushes prices up."
It is not only upscale suburban communities that experience rises in real estate prices when commuting is made more convenient. The same phenomenon is at work in Bayonne, N.J., a working-class city of more than 60,000, where New Jersey Transit's Hudson-Bergen Light Rail service began last April.
Cathy and Kevin Ryan, a couple in their 30's from Bayonne, had been commuting by car and bus the past two years -- Mrs. Ryan to her job in Jersey City as a systems administrator at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, her husband to Weehawken, where he works as a tunnel and bridge agent for the Port Authority.
"But I started taking the Light Rail this spring," Mrs. Ryan said, "and I was so satisfied with the commute that we bought a two-family, four-story house on the east side, a block from the station."
Between New York Bay and Newark Bay, Bayonne is only the briefest of flights from Jersey City as the gull flies. But before the Light Rail service began, Mrs. Ryan's drive would sometimes take two hours each way, depending on traffic and weather. By train it now usually takes no more than 20 minutes. And when the rail service is extended to Weehawken, as intended, Mr. Ryan will switch from commuting by car to commuting by rail.
In the six months since the opening of the nine-mile Light Rail between Bayonne and Jersey City, a line that eventually will be extended 11 more miles to Ridgefield, the price of houses in Bayonne has risen at least 10 percent, said Rosemary Sugrue, a broker with Century 21 McGeehan & Pineiro in Bayonne.
"In the 16 years I've been doing this, I hardly ever had anybody ask to buy on the east side of town, because the west side is near the bay and the Hudson County Park," Ms. Sugrue said. "But since the light rail came in, we've gotten a lot of requests to buy on the east side," where the station is. "I just sold a two-family house there for $240,000," she added.
Although Mrs. Ryan declined to give the price of the house that she and her husband are in contract to buy, she said similar houses in the neighborhood sell in the $200,000-plus range. A friend three blocks away is asking $279,000 for a one-family house with a deck, pool and sauna, and Mrs. Ryan has little doubt she will get it. "Property prices have gone up ever since the Light Rail came in," she said, "because more people are wanting to live in Bayonne."
In the last two years, real estate prices have risen throughout New Jersey, said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. And while it is difficult to untangle precisely the impact of transportation on real estate, Dr. Hughes said that for a year or two before Midtown Direct started, price increases for real estate in the string of suburbs served by Midtown Direct outstripped those in New Jersey communities elsewhere.
Eugene Spruck, chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, said the strong job growth in recent years in the 17-county New York City metropolitan region (190,300 new jobs last year alone) had obviously had a significant impact on real estate. "Just think what it means for the real estate market with a lot of people with newfound wealth," he said. "And shortly after Midtown Direct was initiated, I'd hear all this talk about how hot the real estate market was in those towns."
The same is true along the Hudson River waterfront, where, as in Bayonne, property values are rising along the Hudson-Bergen Light Rail route. And the pattern is likely to be repeated elsewhere in the metropolitan area where rail service is being upgraded.
ONE such project is the Montclair Connection, which is expected to open next year and which will link the Montclair and Boonton lines into a single line and will for the first time provide direct service to midtown Manhattan. The new service is expected to attract an estimated 1,800 new riders a day, for a total of 2,600 riders a day traveling to New York in 2005.
An even bigger transformation will begin in 2002, when the $448 million Secaucus Transfer rail station will start operating. It will link 11 of New Jersey's 12 commuter rail lines, allowing passengers to transfer to trains providing service directly to Penn Station. By 2010, the transfer point is expected to serve more than 16,000 riders a day, nearly 14,000 of whom are expected to be new to the railroad, many having switched from commuting by bus or car. By bypassing Hoboken, the commuters currently bound for mid-Manhattan from northern New Jersey and from Orange and Rockland counties in New York will save an estimated 30 minutes round trip.
For many people, 30 fewer minutes spent commuting is a huge plus. And for many parents of young children, that extra time is golden. When Sean and Sue Leonard, whose daughter, Megan, is 3, decided to move from Westport, Conn., they looked in New Jersey. "We specifically looked for places where I could commute directly into Manhattan without changing trains," said Mr. Leonard, a partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers. "And it's close to my family in Philadelphia."
So this June the Leonards bought a four-bedroom house on half an acre in Chatham Township, one stop west of Summit. The commute takes about 45 minutes on the express train, Mr. Leonard said, and the local train takes a few minutes more. And he is in his midtown office after a 15 minute walk from Penn Station.
"If you get on a good transportation route, you know you're going to pay a premium," Mr. Leonard said. "And the closer in you get, the more expensive the real estate."
It is hardly surprising that commuters who can afford it willingly pay extra to avoid traffic jams and inconvenience. Maury N. Klein, a professor of history at the University of Rhode Island and the author of a two-volume account of the Union Pacific railroad, recalled that Jay Gould, the financier and railroad titan, commuted to Wall Street by yacht from Lyndhurst, his estate in Westchester County. "He found it a very pleasant way to get to work," Professor Klein said. About that time, in the late 19th century, many people, including those of modest means, were looking for convenient ways to get to work.
In "Crabgrass Frontier: The Suburbanization of the United States" (Oxford University Press, 1985), the historian Kenneth T. Jackson writes that it was the rail lines to Westchester County in the 19th century that enabled the nation's first large suburban area to develop. Around the turn of the century, "Hundreds of trains from northern and eastern New Jersey poured into Hoboken every morning," he said, "discharging passengers who immediately embarked on the 10-minute ferry ride to Manhattan."
Professor Klein added: "In the 1880's, cities grew around streetcar lines instead of the railroads, making it easy to commute to the city but not having to live there. Then the advent of the auto created new kinds of suburbs, especially after World War II. And that allowed you to live away from the railroad but drive to the station to commute back to the city."
The attractiveness of convenient rail service continues. Consider the recent extension of Metro-North's upper Harlem Line from Dover Plains, N.Y, to the Tenmile River and Wassaic stations in Amenia, a town of about 6,000 in eastern Dutchess County, a 90-mile drive from Manhattan.
In service only since July 9, and just under six miles in length, the extension has already had an impact on commuting patterns of a few people who make the two-hour-plus trip to Manhattan several times a week. It has shortened the drive time to the railroad station for these commuters and enables them to board (and park) at a station in Amenia, rather than jockey for a parking space at the Dover Plains station farther down the line. If the past is any guide, those improvements are almost certain to make a difference in real estate values in the area, including property in nearby northwestern Connecticut. "Two years ago raw land surrounding Amenia sold for $6,000 an acre, but as the line was extended, it's now $10,000," said Elyse Harney, who owns Elyse Harney Real Estate in Salisbury, a Connecticut town 15 to 20 minutes from the Wassaic railroad station.
Even with its orchards, dairy farms and other wide open spaces, eastern Dutchess County's population has been growing slowly but steadily almost since 1984. That year, Metro-North completed its $75 million electrification of the railroad between North White Plains, in Westchester County, and Brewster, in Putnam County.
Metro-North officials said recently that they had no plans to extend the Harlem Line beyond Amenia (which, incidentally, had passenger train service for decades until 1972, when the troubled Penn Central abruptly pulled the plug).
But Arlene Iuliano, the Amenia town supervisor, is not convinced. "That's what they used to say about Amenia," she said. "It may take 10 or 20 years before they continue north, but they will."
TO build ridership, Metro-North made a decision not to stint on service. "So we're basically running the same number of trains into and out of Amenia that we run between Dover Plains and Grand Central," said Margaret Anders, a Metro-North spokeswoman. That means four trains to Manhattan during peak hours each weekday and eight off-peak trains, the first train departing at 5:13 a.m., the last at 10:33 p.m. There are 13 weekday trains from Manhattan to Wassaic. The commute takes about 2 hours and 15 minutes each way.
Since service started at the Wassaic and Tenmile stations, Ms. Anders said, ridership has averaged 167 passengers each weekday. That, of course, is only a tiny fraction of the total 24.3 million Harlem Line passengers that Metro-North projects for this year. But ridership on the upper Harlem Line is among the fastest growing throughout the Metro-North system.
A. J. Hayes, an Amenia realtor since 1971, said the Wassaic station's parking lot has already attracted many cars from neighboring Connecticut and Massachusetts. And an economic impact study of the Wassaic and Amenia areas, released in September 1999, forecast that residential real estate values in the region will increase over time as ridership to and from Wassaic increases.
The study forecast 12 percent annual growth rate in passengers using the Wassaic station, adding that "it is only a matter of time before the sites near the train terminus are developed." A study of real estate by Regina Armstrong for the New York Regional Plan Association projected that the extension of the railroad to Wassaic would eventually result in a 64 percent increase in the number of residences within the hamlet of Wassaic and 17 percent outside of the hamlet.
"We expect the train to Wassaic to bring in tourism dollars and raise property values," said Kathleen Schibanoff, executive director of the Harlem Valley Partnership, an economic and regional planning group. "And we expect it to bring a big migration of people who said they never would have considered a long commute, but change their minds when they have kids and think more about the quality of life."
Similar impulses were probably involved in 1980 to 1990, when there was a 30 percent increase in ridership from Dutchess County to White Plains, according to the economic survey, and a 108 percent increase in commuting to Manhattan.
Mr. Hayes, the realtor in Amenia, said that the real estate business had been slow in the area for years. "And since the railroad just started up, it's still a little early for customers to be lined up at the door wanting to buy," he said. "But the last six to eight months, real estate activity has really jumped up."
For the real estate business to break out of its slump and stay there, Wassaic and Amenia would need to attract more people and keep them. And keeping them, realtors say, especially those from big cities, requires a certain degree of patience and understanding on the part of longtime residents and newcomers alike.
Richard and Carol Papper of Manhattan, for example, bought a three-bedroom Victorian farmhouse in Salisbury, Conn., last December and consider the railroad a bonus. But one night while Mrs. Papper and the children were visiting her family out of town, Mr. Papper took the train to Wassaic, then a shuttle bus that dropped him off at a corner in Millerton, N.Y., closer to home.
But at that hour, about 8 p.m., he was unable to find a taxi at the station or at the spot the shuttle bus dropped him off. So he telephoned John Harney, the son of Elyse Harney, their realtor, to ask what to do. Mr. Harney picked Mr. Papper up and drove him home.
"So here was this New York boy who thought you could hail a taxi in the country like you can in New York," Mrs. Papper said, still amused by her husband's predicament, "and instead he was stranded less than 20 minutes from home."

HEADLINE: Oil and Poker

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "A Drop in the Barrel?", by Paul Krugman (column, Sept. 27): A poker player with a winning hand but not enough money to stay in the game is still a loser. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has much more oil than we do, and has shown a willingness to balance its economic needs against ours. The small release of oil from our reserve has far more to do with politics than prices. That arena, not the market, is where the real "manipulators" work.
 
ARNOLD AHLERT

HEADLINE: Economic Outsiders

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The most recent data issued from the Census Bureau reveal a continuation of the substantial decline in poverty since 1993 (news article, Sept. 27). The administration has every right to trumpet that welcome news, but there remains much of concern. 
 Nearly 40 percent of poor families in 1999 had incomes below half of the poverty threshold (the threshold was $13,290 for a family of three, for example). Further, the average income among all poor families fell nearly $6,700 short of the poverty threshold.
Our booming economy notwithstanding, millions have been left behind with profoundly insufficient economic resources.
 
NEIL G. BENNETT
New York, Sept. 27, 2000
 
The writer is a professor at the Baruch School of Public Affairs, CUNY.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Nora Odendahl, David Searls

 BODY:
Dr. Nora Vivian Odendahl and Dr. David Burdette Searls were married yesterday by the Rev. Christine Reed, a Unitarian Universalist minister, at Prospect House, the Princeton University faculty and staff club.
Dr. Odendahl, 44, will keep her name. She is a test developer for the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J. She graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College and received a doctorate in English from Princeton. She is the daughter of Alice Wallerstein of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Alan Odendahl, and is the stepdaughter of Leibert B. Wallerstein. Her mother retired as an adjunct professor teaching English to foreign students at Montgomery College in Rockville, Md. The bride's father was an economist for the Small Business Administration in Washington. 
 Dr. Searls, 49, is a vice president of SmithKline Beecham Pharmaceuticals, in King of Prussia, Pa., overseeing a computerized study of the human genome. He is a graduate of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and received a master's degree in computer science from the University of Pennsylvania, as well as a doctorate in biology from Johns Hopkins University. He is the son of Laura and Darrell Searls of Kennett Square, Pa. His mother retired as a teacher and secondary education administrator in Palos Heights, Ill. His father, also retired, was a consulting engineer and specialist in automated material-handling systems at the Austin Company, a design, construction and engineering firm in Cleveland.
The bride and bridegroom became acquainted in October 1998, when Dr. Searls responded to a posting by Dr. Odendahl on match.com, an online dating service.
"I was attracted to her background in English literature," Dr. Searls said. "Because I am a scientist, I've always felt an attraction to the humanities -- to counter the science." He added, "Her interest in biking and hiking were other areas where we were counterbalanced as well."
Dr. Odendahl said that what attracted her to him was how similar they were. He, too, had roots in academia. Both had made a transition to another career: for him, from academic biological research to research in the pharmaceutical industry; for her, from completing doctoral training for a teaching career to working as a test developer.
After a week or two of exchanging phone calls and e-mails, they met for a date on Penn's Landing in Philadelphia, on a tall ship converted into a restaurant.
"I thought it was a charming idea," Dr. Odendahl said. "I had mentioned that I had written my doctoral dissertation thesis on Melville and enjoyed writing it."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
Why Pay More? Go Ask The Germans

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THE events I'm about to relate are almost too terrible to publish in a family newspaper. Nothing is being done to halt the abuse I'm about to describe, but somebody has to blow the whistle. So if you're the squeamish type, turn the page now.
The situation is this: Not far from where I live in the Hudson Valley, a couple of stores named Aldi are engaged in the most outrageous of business practices. No, they are not selling drugs or trafficking in stolen property. What these stores do is offer customers groceries and other goods at unconscionably low prices -- so low, in fact, that even though each outlet is practically in the shadow of a Wal-Mart, a chain notorious for similar dealings, the Aldi outlets have managed to stay in business. 
 As a result of this scheme -- known to hardened economists by the deceptively clinical term "price competition" -- working people are seduced into shopping at Aldi's for the things their families need. Perhaps saddest of all, government authorities stand by and do nothing while this brazen trade in discounted cornflakes and children's shoes goes on in broad daylight.
Not so in Germany. There, enlightened officials at the aptly named German Cartel Office, aghast at the low prices in German Wal-Mart stores, recently stepped in and demanded that the big American discounter charge customers more for staples like milk, butter, flour and cooking oil. German competitors of Wal-Mart were also ordered to charge more, but they probably didn't mind, since the American company had started all the trouble.
The government's aim, it said, was to protect smaller grocers. The German Retail Trade Association, a trade group, applauded the decision as a "hopeful signal for the end of the ruinous cutthroat competition" between Wal-Mart and two rival German supermarket chains, Lidl and Aldi.
But wait a minute. Is that the same Aldi that freely and shamelessly competes on price at 549 stores in 21 states from upstate New York to Kansas? Indeed it is. In fact, on its Web site, the company boasts of how it keeps prices down by selling house brands in a no-frills setting; low prices are a major emphasis. In other words, Aldi of Germany is happily doing in this country precisely what Wal-Mart is being blocked from doing in Germany.
What is to be done? Well, we could retaliate against the Germans by making Aldi's stores on this side of the Atlantic charge us more. Consumers could even be exhorted to notify the authorities of any markdowns.
But in the absence of evidence of truly predatory pricing -- there certainly is no sign that Aldi is driving Wal-Mart to the brink -- what would be the point? Customers benefit from low prices, after all. One Aldi shopper I know, an older woman with a large family who has to scrimp to make ends meet, likes getting warehouse prices without having to pay membership fees. By forcing Aldi to charge more, the government would just be imposing a regressive tax on Aldi shoppers -- and making a gift of the proceeds to a German multinational.
It is easy to poke fun at regulators who insist on higher prices, and sooner or later German customers will demand a more competitive retail environment, with lower prices and longer store hours. Then the country's merchants will finally have to give people what they want, which, of course, is what retailing is all about.
But there is a much more interesting lesson here, one that goes far beyond the price of milk at Wal-Mart. For nations that impose them, trade restrictions are their own punishment. If the Germans do something stupid, like demanding that stores raise their prices, why should we follow suit?
IN other words, the only sensible approach to international trade is unilateral disarmament. The benefits of letting Aldi's compete freely with Wal-Mart -- and letting imports flow unrestricted -- are just too great, and any remedy we could impose would be worse than the "problem." Seen in this light, trade negotiations are like one of those standoffs in which an armed gunman takes himself hostage. As the economist N. Gregory Mankiw of Harvard likes to say, multilateral trade pacts mean agreeing with other nations that "I won't shoot myself in the foot if you won't shoot yourself in the foot."
Just to see what the reaction would be, I put in a call to executives at Aldi's American headquarters in Batavia, Ill., intending to plead with them to raise prices in their stores. They never called me back. Probably just as well: I might have persuaded them.
