SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Style Desk

LENGTH: 1497 words

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE;
Hitching a Vintage Ride to the Past

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
THERE are two kinds of car people," Jan Voboril told me as we climbed into his 1916 Lancia convertible. "One likes to polish them, one likes to drive them. I think it's much more fun to drive. Wouldn't you rather cook than do the dishes?"
Sure. But even the dishes sounded more appealing than the prospect of driving over the George Washington Bridge in an 84-year-old car with no roof and no doors on one of the windiest days of the year. I would get my fill of the polishers soon enough, once we reached the Louis Vuitton Classic at Rockefeller Center. The event, which was held last weekend and has been an annual occurrence since 1995, is an outdoor exhibition of 50 of the world's rarest classic cars -- the lush, romantic kind Jay Gatsby would have owned. 
 The Vuitton Classic judges cars on their rarity, impeccable provenance (whether they are original or reconstituted), history (whether a celebrity or famous race car driver owned it or drove it) and engineering excellence. There are more car enthusiasts today then ever, said the show's curator, Murray Livingstone Smith, who races vintage cars around the world. And with the present economy, more people are buying, everyone from "the chairman of Wal-Mart to guys at Microsoft," he added. The cars in this year's show were worth about $40 million.
Though the usual venues for vintage cars this valuable are private estates or country clubs, the idea for showing them in the streets was Mr. Smith's. His hunch that the general public might take a liking to the show was right. According to the New York Police Department, last year's event drew two million spectators.
This year, Mr. Smith had another hunch. For the first time, he instituted the New York Style Awards at the classic. "Generally speaking, cars are only judged by car people," Mr. Smith said. "I wanted to take people with aesthetic sensibilities and see how the cars appeal to them. A great design has great value. A Balenciaga dress that was good then is good now."
Mr. Smith assembled a jury of eight style mavens that included Eileen and Jerry Ford, founders of the Ford Modeling Agency; Martha Nelson, managing editor, In Style magazine; Dana Cowin, editor in chief, Food & Wine magazine; Brenda Cooper, host of E! channel's "Fashion Emergency"; Laurin Sydney, anchor, CNN's "Showbiz Today"; Amy Fine Collins, special correspondent, Vanity Fair; and Tiffany Dubin, vintage fashion expert.
The idea of linking cars and fashion is nothing new. In the early 1920's, the French paired the latest couturier fashions with the most elegant automobile designs, calling it a concours d'elegance, a competition of elegance. Cars would be judged with models posing beside them, and wealthy individuals would then order their own custom-built cars and custom-made gowns.
Those events virtually disappeared during World War II, but were reinstated in the economic boom of the 1950's, a trend that was celebrated in a 1997 exhibition at the Fashion Institute of Technology called "Fashion: Automobile Fabrics of the 1950's." That was the decade when women who bought the 1952 Crown Victoria Ford were given a coat to match their new car, and Dodge buyers could order the 1955 La Femme in pink and white, with a matching shoulder bag, lipstick case and compact.
I thought about coordinated cars and outfits as I joined Mr. Voboril for the last leg of his journey in his 1916 Lancia; he had started in Los Angeles less than a week earlier. One of the best-known classic car restorers in this country, he bought the car for $2,300 in 1973, and has put 130,000 miles on it.
I met him in New Jersey, and though the temperature was in the 80's, he gave me a heavy blue baseball jacket to ward off the wind on the bridge. I had tied a Hermes scarf around my head, imagining how glamorous I would look, but he insisted I anchor it with a red baseball cap. I ended up looking like a refugee from the right side of the tracks in Anatevka who had somehow wandered into a seventh-inning stretch.
Mr. Voboril says he estimates the car to be worth "about $100,000." For that kind of money you'd think you'd get a key, but he had to get down on all fours to start it somewhere underneath. As he tried, he drew quite a crowd in the parking lot of a Marriott hotel near the bridge. One man said confidently, "It will never start." Mr. Voboril responded, "It's not getting it going that's the problem, it's stopping it." Oh, swell.
Once on the road, Mr. Voboril was intent on getting Lancia up to her full speed of 85 miles an hour, and, I'm sorry to say, nearly succeeded. I clutched the outside of the car for ballast while sliding off my shoes so I could grip the floor with my bare feet. The car had no well for legs; the floor was flat out in front of us.
Mr. Voboril, whose complexion resembles a rock formation, clearly relishes being at one with the elements. He was also so completely bonded with the car, driving it with both feet and a stick shift, that he pulled me out of my fear. To drive in a car like this is to travel through time, to see what it must have been like nearly a century ago for the first people to try a swift motor car. The thrill of adventure seemed to dance all around us as we crossed the bridge, the sun glittering hard on the water, the open sky beckoning.
As he pulled into Rockefeller Center, the crowd applauded and toasted his journey's end with Champagne.
To try out city driving (utterly tame but for the finger-pointing), I took a quick spin through Central Park with Mr. Smith, who borrowed a Mercedes 300 SL convertible, circa 1963, for the occasion. "These cars are so idiosyncratic," he said. "They have their own characters."
Our Mercedes must have been menopausal; the heat seemed to be on high, and Mr. Smith was understandably reluctant to fool with it. Within minutes, we were soaked with sweat.
By the time the style jury arrived, though, he had cleaned up. "Don't worry about the technical, choose what you like," Mr. Smith encouraged them. They were selecting four categories: Best Car for a Night on the Town; Timeless Style Regardless of Age; the Car I Would Most Like to Own; the Most Surprising Car.
What would the winners get? "Prestige," Mr. Smith said. "And the car jumps in value."
Out the jurors went, clipboards in hand. Mrs. Ford fell immediately in love. "I want that Rolls convertible sedan," she said, pointing to a breathtaking dark green 1910 Rolls-Royce Silver Ghost Tourer with three banks of seats. Ms. Sydney, however, was more interested in Ms. Dubin's boots, an exquisite camel leather with maroon diamond patterns that she had bought at Colette in Paris. "I'd like to drive those boots out of here more than any car," Ms. Sydney said hungrily.
Mostly everyone exclaimed over the 1940 Duesenberg, the last one ever built. Its former owner, the German painter Rudolph Bauer, who was sent to a concentration camp, reclaimed ownership after the war; the car was bought by a restorer and still has its original tires.
The car's interior was purple leather. "It's so chic," Ms. Cowin said. "That purple interior is so this season."
Ms. Cooper agreed. "I would have expected deep burgundy," she said.
Everyone marveled at the car that Mr. Smith called the Copper Kettle, a 1921 copper Rolls-Royce that its owner says takes 50 hours to clean. Its battery was housed in a polished wooden box.
The menopausal Mercedes fared well, too. "It has that early Bondian quality," Ms. Nelson said.
Transcending even Bond was the 1925 Rolls-Royce Phantom 1 Torpedo, which was on exhibition but not in competition. It's former owner, the Maharajah of Bekanur, used it to hunt tiger on his 25,000-square-mile estate. The car was equipped with special ammunition cases and twin express rifles.
Ms. Collins arrived only as the rest of the judges were finishing, but she quickly discovered that her purple shoes were a perfect match for the Duesenberg interior. She was the envy of them all.
I checked in on the Lancia. In his zeal to champion the drivers versus the polishers, Mr. Voboril had not only skipped the polish; he hadn't even washed the car or removed the dead bugs from the front grate. The style judges just shook their heads. I found Mr. Voboril.
"Why didn't you at least wash it?" I demanded. One ride and the car was mine. He shrugged. "It was going to rain," he said.
Needless to say, the Lancia didn't win. The 1940 Duesenberg won for a Night on the Town; the dark green 1910 Rolls-Royce won for Timeless Style Regardless of Age; Most Surprising was the silver 1936/37 Dubonnet Hispano; and Most Like to Own was the 1953 Ferrari 342 America.
Poor Lancia. I went back outside to take one last look, but my view was blocked by an elderly couple standing in front of it. They were transported.
"Isn't that beautiful?" the woman gushed, positioning her camera.
"Fantastic," her husband exclaimed. "Simply fantastic."
He smiled at me and I nodded. Justice at last.

HEADLINE: Customers Flock, and the T-Shirts Fly

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HAYT

 BODY:
NOT every designer can trace his inspiration to the surfers off Newport Beach, Calif., glimpsed on a cross-country motorcycle trip. But that is where Custodio Dalmau, better known as Custo, the designer of Custo Barcelona, had his creative epiphany.
"On the coast from Los Angeles to San Diego, I saw the first printed T-shirt in my life," he recalled. "It existed in Europe as a means for publicity, to advertise something, but not as a fashion statement. I saw a classic surfing T-shirt with a palm tree and a wave rider. It was the experience of my life." 
 Today Mr. Dalmau's snug-fitting psychedelic T-shirts decorated with images of party girls are the marquee items of a moderately priced clothing line that has a cult following. Customers line up for the designer's personal appearances, and many scour the country for every T-shirt he has ever created -- customers like Julieana Choy, 25, an office manager in Manhattan who lives in Fairfield, N.J., and has over 200 Custo Barcelona items.
"I research his T-shirts to get as many as possible," she said. "I contact distributors before each season so that I know what will be in each store. I separate my 1998 shirts from '99 and 2000 and keep the seasons separate, too."
A resident of Barcelona, Mr. Dalmau makes playful clothing that seems to echo that city's whimsical Antonio Gaudi buildings and Surrealist Miro paintings. At his Fashion Week show last month in Bryant Park, his sixth in New York, the models flounced down the runway in outfits splashed with red and pink polka dots, tan suede fringe and disco-style metallics. Set to techno music mixed by a French-African D.J., the collection looked like "I Dream of Jeannie" meets the rave scene.
"They're clothes to dance till 8 in the morning in," said Kim Hastreiter, an editor and publisher of Paper magazine, who was at the show. "He has a huge following. It's kind of like Betsey Johnson. But Betsey is more girly, and he's more clubby or Ibiza-y."
Since 1996, when Custo Barcelona was introduced in a few boutiques in the United States, ringing up $500,000 at wholesale, the brand has grown rapidly. Today it is sold in department stores like Saks Fifth Avenue, Henri Bendel and Neiman Marcus, with projected wholesale revenues this year of $25 million, Mr. Dalmau said. Worldwide, the line is expected to total $50 million this year. Ranging from $65 for a T-shirt to $300 for a cashmere and silk sweater, Custo Barcelona offers an economical way to embrace the swirling prints currently in fashion, compared with the four-figure designer versions from Fendi, Pucci and Versace.
"Custo came at just the right time when people wanted a change," said Joan Kaner, the senior vice president and fashion director of Neiman Marcus. "Fashion had turned a corner from minimalism and modernist. The line is about pattern and color and fun. The lady who buys Custo is interested in fun and fashion without a heavy investment."
Retailers across the country confirmed that Custo Barcelona is so popular that the items rarely go on sale. Although Mr. Dalmau isn't the only designer who makes appearances in stores, his habit of autographing his T-shirts has proved irresistible. Before a visit in March to Christians, a boutique in Raleigh, N.C., the store sent customers notices and a local newspaper wrote about the designer. Throngs lined up at the door, credit cards in hand.
"I've been in business 17 years and I've never seen anything like Custo," said Nancy Steelman, the owner of the store. "We sold over 400 units in four hours. We saw people from the military bases of North Carolina. We saw 13-year-old girls to an 85-year-old woman who wore a Custo and had it signed."
Similarly, when Mr. Dalmau made an appearance in April at Henri Bendel on Fifth Avenue, the line stretched to 25 people and the cash registers rang up over 400 shirts in three hours. The store had never sold so many items by a single designer in so short a time, said Gayle Scheck, the department manager for market collections.
At the two Vin Baker boutiques in Santa Monica and Los Angeles, Custo Barcelona is the most profitable of 40 labels, Joe Peach, the owner, said. His best customers are middle-aged women, former flower children, he said, who relate to the graphics, which hark back to the 1960's and 70's. When Mr. Peach posted a date for a T-shirt signing by Mr. Dalmau on the store's Web site, he got orders from around the world.
Mr. Dalmau, 44, is tan and short with rugged good looks. His deep voice and Castilian accent enhance his caballero appeal. Although his designs feature a palette of flamingo pink, peacock blue and canary yellow, he himself prefers a uniform of black and white. Only his long dark hair curling around the nape of his neck, his sandals and a thick silver necklace adorned with a few chunky crucifixes hint at the flower child within.
Twenty years ago, Mr. Dalmau dropped out of architecture school at the University of Barcelona to take a two-year motorcycle trip with friends. To finance their journey, they planned to write about their travels for motorcycle magazines. In June 1980, they began their adventure in Washington Square Park and rode to California. It was there that Mr. Dalmau saw the T-shirt that he says shaped his career.
After the trip, he briefly returned to San Diego to learn to surf. In 1982, he went back to Barcelona, where he had grown up, and started a T-shirt business with his brother, David, four years his junior, who assumed the role of financial manager.
It took 13 years of false starts before the T-shirts evolved beyond simple central images derived from surfer culture to the elaborate designs of today: a mix of vibrant colors and retro prints combined with illustrations of hipster chicks in bell-bottoms, shades, hats and heels, sipping martinis, having a swell time. Recently, Mr. Dalmau began adding fanciful details to the tops, like sequins, eyelets and knit trim, and diversified the collection by including skirts, dresses, pants, tops and even men's wear.
Katherine Coats, 35, an optometrist in Holly Springs, N.C., is a typical collector. Two years ago, she spotted a T-shirt on a store mannequin and liked the retro design. The splashy style also reminded her of Fran Drescher's wardrobe on the television show "The Nanny."
Before long, Ms. Coats was a Custo addict. Every store in the Raleigh area that carries the line now calls her when a shipment comes in. She has instructed them to hold one T-shirt in her size in every style until she can get in to make her selection. Competition for the tops is so fierce that she has been forced to comb the country in her hunt for them.
"I've bought them in Nordstrom's in D.C.," she said. "I tracked down one in Atlanta and another in Texas. I went to a T-shirt signing, and it was unbelievable. There were 15 people lined up outside the store before it even opened. I got there at 9:30 and there were already women ahead of me."

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
One Home's Unplanned Addition: A Courtroom

BYLINE: By ROY FURCHGOTT

DATELINE: BALTIMORE

 BODY:
BE had done all the right things. We checked the record of the home improvement contractor with state regulators and the Better Business Bureau. We inspected the contractor's jobs in progress. We checked references. And we wrote and signed a detailed contract and an additional written agreement that the contractor would forfeit $100 for each day the job ran late. If the work didn't go smoothly, we thought, we were covered.
Yet, a year later, we were in a Baltimore courtroom, fighting over a project that had run months late and was never finished -- and it was the contractor who was suing us. 
 The contractor-homeowner relationship is a famously fraught one, of course. Almost everyone has heard horror stories about remodeling projects from hell, and read the usual tips about how to head off trouble.
But what happens when the dispute winds up in litigation is seldom dissected. Our experience disabused us of some cherished notions about day-to-day civil justice and exposed the near-uselessness of many of our precautions, especially when contractors are in such short supply that homeowners have almost no leverage over them.
The story starts with a house that my girlfriend, Guillemette Brouillat, bought in November 1998 in Canton, a mainly industrial area of Baltimore being gentrified with a technology center, stores and waterfront condominiums. She paid $77,000 for a fixer-upper near the tech center on a block that seemed poised for a renaissance. Together, we set out to get the place up to scratch.
After interviewing about a dozen contractors, we chose Russell L. Miller, a friend of a friend of mine. Mr. Miller returned calls promptly, showed up on time for meetings, had good references, no complaints against him on file, and he didn't object to our desire to do the paint and tile work ourselves.
He was not the least-expensive contractor around, but time meant as much to Guillemette as price, because of the high cost of renting space elsewhere while the work was done. Plus, her mortgage agreement mandated higher interest charges during construction, and a six-month deadline for completion.
Demolition started on time, and the framing went quickly. But progress soon slowed, then seemed to come to a halt. The nine weeks specified in the contract elapsed. Nervous, we started doing more of the work ourselves, and barely got the house to a state that would satisfy the bank in time.
As is usual with home improvements, Mr. Miller had been receiving partial payments along the way, with a final payment of $7,314 due on completion, plus $1,899 for work added to the project after it had begun. But by our initial reckoning, the job ran 91 days over, making the late fee $9,100, almost as much as the $9,212 we owed Mr. Miller. We wrote to him, offering to pay $1,899 for the extra work and call the rest even. That was a lot less than he was expecting but, we thought, more than he was strictly entitled to. We awaited a counterproposal.
Instead, Guillemette was served with a legal notice: Mr. Miller's company, M & M Restorations, wanted to put a lien on the house for the entire $9,212, ignoring the late fees, and was suing us to do so.
We hired a lawyer, Thomas A. Baker, a construction industry specialist, who explained to us our first mistake: calling the $100-a-day fee a penalty. As in most other states, Maryland law generally allows "damages" for whatever the delay cost us out of pocket, but not "penalties," so a judge could throw out the whole contract on that technicality, Mr. Baker said.
Financially speaking, mistake No. 2 was plowing ahead with litigation despite Mr. Baker's warning that the cost could rapidly outstrip the amount at issue. But an emotional calculus was at work: Guillemette was losing sleep worrying about the dispute, fighting back would make us feel better, and lawyers don't charge all that much more than therapists. So we countersued, asking for a delay penalty that we now reckoned at $9,800, plus $4,521 to repair faulty work.
Over the next few months, Mr. Baker had us spend tedious hours amassing an accordion file full of photographs, specification sheets, building codes, timetables and other evidence to support our claim. Meanwhile, we received the specifics of M & M's claim, which basically said the delay was our fault.
(Asked last week to comment for this article, Mr. Miller said: "Delays were caused by the homeowner's inability to complete the work she had charged herself with doing in a reasonable amount of time.")
We were sure that, given our evidence, the court had to back our delay claim. But that was mistake No. 3. Irrespective of proof, Mr. Baker told us, courts generally discard such claims: "Judges tend to say, 'Is the work complete? If so, pay the contractor.' "
On Mr. Baker's advice, we grudgingly switched our sights to more promising legal territory: work defects. Courts, he said, usually support homeowners who hold back from a contractor the amounts they spend to correct poor work. But by fixing some problems ourselves and putting others off, we had made mistake No. 4: The courts, Mr. Baker told us, care only about money actually spent and rarely compensate homeowners for work they do themselves.
(Asked last week to comment on the faulty-work claim, Mr. Miller said, "There were no complaints from the homeowner to myself or any of my employees until after I had brought a lawsuit against them.")
We were learning that at this level, lawsuits are anything but a high-minded contest of evidence and argument. The court's main goal is to clear cases from a crowded docket, and there is little patience for aggrieved homeowners expecting meticulous pursuit of the truth.
When our first court date arrived in May, neither side had budged from an initial meeting in which we had offered to pay $4,000 of the $9,212 Mr. Miller wanted, but he had come down by only $1,000, to $8,212.
Before hearing any arguments or testimony, Judge Richard T. Rombro called the lawyers into chambers to get the bidding going again. We raised our offer to $5,200, Mr. Miller came down to $7,412, and Mr. Baker told us we seemed headed for a settlement at around $6,000. We thought we could do better in a trial -- mistake No. 5, since each additional day in court added $1,500 to our legal fees. But the emotional math still added up, so we held firm.
The next time around, in mid-June before Judge John C. Byrnes, the settlement tango was reprised. "The judge thinks the case will settle for $6,000," our lawyer told us. Still too high, we thought. But when Mr. Miller unexpectedly agreed to that figure, we were on the spot: refusing might seem unreasonable to the judge, who might find for Mr. Miller in a trial to teach us a lesson. Still, the judge had yet to see our evidence. We decided to roll the dice.
That might have become mistake No. 6, but for a curious turn of events. The judge called Guillemette into chambers -- "to bang her over the head," Mr. Baker told me outside. The judge was polite but firm, Guillemette reported afterward: "He said, 'We are not trying this case over a couple of hundred dollars.' "
Guillemette offered to drop the delay claim, and told the judge, "I just want enough to fix the defects." He asked what proof she had -- any photographs, perhaps?
At last! Guillemette produced our bulging accordion file, starting with holes in water-damaged basement walls where light could be seen streaming in. "They left it like that?" he asked her, amazed. Guillemette was dismissed and Mr. Miller summoned.
We soon settled on a payment of $5,800 of the $9,212 Mr. Miller wanted. All our trouble had won us a reduction of $3,412.
We considered it a moral victory, if a pyrrhic one -- Mr. Baker's bill came to $6,914, even after a generous gift of a day's fees, and the house still needed work. Over sandwiches afterward, we discussed how justice works in a case like ours.
Mr. Baker explained that while our case was unique and all-important to us, judges have seen thousands like it. "The judge first meets with the lawyers to see if he trusts them," Mr. Baker said -- a wash in our case, with experienced local lawyers on each side. Next, the judge might ask a few questions to help steer the parties toward a settlement. Evidence might only enter into the matter to satisfy the judge's curiosity, as in our case, or at a trial, if settlement talks failed.
Our fight didn't make economic sense in the end, but we thought that we would at least be leaving a record that could guide other homeowners. Again we were mistaken. To complete the settlement, we had to agree to withdraw a complaint we had filed against M & M with the Maryland Home Improvement Commission -- and the Better Business Bureau does not report complaints that have been settled out of court. There is a public record of the suit at the courthouse, but you'd have to know just where to look.
Having learned some expensive lessons, we thought next about the remodeling work that my house needs, and asked Mr. Baker how we could immunize ourselves against winding up in court again.
"You can't," he said, almost cheerfully. He insisted on paying for lunch.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Jean-Pierre Conreur;
Tocqueville Small Cap Value Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
ALEXIS DE TOCQUEVILLE, the French historian and philosopher, visited the young United States in the early 1830's and wrote "Democracy in America," concluding that the democratic system would indeed survive for the long term.
"It was a revolutionary idea at the time," said Jean-Pierre Conreur, who runs the $35.4 million Tocqueville Small Cap Value fund. "The name implies contrarian thinking. It's like our value investing style, which is based on the belief that the majority is usually wrong." 
 That perspective has paid off for investors, even in the bull market. The fund has returned 12.9 percent a year, on average, for the three years ended on Sept. 28, compared with 6.6 percent for its peers in the small blend category of funds, according to Morningstar Inc.
In choosing the 35 or so stocks for the fund, Mr. Conreur, 62, trolls the bottom of the market, looking for undervalued companies with market capitalizations of $250 million to $1 billion.
"I look at companies that all the Wall Street analysts have given up on," he said in a thick French accent, despite his 44 years in the United States, mostly in New York. "They are ignored for very good reasons -- like the company missed its projected earnings or is in the midst of a product line transition or a deep cyclical downturn."
The companies he chooses are typically down 60 to 80 percent from their five-year highs -- and there are many such stocks from which to choose in a volatile market. "The market is driven by earnings and price momentum," he said. "As a result, we get extreme valuations on the upside and on the downside."
He uses three computer screens. The first looks for companies whose stocks are selling near 52-week lows. Then comes a search for price-to-sales multiples that are near their lows of the last 5 or 10 years; the companies in the portfolio sell for just one times their annual revenue, on average.
"Because the American economy has been booming over the last 12 years, many companies have extraordinarily high profit margins, which translate into very high price-sales ratios," Mr. Conreur said. "If anything happens to those margins, stock prices will collapse."
Finally, he screens the usual financial data, including long-term debt, accounts payable and receivable and reinvestment in the business. "We're checking to see that a company's short-term problems don't affect its long-term picture," he said.
MR. CONREUR works with three industry analysts to evaluate whether a company can return at least triple his investment over the next three to five years. They ask questions of company management, to learn whether a business plan is in place to fix problems over the next year or so. Then they monitor the plan's progress to make sure that the company does not shift gears midway.
The analysts also check to see if, as Mr. Conreur puts it, "the company is losing money for the right reasons," like heavy investments in research and development or new equipment.
Mr. Conreur sells stock when its valuation triples or quadruples or when insiders dump a big block of shares.
His biggest holding is Input/Output of Stafford, Tex., one of the largest American makers of seismic equipment used in oil and gas exploration, primarily on land. Its stock price fell from $40 in 1998 to $5.33 in October 1999, when he first bought shares. Mr. Conreur attributes the drop to the collapse in oil and gas prices last year, which caused a drastic cutback in exploration equipment purchases by major oil companies. While prices have since shot up, companies have not yet made major investments in needed exploration equipment, he said. But that is "just a matter of time," he added.
The shares closed on Friday at $9.63, or 160 times consensus earnings estimates of 6 cents a share for the fiscal year ending next May.
Mr. Conreur also likes Anixter International of Skokie, Ill., the former distribution arm of AT&T. He expects sales of its telecommunications equipment to grow over the next few years, "because many businesses and buildings must be rewired to deliver new high-speed communications networks to small businesses." Anixter's share price fell after it missed several quarters' earnings projections following the 1998 Asian economic crisis; the fund bought shares in October 1998 at $14.50; they are now at $14.75 or six times Wall Street earnings projections of $2.45 a share for 2001.
"Wall Street is waking up a little bit to the stock," he said, "but it still sells for a modest multiple."
Another holding is Henry Schein Inc. of Melville, N.Y., which was the second-largest distributor of dental supplies until 1997, when it acquired Sullivan Dental, the third-largest, and jumped to first. Because the acquisition was difficult to integrate, the company missed its earnings projections in 1999.
"Talks with management convinced us that the integration problems were being resolved," Mr. Conreur said, "and it should become a growth business again over the next year or so."
The fund bought shares in August 1999 at $11.47; they closed on Friday at $19.94 or 10.6 times the consensus earnings estimate of $1.87 a share for 2001.

HEADLINE: A Matter of Degree? Not for Consultants

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT

DATELINE: WELLESLEY, Mass.

 BODY:
THERE was a doctor from Boston and a lawyer from Chicago, a philosopher from Australia and an engineer from France. There were people who had Ph.D.'s in mathematics, sociology and astronautics. In fact, in the tiered classroom filled with 50 clean-cut, casually dressed people in their 20's and 30's, there seemed to be just about every graduate degree imaginable, except one: the M.B.A.
Yet within a few weeks, this hyper-educated crowd would go forth as certified management consultants, advising the executives of multibillion-dollar companies. Their projects would, most likely, have little to do with their academic backgrounds. Lawyers would help packaged-foods companies develop new products, and physicists would tell Internet start-ups how to stand out from the crowd. 
 To prepare, the neophyte consultants had come to the campus of Babson College here in this western Boston suburb for a three-week crash course in the basics of business. It was run by their new employer, the Boston Consulting Group.
When it was over, the class would be unleashed on corporate America. "This," said one student, Susan Meine, a lawyer from Atlanta, "allows me to get a business education without getting a degree."
To a growing and surprising extent, this is also how the entry level looks at the most prestigious management consulting firms, ones that count the world's biggest companies among their clients and that have long been dominated by M.B.A.'s. More than half of the consultants at McKinsey & Company do not have a Master of Business Administration degree, a share that is up sharply from a decade ago. Some 20 percent of Boston Consulting's new hires in the United States fall into the same category this year -- four times the level in 1995. Other firms are following suit.
Perhaps most striking are the results: the lawyers and doctors and philosophers perform no worse than their business school counterparts, according to internal studies done by the firms. If anything, they are promoted faster, on average.
All of this raises an interesting and disquieting question: What is the point of an M.B.A., anyway? If there is a single job for which business school -- with its broad curriculum and a teaching method heavy on case studies -- prepares someone, it is consulting. Yet the very consulting firms that are most popular among M.B.A.'s -- as well as with companies -- are now turning increasingly to people with none of this training.
 Part of the explanation is simple. With the tightest labor market in at least 30 years, particularly so for high-paying professional jobs, companies of all kinds are searching in new places for talented people. Consulting firms are especially hungry; they have seen their revenues nearly double in the last four years, according to Kennedy Information, which tracks the industry.
The consulting firms still hire hundreds of M.B.A.'s and say they would sign up even more if many of the most desirable candidates were not instead joining dot-com companies that can lure them with equity stakes.
But another aspect of the shift is more complex. Partners at places like Bain & Company and McKinsey have increasingly recognized that their profession does not require much specific training.
"Frankly, business is in some ways not that difficult to learn," said Rajat Gupta, McKinsey's managing partner. "We can pick up people who have not studied business and can teach them, if they have the intellectual firepower."
THE underlying issue -- whether business practices are best taught in an academic setting or should be learned on the job, as they are in an apprenticeship -- is at least as old as the M.B.A. Since Harvard started awarding the degree in 1910, some educators have derided business schools as intellectual deserts. The harshest critics say the two years spent earning an M.B.A. are little more than an extended job search and a chance to build of network of contacts.
The skeptics note, for example, that Harvard Business School offers business cards bearing the school's crest to its students shortly after they arrive. Stanford, the nation's most selective business school, does not even hold classes on Wednesdays -- which allows many of the students to hit the university's immaculate golf course.
Outside the leafy walls of universities, however, the degree has become known as a golden passport, a credential that is nearly a requirement for joining upper management. The current chief executives of General Motors, Goldman Sachs, Hewlett-Packard, I.B.M., Merck and Nike, for instance, all hold the passport -- as does, for the first time this year, a major-party nominee for president, George W. Bush. The M.B.A., its many supporters say, gives people a business grounding that they would otherwise need years to learn.
Over a two-year curriculum, a business school exposes its students to hundreds of corporate scenarios and allows them to learn valuable lessons by making mistakes that would be unacceptable at a for-profit company, professors say. That is why many companies, whether investment banks or packaged-good conglomerates, are doing little to diversify their graduate-school hiring.
STILL, from some perspectives, these are not the best of times for the M.B.A. The strong economy has left many potential students satisfied with their current jobs -- or eager to join start-ups. If Bill Gates or Jeff Bezos didn't need an M.B.A., some people wonder why they do, either. Also, with technology rapidly and fundamentally changing so many industries, other people worry that two years spent outside the work force is too long.
Last year, the number of applications fell at nearly every highly ranked business school, markedly at some. The number of applicants to Stanford has declined 23 percent in the last two years. Over the same period, the downturn was 10 percent at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School -- proclaimed the nation's best in Business Week's recent ranking. At the University of Virginia, applications fell 24 percent.
Deans of business schools point out that many of the declines have followed record high numbers of applications. On the other hand, those decreases would have been even steeper without the continued influx of foreign applicants, who now make up one-third of the student body on many campuses.
Companies, for their part, are increasing the amount of training they offer on their own, said Richard Schmalensee, the dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
"At the moment, there is some erosion in the notion that the M.B.A. is a required ticket of admission" to a successful business career, Mr. Schmalensee said. "What I can't tell is how much of that is cyclical and how much is secular" or, more structural.
Arguably, no development presents as much of an intellectual challenge to the rationale for business school as the consulting firms' new hiring and training practices. Consulting has been and remains the most popular job for fresh M.B.A. graduates. Despite the appeal of dot-com start-ups, the demand for jobs at firms like the Boston Consulting Group is high enough that its partners recruit at only about a dozen business schools -- and they make offers to a small number of the candidates they interview. In other words, even for an M.B.A., the odds of landing such a job are long -- and the pool of potential hires for the consulting firms is deep.
But rather than dip too much further into it, the firms are turning to people with almost no business experience. Booz Allen & Hamilton, after years of ad hoc hiring of non-M.B.A.'s, started formally recruiting Ph.D.'s on campus last year and expects that one-third of its new consultants this year will not have M.B.A.'s. This fall, Bain is visiting M.I.T., Stanford and a handful of other universities to woo doctoral students for the first time.
Instead of spending two years learning about finance and marketing, as business school students do, the new breed of consultants spends a few weeks in programs like Boston Consulting's version. They skim through subjects that get months of attention in an M.B.A. program.
Booz Allen and McKinsey call their versions the "mini-M.B.A." McKinsey runs one program each month somewhere in Europe or North America; they are less frequent at Booz Allen.
The graduates -- or mini-graduates, as it were -- are thriving. The London office of Boston Consulting, for example, recently found that its non-M.B.A.'s were receiving better evaluations, on average, than their peers who had gone to business school, according to one consultant there.
The new consultants do not even seem to need much time to catch up to their M.B.A. counterparts. McKinsey, long the most aggressive firm in courting other degree holders, recently looked around the world at its consultants who had been on the job for one, three or seven years. "At all three points," said A. Mini Harris, the manager of the firm's recruiting and herself a Stanford M.B.A., "the folks who don't have a business background are at least as successful."
That said, the statistics indicate that business school is still a good investment for its graduates. Most graduates of the very top schools make more than $125,000 in their first year after receiving their degrees. Even at less selective schools, M.B.A.'s often graduate to jobs that pay twice what their previous positions did.
But the hiring experiment by the consulting firms does raise the issue of why companies seek out M.B.A.'s. Is it for what they have learned? Or because the admissions offices of business schools have picked out smart people who show an interest in a business career? "It is a prescreened pool," said Jill Rupple, a partner at Diamond Technology Partners, a consulting firm that hired 85 M.B.A.'s last year and few lawyers, doctors or Ph.D.'s. "That is one of the traditional reasons strategy firms have gone to business schools."
FROM their founding, business schools have been subject to questions of legitimacy that their fellow professional schools in law and medicine have rarely faced (but that schools of journalism and education often have). Some academics have fretted that commerce is an inherently unscientific field and that the study of it sullies a university. Many business people have harbored doubts that intellectuals have much to teach them anyway.
Nearly 120 years ago, however, Joseph Wharton, a wealthy Philadelphia ironmaster, dismissed such doubts, giving the University of Pennsylvania $100,000 to create the first modern business school. It was 1881, and Mr. Wharton, 55 at the time, was concerned that colleges were not adequately preparing their students, the future elites of the management ranks, for the rapidly industrializing American economy.
Management education, Mr. Wharton wrote to the university's trustees in proposing the new venture, "would greatly aid in producing a class of men likely to become most useful members of society, whether in private or public life."
Dartmouth followed in 1900, by setting up the first graduate school of business, while the faculty at Harvard was intensely debating whether to do likewise.
Charles W. Eliot, its president, soon became convinced that companies were promoting unqualified people, based on nepotism or guesswork, and that the nation's economy could suffer as a result.
"A young man who is going into business had better take an academic course, in my sense of the term, if he has any mind to train," the president wrote in 1901, according to the official history of Harvard Business School. "That is an indisputable proposition, and there is no use discussing it."
Not everyone was so sure. "General business is a pretty vague thing, for which it is probably impossible to give anything like a professional training," wrote A. Lawrence Lowell, a government professor who would later succeed Mr. Eliot as president.
Eventually, the proponents won over many of the skeptics. Harvard Business School opened in 1908, and the first Master of Business Administration degrees were awarded two years later to eight students. (Dartmouth's degree had a different name.) Today, some 900 American universities award a master's in business, and each year 170,000 people around the world take the standardized test that nearly all schools require for admission. Students then pay up to $30,000 annually in tuition.
Over the last 50 years, business schools have alternately emphasized so-called hard skills, like finance, and soft ones, like leadership, which are more popular now. Either way, the typical M.B.A. curriculum, in both length and rigor, is a far cry from the "Business Essentials Program" that the Boston Consulting was holding at Babson.
The teachers were senior members of the firm and professors from various business schools who came here for a few days of lectures each. Management accounting took up three days. Finance lasted two.
A Tuesday afternoon toward the end of the program was typical of the compromises that were necessary.
Pacing back and forth in the well of the classroom, a professor was leading a discussion on pricing when he turned toward the class with a question: When should a firm charge high prices and when should it set low ones? None of the soon-to-be consultants responded. So the teacher -- who asked not to be identified because his school did not want to be publicly associated with the Boston Consulting Group program -- answered his own question and quickly told an insurance industry anecdote to make his point.
In an 80-minute session that tried to cover the same material as five full M.B.A. classes, the professor said, he could not spend a half-hour helping the students arrive at every answer on their own.
Already, in one afternoon, the class had analyzed case studies about two Internet companies -- VerticalNet and Freemarkets OnLine -- and had debated which one had a more sustainable business model. Afterward, a mathematician and an aeronautics Ph.D. in the class engaged in a role-playing exercise, one of them acting as the head of procurement for General Electric and the other as a small cabinetmaker. Then the professor drew a matrix on a dry-erase board, collecting ideas from the class about which kinds of companies benefit from business-to-business Web sites.
AFTER class, the students boarded a bus for downtown Boston and watched the Red Sox beat the Oakland A's, 10-3, from the right-field stands of Fenway Park. Two nights later, the consultants shared a graduation dinner, and their 20-day sprint, filled with 17 days of classes, was over. They returned to their offices, in Toronto, San Francisco, Seoul and points beyond, to work alongside M.B.A's and have their firm charge clients $100 an hour, and more, for their time.
Typically, the consultants are eager to get to their new challenge, either to earn more money or to escape the repetitive and isolated nature of their former fields, they said. "In science, you're not rewarded for being a good team player," said Kian Beyzavi, a Ph.D. in electrical engineering, who now works for McKinsey.
At Babson, there seemed to be a unanimous feeling among the doctors and lawyers that they would be at little if any disadvantage. The three-week program was helping them learn the vocabulary of corporate America, they said, and the analytical tools they needed -- like revenue models and spreadsheets -- were not all that different from ones they had used in earlier schooling.
"Basically, the way you think is the same," said Vladik Boutenko, who studied physics in Moscow and now works in the Paris office of Boston Consulting. "It's a question of learning the jargon."
James Deaker, who has a Ph.D. in operations research from Stanford, added, "It's a lot easier to learn the soft skills."
Indeed, at a time when technology is changing the rules for many industries, the skills of scientists and physicians are especially attractive to consulting firms looking to develop new theories. "Oftentimes, the problems they're trying to solve really do require a deeper level of analytical skills" than many M.B.A.'s have, said Laura D'Andrea Tyson, the dean of the University of California's Haas School of Business and the former chairwoman of President Clinton's Council of Economic Advisers.
Business school graduates have other skills, Ms. Tyson said. They can communicate ideas effectively, and their familiarity with dozens and dozens of case studies allows them to make decisions even when important data is unavailable, for example.
They have a vast "tool kit," said Ms. Rupple, of Diamond Technology Partners, that helps them decide the best way to approach a wide range of problems.
 EVEN in the Internet economy, where a good idea is supposed to trump any formal qualification like the M.B.A., those skills are appreciated, business school supporters say. Consider the many Internet start-ups, like eBay, that have hired chief executives with M.B.A.'s once the companies grew large.
Of course, those same companies are now turning around and getting advice from consultants who spent most of their academic careers learning to read Chaucer or to diagnose strep throat.

HEADLINE: The Empty Booth

BYLINE: By JULIAN E. BARNES

 BODY:
ON primary day last month, E. S. Dixon and Janet Ingram sat in the basement of a public housing project in north Brooklyn and stared at an empty voting booth.
For 12 hours Ms. Ingram and Mr. Dixon, poll workers for the 79th Election District, had done virtually nothing. Since 6 a.m. they had logged only nine voters. Ten feet away, at a voting machine for a neighboring district, a line of six people waited to cast ballots. The running total on that machine stood at 109. 
 "I am not sure what the voter turnout should be," Mr. Dixon said of the 79th. "But I figure it should have been a better turnout than this."
For decades, civics teachers and political analysts have lamented the decline in voting. In the 1964 presidential election, 69.3 percent of voting-age Americans went to the polls. By 1996, that figure had dropped to 54.2 percent. Two years later, in off-year Congressional elections, only 41.9 percent cast a ballot.
But those levels look fantastic compared with the record of the 79th District, a nine-block area of engine repair shops and battered three-story brick homes wedged between Bedford-Stuyvesant, Clinton Hill and Williamsburg. Only 21.3 percent of registered voters cast ballots there in 1996. And in 1998, only 24 of the 181 registered voters, a dismal 13.3 percent, did so. That turnout was the lowest among all the 101 election districts in Brooklyn's 54th Assembly District, which itself had the lowest turnout of the 60 assembly districts in the city. As a portion of the roughly 365 adults in the 79th District, the 1998 participation rate was even more wretched: 7 percent.
Residents of the 79th District cite many of the standard reasons for not voting, from busy work schedules to family responsibilities to cynicism about politics. But the district's pitiful turnout also rests on less familiar, more complex forces.
Many residents cannot vote because they are not citizens. New York has always had many immigrants, but a generation ago most would eventually have become citizens. Today, many arrive with no intention of staying. They may live in New York for years, but their hearts remain in their native lands. And while, many years ago, the local political machines would have tried to persuade these immigrants to become voters, election law changes have blunted that force.
But many of those who can vote do not. Laws intended to increase the voting power of racial minority groups have resulted in assembly districts that twist through many neighborhoods and that lack the communal feel that prompts people to vote. The 79th Election District, straddling its three neighborhoods, lies at the end of just one such rambling assembly district.
Roll all these forces together, and the notion of voting is a distant, hazy one in the 79th.
"When do we vote, what month?" asked Eugene Cobb, 51, an unemployed man whose home on Spencer Street is patched with tar paper to cover spots where the gray stucco exterior has peeled off.
Mr. Cobb thinks he last cast a ballot in 1990, but it might have been 1992 or 1998. In any case, he said, he accidentally pulled the wrong lever and ended up voting for the Communist Party. He has not voted since.
Most of the homes in the 79th District stand near Myrtle Avenue, where there is a restaurant, hair salon, church, video rental store, deli and bakery. The district, shaped like a rough triangle, has industrial blocks, too, where men cluster around cars, tinkering with engines or chatting quietly. Textile companies still operate in a few factories, and a faint smell of rotting fish often wafts over the district from the wastes of wholesale food businesses.
The area, which is dotted with vacant, often garbage-strewn lots, is poor, black and Hispanic. The eastern third of the neighborhood, across from a housing project, is mostly black, while the western portion is more Hispanic. At the northern edge of the district, Hasidic families have bought buildings or put up new ones, while students and artists, recent arrivals, live in converted factories scattered throughout the area.
The indifference to voting in the 79th does not rest on a lack of issues. There are tensions. Some longtime residents say that Hasidic landlords are evicting apartment dwellers; others praise the Hasidim for making the streets safer and providing new construction jobs for newly arriving Mexicans. Some black residents, in turn, say the new Hispanic immigrants are driving down wages, while Hispanics counter that they worry about blacks from the projects attacking them.
There are the problems on the street, too. Two weeks before the primary, Anthony Sanchez, a 26-year-old bank teller with an easy smile and quiet voice, sat on a couch with his brother-in-law, Willie Sepulveda, in a Walworth Street apartment building that he shares with his mother, father, sister and her family. Mr. Sanchez propped open the door to let in a little light, and a little air.
Both men, neither of whom voted in the recent primary or in the 1998 general election, expressed frustration about the neighborhood. Mr. Sepulveda, who repairs parking meters for the city, said teenagers from the nearby housing projects sometimes fired guns and scared residents. Both men complained about people parking cars on the curb and playing loud music. Prostitutes congregate at the far end of the street, they say, hidden by industrial buildings, and trucks illegally dump garbage on the sidewalks at night.
But the two disagree about what to do. Mr. Sepulveda, pointing to Mayor Giuliani's quality-of-life campaign, argues that people should vote, because politicians can influence street-level problems.
"If people got more involved, I think things would happen," he said. "But they have ignored the problems, so they are just increasing."
Mr. Sanchez -- who registered to vote in 1992 when he attended the Technical Career Institute and said he tried to keep up with the political news -- sees the day-to-day problems of the 79th as below politicians' radar. His perspective may help explain the rarity of voting in the 79th.
"To solve those problems, people in the neighborhood must change their behavior," Mr. Sanchez said. "The politicians, they don't get into people's business like that. They can't stop people from playing music too loud. They deal with fiscal issues, bigger issues."
George Nordike has no doubts about the power of the ballot. One of the handful of dedicated voters in the district, he and his wife, Hattie, cast 2 of the district's 24 ballots in the 1998 general election. In that year's primary, they cast 2 of the district's depressingly low total of 4 votes. Mr. Nordike, 82, has lived at 113 Sandford Street for 41 years, and has always voted a straight Democratic ticket, deviating only to support Gov. George E. Pataki because of his strong support of the death penalty.
Mr. Nordike does not hold it against his neighbors that they do not vote. Maybe they don't have time, he suggested. Or maybe they cannot make it to the polling place, which is in the projects across Nostrand Avenue. (Some white and Hispanic residents say they are scared to go there.)
But he plans to vote in November, as always. "I just do my part," he said.
One cool evening last month, Allen Ramkhelawan sat behind his desk at Quick Money Rescue Real Estate on Myrtle Avenue and pointed to a second-floor apartment across the street.
"You want to know why people don't vote?" he said. "Look at that flag out there. That tells the story."
From the fire escape, a resident had hung a red, white and green Mexican flag.
"There are a lot of people here who don't care two hoots who gets elected as long as they don't send the Mexicans back to Mexico," Mr. Ramkhelawan said.
He said he had no problem with the Mexicans. Indeed, he said, the influx of residents is good for the neighborhood and has prompted the growth of new businesses. "The street is starting to wake up," he said. "It used to be a run-down slum."
At one business, La Flor Bakery, across the street from Mr. Ramkhelawan's place, his point about the flag is regularly made. Every morning, the older residents who come into the bakery do talk politics, said Nancy Gonzalez, who owns the store with her husband, Gustavo Amigon. But it is not American politics.
"When people talk politics, they basically talk about Cuba and about Mexico, about the new president," said Ms. Gonzalez, who was born in the United States to a Guatemalan mother and a Salvadoran father.
The reason, she said, is that for them this country is just a way station.
"A few of my customers have just disappeared," she said. "I asked their friends where they went and they said home. The money they make here they send back to build their houses. When their houses are done they move back to Mexico."
Even some immigrants with no specific plan to return home cling to their foreign citizenship. Liz Hodgson Johnson, who is Hispanic, emigrated from Nicaragua in 1981 and has lived on Nostrand Avenue ever since.
She has several reasons for not becoming an American citizen. She cannot afford the $250 citizenship application fee, she said, and she cannot take time off from work to stand in line at the Immigration and Naturalization Service. She does not follow politics much, she added, and has a low opinion of politicians. "Sometimes I am so glad I don't have to vote and choose one of them," she said.
But there is something more that stops her. She feels like a Nicaraguan, not an American. Her ultimate loyalty is to her roots, Nicaragua.
"I was born there," she said. "That is who I am."
People like Ms. Johnson frustrate Hector Almestica, pastor of Inglesia de Dios Pentecostal, a storefront church on Myrtle Avenue, who encourages "the stay-ons" to become citizens. But for many parishioners, deciding to pursue citizenship is only the first hurdle.
Juan Oropeza, 55, a Mexican parishioner, used to vote in Mexico and would like to do so here.
"It's much better to be a citizen," he said in Spanish. "My family would have more rights."
But he has twice taken, and twice failed, the English language and citizenship test. With his jet-black hair cresting into tufts of white, he fears he is too old to learn English.
"I've been taking English classes for three years, but I can't get it into my head," he said.
In the 19th century, political machines made it their business to turn immigrants like Mr. Oropeza into citizens. Precinct captains fluent in the newcomers' languages would help them through the paperwork, in return for their loyalty. By the 1890's, nearly 80 percent of eligible voters in cities participated.
But the secret ballot, patronage restrictions and other election law changes dampened the incentive for political clubs to convert immigrants into citizens. The changes, meant to root out corruption and temper workers' voting power, sharply reduced urban voter participation in the early 1900's.
As a result, politicians today do little to find new voters, said Frances Fox Piven, professor of political science at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York and author of "Why Americans Still Don't Vote" (Beacon Press, 2000). The strategy is clear. In New York, with few people voting in primaries, a candidate who turns out a handful of loyal supporters can win.
"We have a long history that shows professional politicians are not trying to raise turnout," Dr. Piven said. "No matter what we are taught in political science courses."
Dressed all in black except for her white-framed sunglasses, Judy K. Thomas stood on the roof of her loft and looked south over the 79th Election District.
"People ask me what neighborhood this is," Ms. Thomas said. "I tell them it's the crossroads of three neighborhoods. Williamsburg to the north. Bed-Stuy to the east. Clinton Hill to the west. It's never been a neighborhood itself."
Ms. Thomas, 40, a sculptor with dyed blond hair and bright red lipstick, did not vote in the 1998 election. She thinks that for many in the district, the failure to vote is linked to the fractured nature of the area.
"You have a few artists, a few blacks, a few Hispanics, and now a few Hasidim," Ms. Thomas said. "But no one is talking to each other. There is no sense of community."
Some politicians say the entire 54th Assembly District, which passes through six neighborhoods, has the same difficulty.
"Bushwick doesn't know Williamsburg," said City Councilman Martin Malave Dilan, who represents Bushwick and has twice run for the 54th Assembly seat. "Cypress Hills doesn't know East New York. It makes it difficult to form coalitions. It makes it difficult for voters to hold representatives accountable."
The State Legislature redraws Senate, Assembly and Congressional districts every 10 years, when the new census data become available. Two principles govern the process. First, the parties try to protect incumbents, by eliminating from a district those pockets where support is weak. Second, under the federal Voting Rights Act, state lawmakers must not dilute minority groups' voting power.
In New York City, the result of these dual pursuits has sometimes been twisting, rambling districts that ignore the geographic, religious, ethnic and other characteristics of a neighborhood. For the 79th District, the oddity is that a minority-group protection law has played a role in making a nonwhite area less cohesive and, therefore, less politically active.
The result can be a vicious cycle. With so few voters, a campaign stop in the 79th might well seem a waste to candidates. But the resulting lack of political presence in the district -- even in late September there were few campaign posters to be seen -- makes residents resentful and even less politically attuned.
Alienation is the result.
"I am too disappointed to vote," said Ms. Gonzalez, the bakery owner, as she cleaned the counter at the close of the day. "I would bother if they paid attention. I don't want to seem that I don't care. But why do I want to put the effort in if no one is listening? It's like talking to a wall."
Ms. Gonzalez thinks city politicians spend their efforts sprucing up Manhattan tourist areas, leaving poor areas to fend for themselves with no city assistance.
Mr. Sanchez, the bank teller, had a similar thought last spring, when he happened upon a rally for Senator John McCain, the presidential candidate, in Lower Manhattan. Seeing such a prominent politician in person excited him, and he began to wonder why he never saw any politicians, even local ones, in his area.
"They should have a day when they come to the neighborhood and you can meet with them and speak your mind," he said.
At 6:15 p.m. on primary day, Israel Vazquez, 77, who along with the Nordikes was one of the four primary voters in 1998, walked up to the 79th District polling place to cast the 10th vote. As he left, Mr. Dixon, the poll worker, balanced his lanky frame in a small chair and resumed his impatient wait.
"I feel like going into the street and dragging my voters in," Mr. Dixon said.
Ms. Ingram, his partner, looked up from the word puzzle she was doing and gave him a smile.
"We have till 9 o'clock," she said. "We are going to have 20 people."
Her prediction was not necessarily a stretch. After all, this year's election had rematches of two close races in the 1998 primary: an ultimately unsuccessful challenge by Barry Ford, a Harvard-educated lawyer, to Congressman Edolphus Towns, and Mr. Dilan's failed bid to unseat Mr. Towns's son, Assemblyman Darryl Towns.
But Ms. Ingram's optimism proved misplaced. When the poll closed at 9, out of the 149 registered voters in the 79th District, only 11 ballots were cast.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Taking A Chance On Takeover Candidates

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
THE triple threat of big-league corporate earnings warnings, signs of an economic slowdown and elevated oil prices has made the stock market an exceedingly frustrating place of late. What's an investor to do?
Play the takeover game. That's the advice of Charles LaLoggia, editor of the Superstock Investor newsletter in Rochester. "We've reached the point where I don't think investors are going to get much help from the economy or from earnings in general," Mr. LaLoggia said. "If you're going to pick stocks, you look for companies in consolidating industries, where there's a certain catalyst that can reasonably lead to a takeover bid." 
 Mr. LaLoggia identifies stocks selling below the value of their assets and not dependent on a rising stock market. That strategy has netted him roughly one takeover a month for the last four years. Forty companies are typically on his recommended list.
This year, eight of Mr. LaLoggia's recommended stocks have received buyout bids, including Advest, Dexter and Pittway.
While pinpointing buyout candidates may seem chancy, the way Mr. LaLoggia does it is fairly conservative. Many companies he recommends are trading well off their highs. Two carry yields of more than 4 percent, versus the 1.1 percent dividend on the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Many have been dumped by the Wall Street herd. Here are some of his picks:
* Houghton Mifflin, the textbook and educational publisher, has dropped in price in recent weeks after downgrades from analysts. But Mr. LaLoggia says the company may benefit from a recent takeover wave in the publishing industry. Scholastic bought Grolier last April, and McGraw-Hill acquired the educational publishing business of the Tribune Company last month. Harcourt General put itself on the block in July. "If there are multiple bidders, a number of them are going to be left at the altar," Mr. LaLoggia said. "Is it a stretch to think they might look at Houghton Mifflin?" The stock closed on Friday at $39.25, down from a high in August of $51.81.
* Alliance Capital Management Holdings is 57 percent owned by the Axa Group of France, which recently sold its holdings in Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Axa Financial. Mr. LaLoggia thinks Alliance Capital will either be the next to be sold or will be bought out by Axa. "It doesn't make sense for it to be hanging out there as a separate company," he said. Alliance shares closed the week at $50.13.
* American States Water may benefit from consolidation in the water utility industry. European water companies have been acquiring American ones, and as Mr. LaLoggia pointed out, only a handful of public companies that sell water remain. "Some of these water utilities are as close as you can get to a free lunch," he said. "They're safe, they have high yields and they are takeover candidates." The stock closed at $30.25, while its takeover value is around $45, Mr. LaLoggia said.
* The Performance Food Group distributes food to restaurants nationwide. The industry has been shrinking as two giants, Royal Ahold and Sysco, have battled for the No. 1 spot by buying up smaller distributors. Performance Food closed on Friday at $37.63, or 23 times its recent earnings per share.
* Midway Games, a maker of video games, is a slightly more speculative play, Mr. LaLoggia said. The stock has fallen 71 percent this year (closing on Friday at $7) as consumers, awaiting the latest technology from game console makers, have held off on buying new games. Sumner N. Redstone, the Viacom chairman, owns 28 percent of Midway and has been buying its shares in the open market. With the stock down, Mr. LaLoggia said, "If Sumner has thought about buying this company out, there's never been a better chance to buy than now."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Ecuador's Electricity Meets Global Power

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
THIS is a story about the search for corporate citizenship, and a cautionary tale of money, influence and the limits of American power.
The tale begins in 1925 in Augusta, Me., where a local company provocatively named American Foreign Power and Electric legally incorporated a subsidiary, the Electric Company of Ecuador (Emelec by its Spanish acronym), to serve the rapidly growing city of Guayaquil. 
 It's a long way from Maine to Ecuador, but such was the reach of Yankee business ingenuity in those pre-globalization days. Foreign Power had already set up similar, quite lucrative companies in Argentina, Bolivia, Chile and Cuba. All were acquired in 1960 by Boise Cascade, the forest products company, which was interested because American Foreign Power had originally burned wood for fuel.
The Ecuadorian operation thrived for years, even after the government started regulating its rates. Then, in the mid-1980's, disputes began flaring. The American owners said they could no longer charge enough to cover costs; the government said Emelec was not meeting the terms of its concession.
In binding arbitration, the company won a ruling that the government had broken the 1925 contract and owed Emelec $52 million. The government refused to pay.
While this dispute simmered, Emelec changed hands several times, eventually coming under the control of a Bahamas-based entity owned by an Ecuadorian tycoon named Fernando Aspiazu who has been in trouble with his government. Yet it remained an American corporation, filing an American tax return each year, though it hasn't reported a profit or paid a dollar in taxes since 1985.
Now the story takes a twist. Mr. Aspiazu also happened to own a bank in Ecuador, the Banco del Progreso, which failed in 1999. To recapitalize the bank, he took steps to sell stock in his power company, which he placed in a trust.
The government of Ecuador seized the bank before the sale, and arrested Mr. Aspiazu. (He has not been charged, but remains in jail.) Mr. Aspiazu then tried to keep the power company's assets out of government hands by creating another trust to sell Emelec's assets and repay thousands of angry bank depositors. An American, Peter Heberling of the Latin America Finance Group, was named the sole trustee, and William Van Dieppen, president of the group, planned to help with the liquidation.
Mr. Aspiazu's motives are less than clear, but he seemed to think he could act like Robin Hood. "More than 500,000 families are affected by the bank's failure," Mr. Van Dieppen said. "Making sure they get repaid can't hurt Aspiazu's chances of having his name rehabilitated."
Any American investor lured by Latin America's promise fears corruption and complication, which go hand in hand. Ecuador is one of South America's least stable countries, and early this year things really started to come apart. The economy was in such a shambles that the president, Jamil Mahuad, tried to scrap its currency in favor of dollars, but people took to the streets, the army took the Presidential Palace and Mr. Mahuad took off for quieter quarters.
As the dust was settling, Mr. Van Dieppen was talking to four potential American buyers for Emelec, including Enron. But the new president of Ecuador, Gustavo Noboa, needed to send a message that things had changed in the country for people like Mr. Aspiazu. He sent troops and the police to seize Emelec headquarters in Guayaquil.
The company appealed to the American embassy in Quito, only to be told that Emelec, the direct descendant of American Foreign Power, was not considered an American corporation. "The State Department did not do its homework," Mr. Van Dieppen said, adding that he thought that the ambassador, Gwen Clare, had sided with the Ecuadorian government. Mr. Van Dieppen said his calls to the ambassador and the State Department were not returned. "We felt totally abandoned," he said.
Mr. Van Dieppen then turned to the one tried-and-true fallback for any company anywhere in the world: he hired lawyers to push Emelec's interests in Washington. He went to Capitol Hill and lined up the support of Senator Jesse Helms. For a time he also paid Kissinger McLarty Associates, the high-octane Washington consulting firm led by Henry Kissinger and Thomas F. McLarty III, President Clinton's former chief of staff, to intervene.
The investment in influence apparently paid off. On Aug. 28, Ms. Clare said in a letter that the dispute had been raised by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright during a visit to Ecuador. "The government of Ecuador should quickly and fairly sort out the competing claims on Emelec's assets," Ms. Clare wrote, adding that she looked forward to working with the trust.
A State Department official familiar with the case said the embassy's initial reaction was based on a mistrust of Mr. Aspiazu's role. But after Senator Helms's office and Emelec's lawyers and representatives in Washington expressed interest, department officials decided to take another look. "Some things could have been resolved faster," the official conceded. "But these guys had a lot of things on their platter."
He was alluding to the new administration led by Mr. Noboa, who also seems to have changed his position. When he was victoriously touring Emelec's seized offices, he brushed off reporters' questions about constitutional violations, declaring, "I have to do what I need to do -- impose order on this country." But in a recent speech to New York investors, he seemed almost contrite, saying that the confidence of American investors, which Ecuador desperately needs, is being restored because the nation is "beginning to change."
In the end, what happened to American Foreign Power exposes some of the rules of global influence game as it is now played.
"Never assume that the United States government is necessarily going to be on your side in your hour of need," Mr. Van Dieppen said. Without top-notch representation in Washington, he said, "no one is going to take you seriously" there.
Or in Guayaquil, either, it seems.
