SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1047 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Fewer Strings Attached;
The World's Bankers Try Giving Money, Not Lessons

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
A snapshot from Prague: One cool, hazy night, a day after black-masked anarchists attacked police lines and rattled delegates to the meeting of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, Horst Kohler and James D. Wolfensohn, respectively the new managing director of the I.M.F. and the World Bank president, stood at an outdoor ceremony with fixed smiles on their faces.
Jubilee 2000, a leading pressure group for third-world debt relief, presented them with a petition, and gave them a dressing down. ' 
 'Your declarations have proven to be empty promises once again," one speaker scolded. The two officials vowed to do better and left shaking hands.
Just a decade ago leading economists in the United States and Europe settled on a new strategy for fighting poverty. In return for long-term loans, poor nations got mandatory lessons in capitalism, what might be called the teach-a-man-to-trade theory of aid.
It seemed like a great solution at the time. After the fall of Communism, poor nations hungered for unbridled capitalism. And the industrial countries had more energy for lecturing than they did money for traditional aid, which plummeted in the 1990's.
But as Prague sweeps up the shattered shop window glass left over from the violence-plagued meeting of global aid agencies last week, one thing has become clear: The old way of thinking is now economically debatable and politically untouchable.
In its place is emerging a new consensus about helping the poor that shifts some of the burden to the rich. It has the potential to raise living standards, but will cost a great deal more money.
The new consensus has three main elements. First, loans are fine, but grants are better, especially for humanitarian projects like fighting AIDS and malaria. The World Bank and other development agencies keep even their low-interest loans on their books as assets. Grants, however, are write-offs, and will require more cash infusions from donor countries if the aid agencies want to preserve their capital.
Second, debt relief must come faster and be more generous. There are 41 nations eligible for debt relief, whose average debt load is 125 percent of their gross domestic product. Rich nations have begun a slow process of relieving this crushing burden, but the drumbeat to forgive much more of the third world's debt is deafening for government ministers, who seem to up their pledges with every anti-globalization riot.
Third, trade is a two-way street. There is broad agreement that poor nations have done more than their fair share to free up trade, and the pressure is on rich nations to open their markets wider to the things poor countries make.
For Europe and Japan, that means lowering the wall protecting their farmers. For the United States, it means a showdown with the influential textile and sugar lobbies.
The betting is that these kinds of changes will throw a lifeline to the world's poorest people, defined as those earning $2 or less a day. They number a staggering 3 billion, roughly half the world's population.
The World Bank acknowledges that the poor in Africa, Latin America and the former Soviet Union did not benefit much from the roaring prosperity of the 1990's. They may eventually benefit from the almost universal shift toward market economics, but that has not happened yet.
The new thinking aims for more immediate results. Easing debt loads, handing out grants directly to villages, clinics and schools, and providing more export opportunities for the crops grown and the shirts stitched by the poorest workers could help. But there will be a price to pay.
"We have to tackle the selfishness of wealthy countries," says Mr. Kohler. "This is a question of morals."
And of expediency. The I.M.F. and the World Bank, its fellow Washington-based global lender, have been front-line targets of the anti-globalization movement that has spread from Seattle to Washington and Prague.
But Mr. Kohler and Mr. Wolfensohn are edging closer to their critics, even pandering a little. Though they still espouse free market capitalism, they argue for a humane approach to poverty relief that puts developing nations in charge and cuts some strings attached to aid.
When the aid experts talked about economic overhauls in Prague, they were as often calling for changes in wealthy nations as for the 90's-formula medicine prescribed to the poor.
Their message is: We want to fight poverty more effectively, but it will only work if industrial countries dip into their pockets and challenge their entrenched domestic interests on trade and, by extension, on employment.
"The globalization battle is really about the parsimony of the G-7," said Trevor A. Manuel, South Africa's finance minister, who chaired the Prague sessions. He was referring to the United States, Japan, Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Canada, members of the Group of 7 developed countries.
Financial leaders from rich nations are beginning to feel the heat, and they are touting their own anti-poverty strategies.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who said in Prague that the poverty battle has become "the overarching economic and humanitarian challenge of our time," proposed last week that the World Bank replace some loans with outright grants, a first. The proposal echoed a key demand made by a Congressional commission that recently criticized the bank as a feckless anachronism.
Trouble is, Congress is still practicing tough love. American foreign aid declined an average of 8 percent annually in the 1990's. The average American had $42 of his taxes devoted to foreign aid in 1993, and $32 in 1998, according to World Bank figures. The United States is the stingiest rich nation, but aid declined in many European countries as they tightened their budgets for monetary union.
With the backlash against globalization mounting, the next president will probably have to figure out a way to persuade lawmakers to provide more aid and debt relief, even while making politically tricky compromises on trade. It will be a hard sell, but Mr. Kohler of the I.M.F. says he has the solution.
"It will be very helpful," he says with a smile, "when these groups that have been attacking us turn their attention to the Congress."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1011 words

HEADLINE: The Nation: Debatable;
What to Do With All That Money

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE presidential debates of 1960 are best remembered today for the contrast between a tanned, youthful-looking John F. Kennedy and a pasty, sweaty-looking Richard M. Nixon.
What has been forgotten is that the 1960 debates were also the last occasions on which two presidential candidates argued at length about what to do with a government surplus, and whether it made sense to pay down America's debts. 
 It has been 40 years since a surplus intersected with a presidential election (though there was one balanced budget, in 1969) and far, far longer since there was any hope of paying off a debt that has now swelled to $3.63 trillion.
Yet what to do with that opportunity will likely dominate Tuesday night's arguments, when Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore face off. Mr. Bush has not backed off a tax cut plan that has made some in his party so queasy that they have come up with their own, more modest proposals. And Mr. Gore has learned that even if paying down the national debt is, as one of his advisers puts it, "an eat-your-broccoli message," it seems to be registering in the polls.
In their more candid moments, Mr. Gore's strategists concede that the Clinton administration stumbled into debt reduction. Mr. Clinton used a State of the Union address to declare that America's mission was to "save Social Security first," which was little more than a tactic for fending off Republican tax cuts. It worked.
"To this day," said Robert L. Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan fiscal watchdog group, "most people still don't understand that using the surplus to shore up Social Security just means debt reduction."
He's right. Since the government doesn't have a savings account, any money that doesn't get spent is automatically used to buy back outstanding debt. (This may be the first time an accounting rule created a huge political following.) And it is not getting spent precisely because of that much-maligned Washington trait: gridlock.
"There is nothing more American than to say your budget should be balanced and you should be paying off your debts," said Robert Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute and a former director of the Congressional Budget Office. "But of course, what debt reduction really does is keep the money out of the hands of the other party, to spend on its priorities. It's everyone's second choice."
True, but a very popular second choice. So popular that both Democrats and Republicans in the House overwhelmingly approved legislation two weeks ago that would commit this year's surpluses to pay down debt. And President Clinton, beating the drum for his own legacy and Mr. Gore's candidacy, stepped out of the White House on Wednesday morning armed with a big magic marker to declare that the government's fiscal year was ending with a $230 billion surplus -- and that all but $7 billion of it would be used to pay down debt.
That puts the United States on track to paying off the debt by 2012, Mr. Clinton said. By remarkable coincidence, Mr. Gore's plan sets the same date.
Mr. Bush's plan would also pay off the debt, only in 2016. But he doesn't talk about it much, preferring instead to dwell on tax cuts that seem drawn from the playbook of Ronald Reagan.
Meanwhile, as Mr. Gore continues to portray himself as the man who will lift the debt off the shoulders of the nation's children, Mr. Bush has to make the case that under his plan Americans can have their big tax cuts and eat their debt, too.
"Bush is caught caught between a rock and a hard place," said Mr. Reischauer, "because he wants to establish individual accounts for Social Security, and those will be funded out of the Social Security surplus. So there will be less debt paydown."
Mr. Bush's advisers, not surprisingly, look at the numbers differently, arguing that Mr. Gore's surplus is a phantom that will disappear after Election Day. Mr. Gore, meanwhile, is betting on the analogy he believes Americans will make between debt reduction and the way they would like to manage their own household budgets. "No one can relate to a $2 trillion budget," Mr. Bixby said. "But they can understand that when you have a big expense coming up -- kids going to college, or retirement -- it makes sense to get rid of your debts."
Here it is the voters, not the politicians, who may be engaging in election-year hypocrisy. One of the strongest arguments for paying down the government's debt is that Americans are running up their private debts. And the two are related: If the government and its citizens are both borrowing, they are competing for the same cash. That sends interest rates higher.
There are other virtues in paying down the debt. If the economy turns down sometime in the next few years, Washington will have more room to stimulate the economy, either with tax cuts or spending. Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers calls that "loading the cannon," and warns of the dangers of shooting it off too early.
But other economists make the case that too much debt reduction can be, well, too much of a good thing.
Virtuous as paying down the debt may be, it is not necessarily the best use of the government's money. Mr. Bush's tax cuts could, arguably, put more money in the stock market, where it would be available to old and new companies for research and new technologies. (If those cuts come too soon, though, they could also overstimulate an economy and a stock market that many fear is still flying too high, forcing the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates even more.) Or maybe the return on investment would be better if the money was spent on education. After all, a well-trained software engineer -- or 10 million of them -- can foster a lot of growth.
So in the end, perhaps the most interesting question for Tuesday's debate won't even be asked. It is, to be fair, a technical query: What is the optimal debt for the United States? Elections don't often turn on arcane arguments over such issues. The country's economic future, however, may.

SECTION: Section 14WC; Page 2; Column 3; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2078 words

HEADLINE: What's Entertainment? That Depends ...

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA KUEHL

 BODY:
REMEMBER what fun it was rushing Snowball to the vet after he gulped down a badminton birdie? Hey, you protest, that was not fun. Nevertheless, that's entertainment, according to the United States government.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics, which annually surveys Americans about their spending habits, includes veterinary expenses in its "entertainment" category. Not classified as entertainment: reading, dining out and using a home computer, omissions that might give the bibliophile, the gourmand and the chat-room addict pause. The bureau also leaves out gambling, which some experts say is the most popular outside-the-home recreation in America. 
 The bureau's sometimes curious choices prompt the question: What is entertainment, anyway? And what factors -- genetic, geographic, chronologic, socioeconomic -- determine that some people, like Beth Henderson of Ashford, Conn., meet their entertainment needs through contemplative pursuits like reading and gardening, while others, like Rina Isaac of White Plains, embrace pulse-pounding activities like mountain biking and archery? What impels Dr. Alfred Scherzer of Hampton Bays, N.Y., to travel to Somalia to gaze at maribou storks, or Donald Wayne of Piscataway, N.J., to amass 100,000 postcards, including one made out of kangaroo skin?
Social scientists say the human hunger for entertainment may be as old as society itself. "I don't know that we have any sort of archaeological evidence of entertainment, per se," said Daniel Fessler, an assistant professor of anthropology at the University of California at Los Angeles, whose research fields include evolutionary psychology and psychological anthropology. "But what we do have is the observation that all known human societies have entertainment of some fashion, and that suggests that it's very old indeed."
A society without entertainment "would be a pretty frightening thing," said Frank A. Salamone, a professor of sociology at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y., and the author of "Society, Culture, Leisure and Play: An Anthropological Reference" (University Press of America, 2000).
Entertainment "lets us dream," he said.
"It's imagination," he added. "Play at its best gives us a million options."
As a noun, "play" commonly refers to the games of children. Adults, too old to zip into playsuits, instead put on "leisure wear" to "recreate." But whether it's called leisure, recreation or entertainment, when an activity is "nonproductive, in other words, the aim is not a product, the aim is the experience," that's play, and adults need to do it, said John R. Kelly, a sociologist and the author of 11 books about leisure.
"We are working creatures, we are bonding creatures," he said, "and we are playing creatures."
In the New York metropolitan statistical area -- which includes New York City, Westchester, Long Island, most of northern and central New Jersey, and southwestern Connecticut -- households spent an average of $1,835 annually on entertainment in 1997-98, according to the Consumer Expenditure Survey conducted by the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
That number, though, is misleadingly low. Besides pet care, the bureau's list of entertainments includes movies and sporting events; hobbies, toys and games; television sets, videos and stereos; and sporting and exercise equipment. But add items like dining out, alcoholic beverages and reading, and the amount jumps to almost $5,200 a year, or more than 10 percent of the average household's pretax income. Add still more -- lottery tickets, Internet access, the incalculable costs of recreational shopping, and major investments, like the room Mr. Wayne added onto his New Jersey home to accommodate his collections -- and entertainment costs can soar.
In some years, Dr. Scherzer, 71, spends more than $5,000 to watch birds in exotic locales. In 35 years as a birder, Dr. Scherzer said, he has logged between 1,500 and 2,000 species. A practicing pediatrician and emeritus professor of pediatrics at Cornell Medical College, he is a co-president of the Moriches Bay Audubon Society, which has more than 750 members and covers a territory extending from Patchogue to the tip of the South Fork.
According to Dr. Kelly, who is a co-author with Rodney B. Warnick of "Recreation Trends and Markets: The 21st Century" (Sagamore, 1999), bird-watching is increasingly popular, especially among older adults, a population that grows with each aging baby boomer. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, membership in National Audubon Society chapters has climbed almost 17 percent in the last decade, to nearly 72,000, an Audubon Society spokesman said.
Economics, education, sex, religion, family background and age all influence entertainment choices. Up to 20 percent of Americans have no discretionary income for entertainment, while 10 percent can afford to spend "significant amounts" on fun, according to "Recreation Trends and Markets." Further, some Americans have little discretionary time, Dr. Kelly said, citing people who hold two jobs to support a family, mothers who shoulder a full-time job and take care of their families, too, and workers who may lose hours of recreation time to commuting.
Choices also spring from living in a particular time and place. "What was incredibly amusing in 1890 is now seen to be no longer funny, for the most part," said Dr. Salamone, the Iona professor. "See two minutes of a German film, and you know it's German. Broadly speaking, English jokes aren't funny in the United States, no matter what background people have. Why do the French like Jerry Lewis? I never understood that."
People also choose activities that balance their lives. "If you work in a steel mill all day, you don't rush out to play tennis when you leave the job," Dr. Kelly said. And for reasons that are still little understood, he said, some people are risk takers who like to play on the edge, others are intensely self-protective and need a comfort zone, and the majority fall between the two extremes.
Ms. Isaac, 38, who teaches first graders in Manhattan, said skiing, hiking, biking and archery help keep her balanced. "When I leave the city, I need to revive my soul," she said. "I make sure I am with nature."
The bow and arrow, which she took up three years ago, require a concentration and focus that send her deep into herself. "You only hear your pulse, your heartbeat -- you can feel your sweat," she said. "It's a competition between my physical self and my mind."
Ms. Isaac said one benefit from her archery is a new identity. "People call me Rina the Archer, Pocahontas," she said. "They say, 'The wild woman is here.' People see you on another level: 'Hey, that person shoots, and that's awesome.' "
If archers inspire awe, couch potatoes draw sneers. But watching television remains Americans' prime pastime at night, a Gallup Poll reported in March 1999. Results of another Gallup Poll in January show that 57 percent of Americans watch three or more hours of television a day.
Television delivers story after story, feeding the human need for narrative, which, along with dance, is a universal form of entertainment, said Dr. Fessler of U.C.L.A. Some theorists say that entertainment, like cooking, may be a tradition passed down from ancestral societies. But Dr. Fessler said it may instead be an evolved psychology, a desire that became embedded in the human mind through evolution.
Unfortunately, Dr. Fessler said, evolved psychologies can become insatiable. "If you could afford it, and I guess some people can," he said, "you can just plug yourself into entertainment all of your waking hours and never leave the house."
Meanwhile, more narratives await at the local multiplex. Between 1989 and 1999, the number of movie screens in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut rose 60 percent, to 3,470, according to the National Association of Theater Owners. Box offices nationwide took in $7.49 billion in 1999, and Americans spent an additional $17.36 billion renting and buying movies, according to the Video Software Dealers Association.
Luckily for literacy, the stories on library shelves still beckon. According to "Recreation Trends and Markets," more than 90 million adult Americans read books, and the number is rising. In early September, Ms. Henderson, 57, said she was reading six: a memoir, a biography, a travelogue, two local histories and a Harry Potter. A former teacher and school administrator who is now a sculptor, Ms. Henderson said that she spent $75 to $100 a month on newspapers, magazines and books, and combed the library stacks in Ashford and Mansfield, Conn., for free riches. "One of the things I like about reading is that it really promotes the use of your imagination, a lot more than watching a movie, for example," she said.
In contrast, gambling, which Professors Kelly and Warnick describe as "the largest single 'recreation' activity outside the home," doesn't so much promote imagination as feed off it, as gamblers imagine themselves rich.
Their imaginations were working overtime in 1999 as Americans wagered more than $742 billion, according to an industry analyst, Christiansen Capital Advisors. That's 99 times last year's national movie box-office receipts, and almost triple the amount people wagered in 1989.
In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, dreamers spent $6.2 billion on lottery tickets in 1998-99, 73 percent more than a decade ago, according to figures provided by state lottery officials. And gamblers wagered $43.5 billion in Atlantic City casinos in 1999, about twice what they spent in 1989, according to New Jersey Casino Control Commission figures.
Gambling creates "a kind of an artificial excitement," Dr. Kelly said.
Gambling choices and styles vary. Some play bingo for fun, others buy lottery tickets out of financial desperation. "That isn't play," said Dr. Kelly. "That's waiting to be struck by lightning."
Gamblers and collectors are both treasure seekers, but collectors rarely go home empty-handed.
There are four clubs in New Jersey for postcard collectors, known as deltiologists, and Mr. Wayne belongs to three of them, including the Central Jersey Deltiological Society, of which he is president. A serious collector since the mid-1960's, Mr. Wayne, 65, said he went "a little berserk" over novelty cards. Besides the kangaroo-skin oddity, he owns cards made of Irish peat, celluloid, aluminum, leather, macerated money and woven silk.
But his acquisitive days are winding down, Mr. Wayne said, because even with the extra room, "the house is full." Still, a collector can dream. At a recent postcard show in Clark, N.J., Mr. Wayne pointed out a man who claimed to own a million cards. "People revere him as one of the icons of the postcard world," Mr. Wayne said. "At least, I do."
Somewhere in the United States is someone who collects just about every kind of object, Dr. Kelly said. Add up all the collections -- stamps, coins, rocks, bones, thimbles, Hummel figurines, comic books, ice cream scoops, barbed wire and everything else -- and "you probably have a fairly significant part of the adult population," he said.
Collectors form groups, attend meetings and publish journals. "The social aspects become very important," Dr. Kelly said.
Mr. Wayne, a retired math teacher who also collects slide rules and books about space, said he couldn't expect people to appreciate the thrill of postcards unless they saw his treasures. Even then they might not understand. Such passions develop over time, and the impulses behind them are often complex.
Although it is easy simply to mock somebody else's idea of fun, the Bureau of Labor Statistics contends that it has valid reasons for each omission from the Consumer Expenditure Survey's entertainment category.
For example, the bureau deems reading more informational than entertaining, said Bill Passero, a senior economist. Dining out is a subcategory under food, and gambling is a miscellaneous expenditure, Mr. Passero said, noting that many people regard it not as entertainment but as an investment with a possible return.
As for pet care, it's been part of entertainment (formerly "recreation") since at least 1950, according to bureau records. Where else would you put it? Mr. Passero wondered.
Mr. Wayne, for one, said the notion of pets as entertainment made sense. He and his wife have two Shetland sheepdogs. "They're a riot," he said.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY;
FUEL-PROOF PROSPERITY

BYLINE: By Anne Ruderman

 BODY:
Two Rutgers economists, speaking at their annual seminar for state officials and lobbyists in Trenton last week, said that soaring energy prices will not end the state's economic boom. Joseph Seneca, vice president of academic affairs at Rutgers and chairman of the Governor's Council of Economic Advisors, and James Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy, acknowledged that high energy prices historically touch off a recession. But "the New Jersey economy and national economy are much less dependent on energy than they were a decade ago and two decades ago," Mr. Seneca said.
 Anne Ruderman

HEADLINE: Regulations on Park Rides Serve the Public

 BODY:

To the Editor:
With the dizzying heights and great speeds of modern amusement rides, patrons place a great deal of trust in the mechanics and operation of these devices. It is our job at the state Division of Codes and Standards to see that that trust is well placed. It was no accident that New Jersey just completed one of its safest amusement-ride seasons ever. We have strict standards and regular inspections. People who are strapped into these rides expect nothing less. 
 In a recent article ("A Bumpy Ride This Summer," Sept. 10), some amusement-ride operators complained that New Jersey's regulations go too far. We believe they should go even further. The state has nearly doubled the number of inspectors on staff, initiated surprise inspections to observe rides and operators in action, conducted engineering reviews of new rides and significantly increased penalties for violations of regulations.
But the deaths of a mother and daughter on a relatively tame amusement ride in 1999 indicated the need for additional steps. We are working with state lawmakers to develop legislation that would require greater accountability on the part of ride manufacturers and enable us to ensure that ride designs, especially new ones, are safe.
We recognize that amusement rides are a business, and that park owners and operators make a living from the thrills they provide to patrons. We also appreciate the impact of the amusement-ride industry on New Jersey's economy. That is why we are committed to processing ride applications within 30 days.
We do require that maintenance-operating manuals be supplied for each ride. Without them, it is impossible for the ride operators to keep the rides safe and impossible for our inspectors to thoroughly check them out. We don't view that as excessive "paperwork" or over-regulation. And we doubt that those who climb aboard these rides for fun and excitement do either.
 
JANE M. KENNY
Trenton
 
The writer is commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Community Affairs.

HEADLINE: A Suggestion Box For United Airlines

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Righting United Airlines: Nine Flight Plans" (Sept. 10), in which airline experts, professors and consumer advocates offered their ideas for solving the carrier's labor and service problems: 
 I disagree with Gerald Meyers, a University of Michigan professor, who, in criticizing United's employee stock ownership plan, said that "very few" ESOP's are successful.
I happen to be an employee-owner in an ESOP company, Scot Forge, a Spring Grove, Ill.-based manufacturer of open die and rolled ring forgings -- a true "heavy metal" industry. Just under 500 of us own two manufacturing plants in Illinois and one in Wisconsin. We are a 100 percent employee-owned company, through an ESOP established in 1978.
We are a very profitable private company, and over the years we have watched the value of our stock increase steadily. Our ESOP has created a few new millionaires, and many of us have retired with very healthy, six-figure stock accounts. These are not just company officers or directors -- we are talking about factory and office workers, too. As owners, we also share in the profits through bonuses and dividends, and our pay scale is competitive with that of companies in our area that are not employee-owned.
Scot Forge is far from an isolated success story. Many ESOP companies are much like ours, small to midsized businesses. They represent every aspect of our economy, including manufacturing, retail and service industries.
 
KAREN YORK
Spring Grove, Ill., Sept. 12
 
The writer is a staff accountant at the Scot Forge Company.

HEADLINE: In an Ex-Soviet Land, High Hopes Are Ebbing

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

DATELINE: RUSTAVI, Georgia

 BODY:
The factories built as part of the great Soviet industrialization undertaken for Stalin, Georgia's native son, stand empty. The ugly concrete apartment houses for the workers are crumbling. The shops display few wares, and every traffic light is off to save electricity.
Only the soup kitchen seems to be thriving as a line snakes out the door. 
 Etery Guedashvili, 61, emerges from the squat building, carrying her ration of soup in a jar and bread wrapped in paper, a meager meal that embodies the dashed hopes for democracy and prosperity all across the former Soviet republics of the Caucasus and Central Asia.
At first she is embarrassed by this handout. But humiliation fast turns to anger, and she spits out her indictment of the government.
"I worked in a military production plant for 30 years and I earned a good pension," she said. "Now I get only 12 lari a month, and they don't even pay that. I would go back to work, but there are no jobs."
Twelve lari is $6, the average pension. Often the government does not have enough money to pay even that pittance, or the salaries of teachers, police officers and judges.
Rustavi was once a model of the Soviet economy, a new city built in 1948 for 160,000 residents whose lives centered on the bustling factories. Today, Rustavi is a model for the stubborn poverty gripping a vast region rich in oil, gas and strategic importance but short of the hope that even five years ago buoyed forecasts of a better tomorrow.
Details and degree differ from country to country, but everywhere there is the same volatile mix of ethnic and religious strife and despair over government failure to create even the prospect of wealth.
The people here, particularly the middle-aged and elderly, grew up secure in the belief that the state, however hated, would meet their needs, and they can scarcely cope now that it patently does not.
"The standard of living for large sections of the population has been falling now for 15 years," concluded a new report by the International Crisis Group, a private organization in Brussels. "And there are political forces already mobilized to exploit any outburst of popular discontent."
The report dealt with Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Uzebekistan, but the assessment is depressingly similar elsewhere.
Georgia, whose modern political star is not Stalin but Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the former Soviet foreign minister who helped tear down the Berlin Wall, was supposed to be different. It is a country of rugged beauty and rich culture, with a population of about five million in a mountainous area slightly smaller than South Carolina. The first independent state was founded in the fourth century B.C., and Christianity became the state religion in fourth century A.D.
Five years ago, Georgia seemed poised to become something of a model for the triumph of Western values and the free market.
The bloody civil war and the chaos that followed independence in 1991 were over. Mr. Shevardnadze, newly elected as president, was highly regarded in the West. He carried out democratic reforms and, with help from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, created the fastest growing economy among the region's former Soviet republics.
Then things went awry. The Russian financial crisis in 1998 robbed Georgia of its export market for machinery, agriculture and wine. Next, fighting resumed in the breakaway ethnic enclave of Abkhazia in northwestern Georgia. Both there and in a second separatist region, South Ossetia, peace remains elusive.
The economic woes deepened this summer when drought destroyed 80 percent of the wheat crop and drained reservoirs.
But the biggest problem is corruption, which is so rampant that the government cannot collect enough taxes and customs duties to pay salaries and pensions regularly, let alone reduce the $200 million in foreign debt or curb its budget deficit.
Teachers in the eastern region of Tianeti refused to open the schools in September, because they had not been paid for 10 months. Residents in Tkibuli, in the west, blocked streets to protest the lack of electricity.
In an interview at his office in the capital, Tbilisi, Mr. Shevardnadze, now 72, acknowledged the difficulties but said he remains optimistic. He described plans for improving health care and irrigation and new efforts to improve tax collection.
There is some potential help from a much-debated proposed pipeline from Baku, Azerbaijan, to the Turkish port of Ceyhan, but that is a bit further down the road, and more speculative. The pipeline would pass through Georgia, generating jobs and eventually about $50 million a year in transshipment fees.
"We have gone only halfway there in terms of economic development," Mr. Shevardnadze said. "It is a slow process."
One reason for the agonizing slowness of change is the prevalence of the Soviet-era mentality, especially in societies that were predominanty feudal and rural when the 1917 revolution suddenly foisted Communist visions of equality and forced industrialization on them. "Stalin and Lenin taught us to stay in one place and wait," said Alexander Rondeli, director of a research center linked with the Foreign Ministry. "This condition did not change overnight. There is no Soviet Union, but we live in the Soviet Union. We have the same values and the same mentality."
The leadership mentality is similar, too, in most of the former republics. Authoritarian leaders have centralized power and neutered the opposition just as Kremlin bosses once did. Mr. Shevardnadze is a leader of equal longevity, dominating Georgia for much of the last 35 years.
True to his foreign reputation as one of the men who helped Communism collapse relatively painlessly, Mr. Shevardnadze has steered a more democratic course than other former Soviet leaders. Power is shared among the strong presidency, the judiciary and the legislature, though Mr. Shevardnadze's party controls Parliament and the opposition is weak.
But corruption, from a booming black market in oil and cigarettes to bribery of officials, remains almost intractable because of the tightknit, clannish nature of Georgia and because some of those involved are longtime associates of the president and he remains loyal to them.
"Corruption is the key to the economic future of the country," said Gela Charkviani, a senior adviser to Mr. Shevardnadze. "If we can deal with the underlying corruption, we can collect enough taxes and other revenue to pay the salaries of the teachers and all the pensions."
A seven-member commission has just completed work on a blueprint for scrubbing the government, but details have not been disclosed.
What is apparent is that the effort will have to be tough and thorough to save people like most residents of Rustavi, a city built 25 miles southeast of Tbilisi along the Kura River on the site of an ancient village said to have been destroyed by Tamerlane at the end of the 14th century.
Steelworks and ironworks were started to supply the Soviet military and agriculture, and chemical factories produced pesticides. All of them polluted the river, a toxic residue that adds to the city's troubles.
But the modern destruction of Rustavi occurred when the Soviet Union collapsed. The market for its goods evaporated. In the chaos that followed, armed gangs and free-lance looters pillaged the factories and sold the machinery for scrap.
The local authorities estimate unemployment at higher than 50 percent, but that seems low to Malkhaz Irenadze, who runs one of the city's two soup kitchens for the Salvation Army. Each kitchen gives away 1,000 meals a day, he said, adding that he could easily serve 10 times as many.
For many of those who go there, the only meal of the day is thin soup, vegetables, bread and an occasional sausage.
"This is a frozen city," one older woman said bitterly. "The government has forgotten us."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: ADVERTISING;
Costly Prescriptions: One Issue That Fits All

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
Brian Schweitzer, a peppermint, alfalfa and cattle farmer running for the Senate in Montana, holds up a pair of pill bottles for the camera and declares, "I bet you'd be surprised to find out that veterinarians prescribe the exact same medicine for dogs, and charge half as much."
In a New Hampshire television commercial, Gov. Jeanne Shaheen, seeking re-election, has found a novel way to attack her Republican opponent, former Senator Gordon Humphrey: she says his vote against creating a prescription drug benefit under Medicare makes him "an extremist." 
 And an advertisement for the Democratic hopeful for the Senate in Minnesota, Mark Dayton, shows the candidate riding a bus with elderly people to buy their pills for lower prices in Canada. "He's helping us," one of the retirees, Buzz Otte, exclaims. "He likes us old-timers!"
In the 2000 campaign, no question is getting more play from more candidates than what to do about the rising cost of medication. It is, in fact, the issue that spin doctors prescribe most. Jim Jordan, political director for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, says that he knows how many of the Democrats waging television advertising campaigns are invoking the issue: all of them.
"There is just so much wind in the sails of this issue," he said. "I have no doubt that by election day every single Democrat who is on the air will have run ads about prescription drugs."
The topic has become such a ubiquitous feature of this year's advertising that it is virtually a requirement for candidates to have a prescription drug commercial. And some contenders have already produced as many as six advertisements on the subject. "It's stunning," said Neil Newhouse, a Republican pollster who has advised several of his clients across the country to weave the subject into their messages.
"In terms of campaign advertising, it's hard to think back and find an issue that bridges federal and state candidates, Republicans and Democrats, the way that prescription drugs has," Mr. Newhouse said.
That such a narrowly defined issue could dominate commercials from coast to coast illustrates how swiftly and widely potentially winning messages can be franchised, almost like coffee houses or fast-food outlets.
"I guess voters want to hear you have a plan," said Mac McCorkle, an issues consultant to Democrats in races for governor in North Carolina and Missouri. "They don't trust all the protestations about what a great character I am, but they do relate to whether you get the message on prescription drugs."
Candidates of every stripe are seeking to sound like friends of the little guy in his fight against escalating drug costs.
"Slade Gorton stared down the drug companies to lower the unfair prices of prescription medicines," an announcer says in an advertisement for the Republican senator's re-election campaign in Washington State.
Three thousand miles away, another Republican, Senator Olympia J. Snowe of Maine, offers a similar theme. "No senior citizen," she says in her commercial, "should ever have to choose between putting food on the table and getting the medicine that they need."
And it is not just the candidates who are weighing in. The A.F.L.-C.I.O., various state parties and the Democratic and Republican national committees have all run prescription drug advertisements. That is not to mention the Citizens for Better Medicare, a group allied with the pharmaceutical industry that has spent more than $34 million this year on a nationwide advertising campaign against those who support a Clinton administration proposal to make the drug benefit a part of Medicare. Dan Zielinski, a spokesman for Citizens for Better Medicare, said that he believed the group's adversaries had spent just as much.
Both parties, of course, say they support lowering the drug costs for older people, but it was the Democrats who were first to recognize the telegenic appeal of mixing pills and politics. Democratic Party officials say it was no coincidence that they made Vice President Al Gore's support for the drug benefit the subject of his campaign's first commercial.
Regardless of party affiliation, the rewards can be handsome for candidates who have taken early stands on the issue.
Dr. Paul Perry, a surgeon from Evansville, Ind., and first-time candidate for Congress, says he went from relative unknown to victor in the Democratic primary in Indiana's Eighth Congressional District on the strength of health care concerns in general and the economics of pharmaceuticals in particular.
"We had nine weeks of TV advertising, talking about H.M.O. reform and the cost of prescription drugs," said Dr. Perry, who defeated John Hamilton, nephew of the popular former House member Lee Hamilton, in the primary. "The power of that message took us to a 20-point win. Patients understand that the power of the insurance companies has become so great. And prescription drugs play into the whole idea of who's in control of health care."
Those in the business of promulgating campaign messages and measuring their effect say the issue is keenly calibrated to these political times. Voters, their surveys show, are not impressed with thematic advertising that highlights values or vision. In this peacetime era of relative economic security, they say they want to hear about plans to solve problems in their own lives. And they want details.
"You've got to go specific," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist Institute for Public Opinion in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.
The message is not only tailored to the elderly. Joe Andrew, national chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said that in advising the party to focus heavily on prescription drugs, he saw the issue's appeal as "cross-generational": a health care issue for the oldest voters, a financial issue for baby boomers worried about how to support an aging parent and a matter of social responsibility for young people.
In some races, like the Senate contest in Michigan between the Republican incumbent, Spencer Abraham, and his challenger, Representative Debbie Stabenow, the fight over whose prescription drug plan is more effective has spawned a campaign that at times feels like a visit to an insurance broker. On a recent evening, a Detroit television station, WXYZ, devoted several minutes to trying to decipher the dueling claims, right down to a discussion of co-payment fees.
"This is a bigger pocketbook issue than taxes right now," said Karl Struble, a Washington media consultant who has made prescription drug advertisements for clients like Mr. Schweitzer in Montana and Ed Bernstein, a Democrat running for an open Senate seat in Nevada. "I've sat in focus groups. I've watched people talk about it. I've been a pied piper telling people, 'This is where you want to go.' "
In no campaign have prescription drugs played a larger role than in the bid by Mr. Schweitzer to unseat a Republican incumbent, Senator Conrad Burns. A year ago, Mr. Schweitzer said, he drove across the state talking to voters. "It wasn't the first issue that most people talked about, but it was the second or third," he recalled. "It was a matter of listening to what they were saying."
Not long after, Mr. Schweitzer began signing up Montanans for chartered-bus trips to Canada to buy prescription medications at lower prices there. Coverage of Mr. Schweitzer's trips -- he called them "The Run for the Border" -- spawned imitators. Mr. Dayton began an "Rx Express" from Minnesota to Canada, and Mark Lawrence, Ms. Snowe's opponent in Maine, boarded buses for Canada, too.
Mr. Schweitzer has run several drug commercials, including the one in which he compares the prices with those of pet medicines. It was reminiscent of a statement by Mr. Gore that his mother-in-law paid three times as much for an arthritis medicine as he did for the drug for his dog. (The Gore campaign later acknowledged the anecdote was based on a Congressional study.)
Still, Mr. Schweitzer's advertisements have boosted his poll numbers, his advisers say, and forced the opposition to respond. In a new advertisement, the state Republican Party asserts that Mr. Schweitzer "backs Al Gore's big government health care agenda," a plan it calls "bad medicine for Montana."
Dick Wadhams, a spokesman for Senator Burns's campaign, said, "It is fair to say the prescription drug issue has been fairly dominant in the campaign, largely because Schweitzer has been a one-issue candidate since last year."
From any camera angle, it is clear Mr. Schweitzer thinks that one issue might just be enough.

HEADLINE: Europe Delays Its Sanctions Against U.S. Over Trade

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN

 BODY:
The United States persuaded the European Union yesterday to delay imposing billions of dollars in sanctions stemming from a dispute over tax laws, providing at least a short reprieve while both sides seek to cut through a thicket of trade tensions.
The 11th-hour delay, negotiated in Brussels, is a victory for President Clinton. Mr. Clinton decided this month to hold off on applying new sanctions on European luxury goods in connection with a separate case involving beef and bananas, hoping to a avoid an escalation in trans-Atlantic trade tensions. 
 The agreement yesterday is only a procedural delay and does not address the substance of either trade dispute. But it does give the two sides more time to work out settlements to cases they have each won against the other at the World Trade Organization, the Geneva-based trade regulatory body.
"The United States and European Union today demonstrated a commitment to avoid escalating trans-Atlantic trade tensions and managing this W.T.O. trade dispute responsibly," said the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky.
The delay would appear to justify Mr. Clinton's faith in Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, who had appealed to him to stall new sanctions on Scottish cashmere and other European goods. Mr. Blair persuaded Mr. Clinton that he was intervening to soften the hard-line European stance on both the beef and banana case and the tax case.
Europe's concession also came after the United States intervened in currency markets to shore up the troubled euro just over a week ago. The Clinton administration took traders by surprise when it joined the European Central Bank in buying euros and selling dollars, at least temporarily breaking what had been a steady fall for the 21-month old European common currency.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, did not cite festering trade disputes as a reason for the intervention. But the action improved the sometimes hostile relations between the world's two leading economic powers at a crucial time.
The tax case is, in dollar terms, the largest trade case in history. It involves an American law that allows major corporations, including Boeing and General Motors, to avoid paying some taxes on sales they make overseas. The tax break amounted to $4.1 billion last year. The trade body ruled that the law amounts to an illegal export subsidy, entitling Europe to impose trade sanctions that would probably amount to at least that much each year.
Under the accord yesterday, Europe will not begin the possibly long process of imposing sanctions until at least Nov. 1, extending by one month the date originally set by the trade organization. That gives Congress more time to pass new tax legislation that the Clinton administration says will bring the country into compliance with trade rules, obviating the need for sanctions. The House has already passed such legislation, and it is now before the Senate.
The European Union has argued -- and it reiterated its stance yesterday -- that the new American legislation does not address the flaw in the previous tax law. But it also agreed yesterday to allow the W.T.O. to decide on the validity of the new law before any sanctions are imposed. That could mean that even if the new law is ruled a violation, trade between the two powers would not be affected for eight months or so more.
Meanwhile, the Clinton administration has yet to publish the new list of sanctions in retaliation for Europe's restrictions on beef and banana trade.
The administration won the right in 1998 to slap 100 percent duties on about $300 million in European goods each year because Europe restricts trade in beef and bananas. Congress later passed a law requiring the administration to rotate the list of European luxury goods hit by those sanctions to make them more painful to more European companies.
But the new list is already several months overdue. A senior administration official said this month that they had been placed in "strategic limbo" while the two sides seek a settlement.
A senior American trade official said yesterday that Europe had made some progress toward complying on beef and banana trade, but the official did not suggest that a resolution to the matter was imminent.

HEADLINE: At Crucial Point in Race, Lazio Retooling Upstate Strategy

BYLINE: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

DATELINE: WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 29

 BODY:
The cheers echoed through the ballroom of the Best Western Carriage House Inn here. White "Lazio 2000" buttons gleamed from shirts and blouses and, as they always do, those in the crowd laughed at Representative Rick A. Lazio's favorite joke about New York subsidizing Arkansas.
"We expect our fair share," said Mr. Lazio, smiling his perpetual grin and adding that New York State sends billions more in federal taxes to Washington than it receives in return. "If you compare it to states that we effectively subsidize, Southern states, like, let's pick a Southern state, say. . . ." 
 "Arkansas!" someone from the crowd cried out, to laughter.
Mr. Lazio had come, though, to convince people that the upstate economy had turned a corner but had not completely righted itself, a notion he found disputed not only in the region, but also in this very room.
"Stay on message," one man called out. "New York State upstate is getting better in spite of what the opposition makes fun of you for."
But one woman in the crowd was not convinced. "We are dairy farmers," she said. "All of the economy in the North Country is not getting better. My husband has taken over a 60 percent cut in wages this year, and so has my son, who works with us. We want to preserve our family farm. We need that Northeast dairy compact now, and we want you working for it."
Nobody mentioned soft money. Few people talked of trust. Instead, this week, as he toured upstate in advance of what his aides said would be a full-court press in October to counter an unexpectedly strong showing in the region by Hillary Rodham Clinton, Mr. Lazio heard concerns about more bread-and-butter issues, like jobs and local development.
Mr. Lazio reaches the start of October, a critical time for his campaign, with three polls indicating that Mrs. Clinton is building a lead, particularly upstate, which pundits say he should command.
He has faced enthusiastic, if modest, crowds, but also concerns among Republican voters and party officials that people do not have a good grasp of him, that he may not be hitting concerns that drive people into the voting booth.
His campaign strategists are sending word to reporters to watch for a "revamp" and "retooling" in his upstate strategy. They say he will devote more time and resources upstate. More television commercials will be broadcast. More proposals will come out. He will talk more about an education plan he proposed nearly three weeks ago but has not heavily promoted since then, although he has called the issue paramount. More surrogates will make appearances, like Gov. George E. Pataki, who toured with Mr. Lazio at a factory today to promote tax relief as a stimulus to the economy.
Mr. Lazio's campaign manager, Bill Dal Col, said of the coming surge, "The final push is about pushing you over the edge."
Mr. Dal Col warned against underestimating the power of grass-roots, low-profile campaigning, including direct-mail and phone solicitations. These, he said, are potentially potent weapons that Mr. Lazio plans to unleash with vigor in October.
Some political scientists watching the campaign say they think that Mr. Lazio's push for upstate voters will not be as successful as he hopes. They say he should have paid more attention to the region earlier, instead of allowing Mrs. Clinton to be the first to bring up the upstate economy and to advance the perception -- right or wrong -- that she has taken the lead on the issue, a perception that has given her a bounce in the polls.
Surveys taken well in advance of Election Day do not necessarily capture the mood of voters. But they do feed impressions of a candidate and a campaign among voters and journalists.
"There is pretty good reason to be concerned," said a top Republican strategist. He wondered if Mr. Lazio's support of large-scale tax relief measures would resonate in upstate areas that were not ailing. "Their numbers are indicating that they are falling far enough back that they have a lot of work to do," he said of the Lazio campaign. "They are allowing the terms of engagement to be dictated by the other side."
Another Republican strategist put it more bluntly, saying: "These guys are flailing. There is no apparent direction that I can see, and they better find one in the next couple of weeks before it is too late."
Even some of Mr. Lazio's most enthusiastic supporters say he needs to do more to connect with voters, particularly upstate.
"The soft-money thing was great for getting his name out there," said a Republican fund-raiser in Ulster County, "but people want to hear more about his record. His message doesn't always get out. He has a good record."
James E. Campbell, a professor of political science at the State University of New York at Buffalo, agreed, saying Mr. Lazio's battle with Mrs. Clinton over the unregulated campaign funds known as soft money cost him precious time needed to counter a growing perception that he was not attentive to the struggling economy in pivotal Erie County.
Professor Campbell said that while there were more jobs in the county now than there were a few years ago, the boarded-up storefronts and abandoned buildings made it clear that much more needed to be done.
"He needs to reassess and make his case that his more broad-base plan is better for the economy than Mrs. Clinton's targeted micromanaging approach," Mr. Campbell said.
Mr. Lazio contends that his comments on the economy have been misconstrued. He has said that his plan to lower taxes and encourage business partnerships among the private and public sectors will strengthen the economy everywhere.
"As I've said all along, more work needs to be done," he said.
He also says that with five weeks left in the race, he does not put much stock in polls. He and his aides say they are not surprised that he is trailing Mrs. Clinton. They point out that Mr. Lazio is running in a state with a Democratic majority, during a presidential election year in which the Democratic nominee is ahead in this state. In addition, they concede, Mrs. Clinton has campaigned aggressively upstate, and her campaign has broadcast several commercials aimed at the region. And they believe that Mr. Lazio's entry in the race just four months ago put him at a disadvantage.
"I think it's very important not to be fooled by poll numbers," Mr. Lazio told reporters today after the Watertown rally. "I think if you look at the enthusiasm at the grass-roots level, the people who are supporting me, the people who are Republicans and Democrats and independents, the people who are willing to cross party lines, the people in this room who are elected Democrats who are supporting me, I think that makes a huge statement about the fact we do have momentum, that we are going to win this race."
Over and over, Mr. Lazio has pointed to his 1992 upset victory for his House seat, a race in which polls showed him behind by 18 points several days before the election, he said.
Mr. Lazio missed a majority of votes in the House in September and has tempered the pace of his fund-raising. That has given him more time to campaign, which his advisers say he needs after spending so much of the summer raising money to catch up with Mrs. Clinton.
On this trip, which began Wednesday and was to end Saturday, Mr. Lazio's stops consisted largely of visits to small light-manufacturing plants, where he closely observed the assembly of lighting fixtures, sprayers for lawn care products and laminates for circuit boards. A strategist explained that such stops may seem low key, but they provide "good optics" for television and newspaper cameras in the smaller media markets the campaign has shortchanged.
Mr. Lazio also worked his base at party rallies and dinners, explaining the high stakes he sees in this race.
"People throughout America are looking to New York," he told the gathering here in Watertown, striking a theme he has sounded for a week or so. "They think this race is more important in many ways than the races in their own home state. They look at this race and they say, 'You know what? This is a race that may determine the direction that America goes. It may determine the moral compass of our country.' It's a race that could determine the heart and soul of America, and for a lot of New Yorkers, I think it's a race over the heart and soul of New York. So there is a lot at stake."
Since the summer, Mr. Lazio has said character and trust are driving issues; his aides said they were the underpinnings of his recent push for campaign finance reform, an issue they insisted he would not drop. But in recent days, Mr. Lazio has hardly raised the subject himself unless prompted by reporters.
Instead, in several speeches he talked of easing tax burdens across the board and stressed the importance of a sound education system -- the subjects of his two major policy addresses since joining the race.
This trip also offered Mr. Lazio a chance to hear more about voters' concerns. A policy adviser has been quietly taking notes at each stop. Mr. Lazio was asked by a veteran here if he supported a constitutional amendment to bar desecration of the flag. He said he did. At another stop, the candidate urged high school students to swear off drugs and alcohol, but later declined to say if he supported voluntary abstinence for everyone.
And he did plenty of old-fashioned, grass-roots campaigning.
"The countdown has begun," he told Republicans in East Rochester. "We need to make sure we get every vote out. Every vote counts in this election. Please, please, please get those bumper stickers on, yard signs up. Call your neighbors. We don't want to have to think about the day after election that we did not do everything that we should have done to make sure we sealed victory."

Violent clashes between Palestinians and Israeli forces in the West Bank and Gaza left at least 12 dead and hundreds wounded in the third straight day of pitched street fighting set off by the defiant visit Thursday of a right-wing Israeli leader, Ariel Sharon, to the ancient mosques atop Jerusalem's Old City. 1

Fujimori's Waning Power
United States officials have encouraged President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru to forge ahead with new elections, even as political experts say his influence appears to be declining. Mr. Fujimori's own prime minister has tacitly conceded that the military is restive. 16

HEADLINE: Low-Wage Jobs Leading Gains In Employment

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
New York City's rebounding economy has produced a record number of jobs, but a new study shows that the number of low-wage jobs, those paying less than $25,000 a year, is growing much faster than the number of middle- or high-wage jobs.
The study, to be released tomorrow, found that while the city had added thousands of high-paying Wall Street and Silicon Alley jobs in recent years, the fastest job growth had been among low-wage service employees, like restaurant workers, security guards, day care workers and home attendants for the elderly. 
 Since 1993, when job growth in New York City began rebounding after the national recession of 1991-92, the number of jobs paying less than $25,000 a year has climbed 22 percent, nearly four times as much as jobs paying $25,000 to $75,000, according to the study. And the number of low-wage jobs has risen twice as much as jobs paying more than $75,000.
The study, conducted by the Working Group on the New York City Low Wage Labor Market, a team of economists from government agencies and nonprofit groups, focuses on some largely overlooked cracks in the city's economic boom. It notes, for instance, that many jobs created in the last decade do not pay enough to support a family. It also found that for the city's low-wage workers, the median wage dropped by 2 percent from 1989 to 1999, after taking inflation into account.
"Despite the strong pace of private-sector job growth," the study said, "an alarming number of families in New York City are unable to earn enough to achieve an acceptable standard of living."
Some economists for New York State criticized the study, saying it was too harsh and overlooked some gains of recent years.
The study is intended to analyze conditions and recommend ways to improve the lives of low-wage workers in New York. It says that compared with the nation as a whole and many other states, the city's job growth has been concentrated among low-wage workers, and that their earnings have risen more slowly.
Mark Levitan, the study's chief author and a senior policy analyst with the Community Service Society of New York, said several factors accounted for those trends. Over the last five years, he said, about 200,000 people in New York have left the welfare rolls and entered the labor market. And as in Los Angeles, the nation's other major gateway, he said, there has been a huge influx of unskilled immigrants seeking jobs.
"We have a lot of people coming into the labor market with not a lot of skills," Mr. Levitan said.
In decades past, many unskilled workers moved into manufacturing or government jobs, which typically pay considerably more than low-end service-sector jobs. But factory jobs have declined faster in New York than in the nation as a whole, while the number of government jobs has remained flat for a decade.
The study found that when measured from 1989, the peak of the city's last business cycle, growth in low-wage jobs had accounted for virtually all the city's increase in employment. From 1989 to 1999, the number of under-$25,000 jobs climbed by 16 percent, to 590,000, the study said.
Suggesting that the city's economy is taking on something of an hourglass shape, the study found that from 1989 to 1999, the number of jobs paying $25,000 to $50,000 declined by 4 percent, as did those paying $50,000 to $75,000. During the same time, there was a tiny increase in the number of jobs paying more than $75,000 a year, as the job boom at Wall Street's securities firms was offset in large part by cuts at commercial banks.
The study, based on data from the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, found that of the 3.5 million jobs in the city in 1999, 590,000, or about 17 percent, paid less than $25,000 a year and that 1.8 million, or roughly 51 percent, paid $25,000 to $50,000. The study said 463,000 jobs, or 13 percent, paid $50,000 to $75,000, and 641,000, or 18 percent, paid more than $75,000.
Several New York State officials criticized the study for focusing on the decade from the 1989 business cycle peak to 1999, another high point. These officials argued that it was fairer to measure from 1993, when the local economy began to rebound.
Stephen Kagann, chief economist for Gov. George E. Pataki, said that the study painted an unjustifiably harsh picture, and that since the turnaround year of 1993, there had been across-the-board growth in the city's low-, medium- and high-wage jobs. Low-wage jobs account for 105,000 of the 311,000 jobs created in the city from 1993 to 1999, or 34 percent.
Mr. Kagann acknowledged that median wages for the city's low-wage workers might have declined over the last decade, as has been the case in much of the nation, but he said many of those workers moved to higher-paying jobs. Pointing to the unusual strength in the city's economy over the last year, he noted that the number of New Yorkers below the official poverty line fell last year and that wages for low-wage workers had begun rising, after accounting for inflation.
"New York City is having its strongest growth on record," Mr. Kagann said. "Employers are very hungry for people. What hungry employers do is they bid up wages."
Whatever year one measures from, the dishwashers, janitors and other New Yorkers who earn less than $25,000 say they can barely make ends meet.
William Cotto, a full-time security guard at an office building at Broadway and 68th Street, said his $7-an-hour pay was so meager that he worked 20 hours a week as a janitor to support his wife and four children.
"It's very hard," said Mr. Cotto, who lives in Harlem. "I barely have any money in my pocket. If I buy clothes for one kid one week, then I have to wait for the next week to buy clothes for one of my other kids."
Mr. Cotto, who has no health insurance, said he had fallen deeply into debt because of a $2,200 dentist's bill for removing a molar.
Andres Pulinario, a Dominican immigrant who works at a meatpacking plant in the Bronx, acknowledged that his $5.27-an-hour wage was far too little to support his family. To help pay the $510 rent for his Bronx apartment, he is forcing his 15-year-old daughter, Escarlin, to work 25 hours a week in a supermarket.
"Sure, I worry that it will hurt her in school, but what can you do?" said Mr. Pulinario. "Some months it's difficult trying to pay the rent on time."
Gloria Pye, a 58-year-old Bronx resident who earns $7.19 an hour providing home care for an Alzheimer's patient, is struggling to repay $3,000 in missed rent payments. She said she fell behind and was nearly evicted because of her low wages, the high costs of her prescription drugs for hypertension and diabetes, and being out of work for several months.
"I'm working 55 hours a week now," she said. "That's the only way I can make ends meet."
The study offers many recommendations intended to make it easier for low-wage workers to make ends meet, including extending health insurance to more uninsured workers and having the government do more to provide affordable day care and housing for low-wage workers. It also calls for improving job training for unskilled workers and providing bus service so workers living in the city can travel to better-paying jobs in the suburbs. The study also calls for raising the state's minimum wage to $6.75 an hour, considerably higher than the federal minimum of $5.15.
"This city is always going to have a significant low-wage service sector," Mr. Levitan said. "The question is: Is public policy going to provide these people with a way to make ends meet? We're always going to have people working in restaurants, caring for the aged, taking care of children and mopping floors. That's part of the modern urban economy. All we're saying is: Why can't these people live at a decent level? Why can't they have health insurance or decent housing?"
A little more than half of those earning less than $25,000 were born outside the United States, the study found. And more than 17 percent do not speak English well or do not speak it at all.
Two weeks ago, several nonprofit groups issued a study saying the federal poverty line, $14,150 for a household of three, did not come close to supporting a household of three in New York City. The study said a household of three in the Bronx needed $38,088 to cover a no-frills budget for housing, food, child care, health care, taxes, transportation and other basic costs.
In Queens, a basic budget for self-sufficiency would be $46,836 a year, that study said, and in the southern half of Manhattan, $74,232.
The new study on low-wage workers found a widening gap between rich and poor workers. From 1989 to 1999, average wages for workers in New York earning more than $75,000 annually jumped by 65 percent, after inflation is taken into account, while those earning under $25,000 experienced a 2.2 percent drop. For those in the least-skilled occupations, after-inflation wages fell by 14 percent.
Those earning at least $75,000 -- about 18 percent of the city's work force -- had 85 percent of the total increase in wages and salaries from 1989 to 1999.
"Clearly in this type of economy, skills are rewarded," said the chief economist for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, Eugene Spruck. "Those with the highest skills get the highest rewards. And the unskilled find that their real incomes are declining."
Calling the low-wage study too harsh, Mr. Spruck pointed out that employment in the New York region rose faster than in the nation last year and was at record levels.

HEADLINE: California's Freeway to Learning

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Abigail Thernstrom's argument against California's expansion of scholarships for needy students who perform well in high school (Op-Ed, Sept. 26) demonstrates elitism and defeatism. 
 She acknowledges that the program is based on merit, with its requirement of a B average, and on need, with its limits on family income. So the only way left to discredit the idea is to say, without offering evidence, that the program will lead to grade inflation and lower standards. The logical conclusion of her argument is that some students are not cut out for college and would never get there unless high schools and colleges lowered standards.
We in California reject that gloomy assessment of our children and our schools. Gov. Gray Davis and the Legislature have demonstrated their belief that society is better served when our children are better educated.
 
JOHN MOCKLER
Sacramento, Sept. 26, 2000
 
The writer is California's interim secretary for education.

HEADLINE: Online Delivery Sites Finding That Manhattan Can Be a Hard Place to Make It

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR

 BODY:
Kozmo.com, which strives to be the 7-Eleven and Blockbuster of online delivery companies, started in Manhattan. Urbanfetch.com, one of its main competitors, has one of the strongest presences in the city. YourGrocer.com, an online supermarket that serves much of the New York region, gained its first footholds in TriBeCa and Greenwich Village.
They came for the density, the upscale customers and the advantage of not having to pay the high rents of their bricks-and-mortar competitors. City and state officials seem to be tripping over one another to offer grants and tax breaks to lure more of these desktop-to-doorstep companies, which deliver a range of items, including soap and DVD players, to New Yorkers. 
 But in all the furor to bring new businesses and jobs to New York, critics say that an important question is not being asked: Can the online delivery model work in Manhattan? The answer varies. But there seems to be a consensus on at least one thing: in Manhattan, success for these companies is going to be harder than it seemed.
"I'll be the first to tell you that Manhattan, specifically, is one of the most difficult areas for any kind of new consumer service," said Shawn Milne, a senior analyst at E*Offering, an online brokerage firm that sells Internet stocks. "It is very difficult logistically."
If the companies cannot succeed in Manhattan, some critics wonder whether it is a good idea for the state and city to provide them with economic incentives -- in effect, becoming venture capitalists with taxpayer money. Many online delivery companies have underestimated the difficulty of operating in Manhattan, the analysts said.
Urbanfetch, which Kozmo is considering acquiring, stopped renting movies in Manhattan and Brooklyn last month because the profit margin on each videotape or DVD was not high enough to justify the costs of delivery. Kozmo and Urbanfetch began requiring minimum orders. And YourGrocer.com moved to Elmsford, N.Y., last year to be able to focus better on suburban families in places like Westchester and in Fairfield County, Conn., executives said.
But the problems did not stop there. Call it revenge of the bricks and mortar. Several traditional grocery stores have begun their own delivery services to complement their regular business. As the logic goes, the most traditional grocery stores -- whose main business is done through their storefronts -- can afford to lose money in order to cut into the online companies' margins.
In November 1997, Allen MacCannell founded NYCGrocery.com in Lower Manhattan. The company went to local markets and shops, bundling the orders and then delivering them to customers' doorsteps. The company was unable to navigate Manhattan's traffic congestion and difficulties like doormen-staffed buildings unwilling to take deliveries when tenants were absent.
"Suburbs," said Mr. MacCannell, whose company was bought in 1999 by a venture capital fund that owned YourGrocer.com. "That's where you get the unbelievably good prices."
Many online companies thought that Manhattan's density would work to their advantage because they would be able to maximize profits by making dozens of deliveries in a small area in one trip.
But analysts say they believe that many of them did not anticipate some of the logistical challenges. Delivering items by bicycle can be more expensive than using vans, because couriers, who are paid by the hour, cannot carry as many items.
Analysts also thought that the high price of real estate in Manhattan would put the competitors of online delivery companies at a great disadvantage. What they have found, instead, is that the intangible benefits of not having a Manhattan storefront must be countered with a flurry of outreach efforts and advertising. Urbanfetch even tried opening a booth to give itself a physical presence in Pennsylvania Station.
Probably the most difficult challenge, analysts said, revolves around consumer habits: Manhattanites are often less likely to purchase in bulk, which decreases the profits made on each delivery.
"Kozmo and Urbanfetch were a good story when profits did not matter," said Ned Vickers, who is starting an online company, NEDexpress, that will team up with traditional retailers, like Fairway.
There are signs of hope, however. Kozmo, which delivers in 11 cities, has seen its revenues increase and expenses drop since it began reconfiguring parts of its business this year, laying off about 300 workers.
Gerry Burdo, the recently appointed president and acting chief executive of Kozmo, said average orders in Manhattan had reached about $18, up from $10 in January.
The company's highest expense, labor costs for couriers, who average about 2.5 deliveries an hour, has stayed at about $12 per hour. Other overhead costs -- rent at $10 to $12 per square foot, management costs, technology and others -- have led to deficits. But Kozmo officials, who refused to discuss their balance sheets in detail, expect to make a profit in Manhattan soon.
The keys, said officials at the company, which has four warehouses in Manhattan, are to increase the number of deliveries couriers make per trip and the amount each customer is paying per order, and to build warehouses that can quickly get orders off the shelves. (Kozmo's newest warehouse in Manhattan, on East 45th Street near First Avenue, can process every order in about one minute, officials said.)
Still, some in the industry have doubts. So, if online delivery companies already in Manhattan cannot seem to turn profits, some critics wonder whether it is a good idea for city and state officials to provide similar companies interested in the market with financial incentives.
Webvan, an online delivery company that was scheduled to open two large warehouses in the South Bronx and Bergen County, N.J., bringing more than 1,900 jobs to the region, has only fueled that argument. Two weeks ago the company, based in San Francisco, said it would delay its most immediate expansion plans, including the New Jersey warehouse.
Technology industry analysts said the delay also cast doubt on the company's plans for the Bronx warehouse, which was supposed to provide more than 900 jobs.
Richard Lipsky, a lobbyist for several small-business associations in New York City, said it made no sense to provide economic incentives to companies that had not proved long-term profitability. "The city is acting like an overeager novice investor," Mr. Lipsky said. "It is putting a lot of faith in companies that have not proven themselves."
Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, who has studied the effect of technology companies on urban areas, said government officials could be wasting their time providing some Internet companies with incentives.
"The traditional instruments to attract and retain businesses are designed for larger companies that have an established history," Mr. Moss said. "So, here when you are dealing with firms that are really at the embryonic stage, then you need to think a little more strategically."
Still, Charles Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, the state economic development agency, said there were ways to protect taxpayer money. "We don't pick and choose one industry over another," he said. "What we do is get a commitment that they are going to come to New York and create new jobs."
Michael Carey, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said that the city had tried to research each of the Internet companies it had given incentives to, but that it was difficult to predict outcomes.
"There is no question that there are companies in this new-media world that may not make it," he said. "But if you look at what has happened in this industry in the last few years, it has become an important part of the city's economy."
