SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 36; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1369 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
'Year One,' a Conceit for the Millennium

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Until now the prospect of the 21st century and third millennium had not evoked much comment at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Whitney Museum of American Art and the Museum of Modern Art have gone all out, with two- and three-part exhibitions of the last 100 years or so of modern art. In its own all-museum effort, "1900: Art at the Crossroads," the Guggenheim looked back to the preceding fin de siecle, showing a cross section of academic and advanced art of that moment.
The Met, meanwhile, seemed to be sitting on its hands, perhaps understandably. After all, what's a new century or even a new millennium to a museum that covers five or six thousand years of art from around the world? But apparently it's not over until the fat museum sings. The Met seems to have felt that some gesture was in order, a suitably understated yet distinctive event that only a museum of its stature and girth could pull off. 
 A result is "The Year One: Art of the Ancient World East and West," a little show with a catchy title and a big reach. Forget about 1900 or the 1900's or anything so gauche as a museumwide celebration. "The Year One" puts the fleeting convention of the millennial-marking art exhibition in a new perspective.
Occupying a handful of galleries and containing a mere 150 objects, many of them quite small, this show simply looks back 2,000 years to the start of what historians sometimes call the "modern era," marked by the birth of Jesus. It takes a core sample of the nearly two dozen cultures flourishing at the beginning of the first millennium that are represented in the Met's collection and comes up with an array that includes coins and seals, jewelry and other accessories, glass, silver utensils, portrait busts, carved reliefs and sculptures, votive objects, architectural fragments, ceremonial vessels of ceramic and bronze and one stunning example of the so-called third style Roman wall painting.
The exhibition, which is the work of a team of curators coordinated by Elizabeth J. Milleker, associate curator in the museum's Greek and Roman department, has an ambitious goal. It sets out to demonstrate that in the several centuries around the year 1, the disparate cultures of the world began to have a new awareness of one another, stimulated by the expansion of stable empires and of trade, which moved people and objects across the vast Eurasian land mass. With them traveled ideas and religious beliefs as well as stylistic conventions, materials and artistic techniques.
The installation travels from west to east, from the several cultures encompassed by the Roman Empire under Augustus through the Parthian Empire of present-day Iran and Iraq, the Kushan Empire of northwestern India, the seminomadic Xiongnu Empire of Inner Mongolia, and finally to the Han Dynasty of China and the other Asian cultures clustered around it.
The exhibition as art-historical time slice can seem arbitrary and capricious, especially when the slice tends toward spongy: the objects here date from the fourth century B.C. to the third century A.D. Korea is represented by a single ceramic funerary urn in the shape of a bird; Thailand by six bronze objects, most outstandingly an eight-inch-high container covered with spirals that suggest both waves and basketry. The Xiongnu Empire, one of the show's big five, seems to be represented by almost nothing except some wonderful silver and bronze plaques with animal motifs that were made by Northern Chinese artisans and prized by the Xiongnu for use on harnesses or belts. And for some reason the show steps outside its premise at the last minute, concluding with four pre-Columbian objects, among them a small Mayan jar of carved stone, its surface enlivened by animal motifs.
The show begins in galleries adjacent to the new Greek and Roman galleries, and at first it feels like an extension of them. The first works reflect the expansion and revitalization of the Roman Empire under Augustus, the first Roman emperor, who ruled from 27 B.C. to A.D. 14. Augustus started and mostly completed the building of imperial Rome, tripling the city's size. He continued to import and emulate Greek culture and secured Egypt, whose Red Sea ports gave Roman sailors access to the Arabian Sea for the first time. The first object in the exhibition is a full-length, life-size bronze sculpture of a Roman boy made in Egypt; the second gallery has a large carved stone urn made in Greece for export to Rome.
It is as unusual for the Met to mix its cultures as it has been until recently for the Modern to mix its mediums, and it should happen more often. Here objects that are usually spread throughout the museum's building -- "four blocks apart," in the words of one staff member -- are seen out of context, in the company of relative strangers. And the viewing conditions are outstanding: the lighting is good and objects can be looked at closely and in the round.
In the show's center in particular one can follow the progress of certain influences, like the give and take between Hellenistic and Asian traits, through different cultures. They compete openly in a vitrine of small Parthian figures. They are united in two carved gravestones from the great Mediterranean trading center Palmyra, which show a man and a woman in tautly-wrapped drapery with star-struck Byzantine eyes. And they go their separate ways in Gandhara, a part of the Kushan Empire: represented here by a small relief (a stair riser) depicting maritime deities whose bulging muscles echo a Greek ideal, and an early stone carving of a Bodhisattva that even without its head is as imposing as it is otherworldly.
Objects that may previously have blended into permanent collection displays can suddenly stop you in your tracks, like a small terra-cotta relief from the Shunga Dynasty of India that depicts an unusually loving royal family in finely textured garments or a Han Dynasty mortuary pillar stamped with the relatively refined patterns of serpents and topped by a fierce gnomelike guardian detailed with incisions at once brusque and deft.
One certain showstopper is a large bronze ceremonial vessel from Indonesia (500 B.C. to A.D. 300) shaped like an ax head standing on its blade. This tall, slim, oddly flattened volume is accented along its gracefully curving edges with tear-shaped ribs thought to have been inspired by water buffalo horns and down its center with a starred diamond pattern. It is startlingly figural, like a regal torso, abstracted yet corseted.
But at least one transformation involves more than a change of scene. One of the most stunning inclusions is a re-creation of the black and dark red frescoes originally made for bedrooms in the summer villa of Agrippa, friend and son-in-law of Augustus. The fresco panels, embellished with trompe l'oeil images of ornate yet attenuated architectural supports and horizontal cornices that mingle Greek and Egyptian influences, were staples of the old Greek and Roman galleries. But to see them in situ, relatively speaking, is to see as never before their deliciously sophisticated mixture of decorative illusion (suggestions of gilded and painted bronze, carved wood, inlaid stone), natural detail and spatial inconsistency. The black simultaneously reads as shallowly niched wall surface and infinite nocturnal space, its doubleness compounded by dark-red dado and the presence of small, free-floating landscapes whose bits of architecture are as ephemeral as the structure that hovers around us.
Often the cultural, political and economic forces that this show tries to reflect are more complex than the objects can sustain; it begins to feel sketchy to the point of skeletal, more like an outline than a full exhibition. But even as the high concept evaporates and a more traditional form of connoisseurship prevails, one comes away with a succinct perception of culture as eternally in flux, driven by the incessant human desires for beauty, power and comfort and the need to know what's over the horizon.
 
"The Year One: Art of the Ancient World East and West" is at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500, through Jan. 14.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Seeking a Constant in the Many Styles of Lee Krasner

BYLINE: By KEN JOHNSON 

 BODY:
Did Lee Krasner (1908-1984) never find her true calling as a painter? Or was she a postmodernist before the fact? That is to say, did she reject the Abstract Expressionist myth of natural genius and deep authenticity and by working in a variety of styles over the course of her five-decade career realize the self as a field of socially constructed possibilities?
In his catalog essay for the Krasner retrospective that opens today at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the show's curator, Robert Hobbs, argues at length and often ingeniously for the latter view. 
 Mr. Hobbs positions Krasner -- who was, depending on how you look at it, blessed or cursed by marriage to Jackson Pollock -- as an anti-Abstract Expressionist. "Her reluctance (or inability) to settle on a single defining image serves in retrospect as a cogent critique of Abstract Expressionism," Mr. Hobbs asserts. "In refusing to settle for long on such a limiting tactic, she presents an understanding of the problematics of a contingent self that is particularly germane today."
It is a canny approach. What might be seen as the central weakness of Krasner's art, its apparent lack of originality or consistent development, Mr. Hobbs turns into a strength, an embrace of complexity and unpredictability.
Looking at the show's 60 works, dating from 1930 to 1981, however, it is hard to deny that despite its restless, searching energy and sporadic moments of formal power or elegance, Krasner's career looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than of real fulfillment.
Born in Brooklyn, Krasner began her art career in high school. She found her way early into bohemian art circles, befriending the poet and later critic Harold Rosenberg, embracing Trotskyist politics and joining the avant-garde American Abstract Artists in the late 1930's. After meeting Pollock and moving in with him in 1941 (they married in 1945), she devoted herself wholeheartedly to promoting his career and caring for his fragile psyche.
Fairly or not, Krasner has been known mainly for being Pollock's wife. Her own painting, which almost always looks heavily influenced by other artists, was never memorable enough to secure her own niche in the Abstract Expressionist pantheon until forces of feminism began working to upgrade her reputation.
As economically presented in this show, organized by Independent Curators International, Krasner's career looks like that of an ambitious perennial student. It begins with a routine, academic self-portrait, followed by an exercise in de Chirico-like Surrealism. In the late 1930's, she made handsome abstractions under the tutelage of Hans Hofmann and, a little later, a couple of abstracted, strongly linear still lifes resembling Arshile Gorky's early imitations of Picasso.
Krasner's "Little Image" series from the late 40's includes grids of hieroglyphic signs that call to mind the pictographic works of Adolph Gottlieb, and small-scale allover webs of spidery white lines on black that echo Pollock's ground-breaking cultivation of the allover field. Original or not, these paintings have a fine material and optical concentration, suggesting that Krasner's talent may have been best suited for more intimate ways of working. But she had bigger aspirations.
After her husband's death in 1956, Krasner burst out with a series of large-scale Abstract Expressionist paintings called the "Earth Green" series: loopy, raw and splattery pictures with mythic titles like "Birth" and "Sun Woman" that look heavily indebted to Matisse, Pollock and de Kooning. The climactic "Seasons" packs a roiling, primitivistic frieze of harsh pink, biomorphic fertility forms (breasts, buttocks, leaves and other bulging shapes) clumsily outlined in a fat black line and set off against drab green negative spaces on a 17-foot-wide canvas.
In the early 1960's, in another burst of energy after the death of her mother, Krasner produced a series of all-brown paintings with dense, allover compositions of swirly lines and hectic spattered texture that critics at the time saw as throwbacks to the glory days of Abstract Expressionism. But later in that decade, in tune with abstract painting of the time generally, Krasner turned to a more colorful, even gaudy palette, as in the garishly pink and purple "Gaea" (1966), and to more boldly defined forms, as in "Green Fuse" (1968), with its white egg shapes and wide arcing bands set off against a deep blue background and accented by vehement splashes of red and green.
Finally, in the 1970's, Krasner responded to the emergence of Color Field painting and Minimalism by simplifying her compositions and replacing areas of gestural texture with flat planes of saturated color, transforming her expressionism into a bland, emblematic design with vaguely exotic (Native American or Far Eastern) overtones.
Two episodes that stand out from this history of generic painting hint at a more personal road that Krasner might have taken. One day in the early 1950's, in a fit of dissatisfaction, Krasner tore up all the paintings and drawings in her studio. Returning two weeks later, she became interested in the chance arrangements of torn shapes on the floor and she began gluing fragments of painted or raw canvas and paper onto large canvases, creating jumbled Cubist compositions.
Some, like "City Verticals" (1953), are dense, wall-like accumulations of vertical strips; others, like "Bird Talk" (1955), have an airy, animated feeling. There are precedents for the collages, from Kurt Schwitters to Robert Motherwell, but they have their own exuberantly playful vitality and raw sensuousness. Krasner's exhibition of these works in 1955 was a critical success; Clement Greenberg called it one of the most important shows of the decade.
Twenty years later, Krasner started another series of collages, this time carefully cutting up her own 40-year-old charcoal studies from Hofmann's life drawing classes and neatly gluing to stretched canvases. These beautiful works are surely the most distinctive of Krasner's career.
Within rectilinear formats, razor-sharp diagonals and sweeping curves cut this way and that, the internal soft grays and blacks of the original drawings adding ambiguous atmospheric depths and a patina of antiquity. In "Imperative" (1976), the interplay of the grid and the central triangle create a classical stability, while dislodged, knifelike shards and the angular, faceted drawing of Krasner's early studies create a kaleidoscopic effect.
These works hark back to early-20th-century Cubism and Futurism yet have an expansive openness that belongs to the 1970's. One senses that Krasner was in sync with the collage process in a way that she never was with painting.
Her painting had a kind of impatient, even desperate urgency; she seemed to throw herself at painting, as if she thought she could make a painting through sheer force of will. Almost always there is a turbulent excitement, but you miss the painterly sensuality of de Kooning or the perfect rhythm of Pollock or the color and light in Joan Mitchell's work. Perhaps Krasner was intimidated by the importance of painting and had too clear an idea of what major painting was supposed to look like: like Picasso, Matisse, Pollock or de Kooning. To collage, it seems, she brought fewer preconceptions, allowing the process to be one of discovery rather than imitation.
Taking Mr. Hobbs's hint, it might also be that collage enabled the realization of a more complicated and contradictory self. If the singular Abstract Expressionist image comes from the achievement of a wholly unified creative persona, a unity that Krasner could never achieve, then collage could be a way to reflect the experience of a disjunctive, multiple self, a self at once new and old, orderly and dynamic, delicate and aggressive, impulsive and controlled, intellectual and intuitive.
Krasner was not a postmodernist; she wanted all too obviously to be a great Modernist painter. But she had her moments of exhilarating freedom from that oppressive ambition.
 
"Lee Krasner" is at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, Brooklyn, (718) 638-5000, through Jan. 7.

HEADLINE: European Court Overturns Ban On Tobacco Ads

BYLINE: By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The European Court of Justice, Europe's highest court, today overturned a ban that would have phased out tobacco advertising across Europe.
In a final decision, the court sided with the German government and four British tobacco companies, which had argued that the European Union was overstepping its jurisdiction in enacting the ban. Tobacco legislation, they argued, is a health matter, and as such should be decided by individual countries, not by the European Union, which oversees market competition among its 15 member nations. They also argued that the ban violated their freedom of speech. 
 "Governments and the commission are not above the law," said John Carlisle, public affairs director for the Tobacco Manufacturers Association. "We feel justified in our actions and hope they will result in a better and fairer mix of legislation in the future." British American Tobacco P.L.C., the Gallaher Group, the Imperial Tobacco Group and Rothmans Ltd. had appealed the ban.
A British high court judge had approved a request by the tobacco companies to take their appeal to the European Union court. The ruling today was based on a recommendation in June from the court's advocate general, Nial Fennelly, who said the European Union did not have the legal standing to enact such a ban.
But the victory is likely to be short-lived for the tobacco industry, which could be facing new restrictions. The European Parliament is considering a directive that would cut the tar content of cigarettes and require larger health warnings on packs. And even though the current advertising ban -- which was ratified by the European Parliament in 1998 and proposed phasing out newspaper, magazine and billboard tobacco advertising across Europe by 2006 -- has been overturned, individual governments are likely to take up the issue.
Britain's public health minister, Yvette Cooper, said today that the government intends to push ahead with a ban on tobacco advertising, despite the European court's ruling.
"This ruling is a disappointment, but it will not deflect us from implementing our manifesto commitment to ban tobacco advertising," the minister said. "We hope that the European Commission will bring forward new proposals in this area as soon as it possibly can."
In response, Mr. Carlisle of the Tobacco Manufacturers Association said, "We would urgently ask the minister to talk to us before framing any legislation so we can help them make sure that what they're proposing is workable."
More than half a million Europeans die each year from tobacco- related illnesses, according to Action on Smoking and Health, a British-based anti-smoking lobby group.
"I am disappointed," Clive Bates, the group's director, said of the court's decision today. "In Britain, we'll be O.K. But we do want to do something that benefits all citizens of the E.U."

HEADLINE: Prosperity and Poverty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Low-Wage Jobs Leading Gains in Employment" (front page, Oct. 1):
"Real wages" are derived by dividing the wages by the Consumer Price Index. It is widely accepted that the index has overestimated inflation. If the index is too high, derived real wages are too low. 
 In 1996, the Boskin Commission estimated that the index was overstating inflation by more than 1 percent per year. With a more accurate measure of inflation, the real earnings of the cited groups did not fall at all -- real earnings rose.
Census data show that the poverty rate in New York declined from a peak of 17 percent in 1994 to 14.1 percent in 1999. Moreover, New York was one of only four states to experience both a significant decline in poverty and a rise in real income.
As a matter of statistics or common sense, prosperity does not breed poverty.
 
STEPHEN KAGANN
New York, Oct. 3, 2000
 
The writer is chief economist to Gov. George E. Pataki.

HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
Armani Hammers Chaos Into Order in Final Touches on His Fashion Palace

BYLINE: By GUY TREBAY 

DATELINE: MILAN, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Workers erected a perimeter fence of fresh-cut oak branches along the Via Manzoni, Milan's main shopping street, preparing for Wednesday's party celebrating the opening of Giorgio Armani's long-awaited new flagship store. Mr. Armani himself stood on the sidewalk at 10 a.m., tearing apart a window display.
The suede headboard was facing the wrong direction, he told his assistants in Italian. The folding screen was angled inelegantly. The silk pillows were stacked, not scattered. With seven assistants tailing him, and several more on alert inside, the designer -- dressed in rumpled trousers, suede loafers and a quilted silk jacket -- deconstructed the window. 
 It was a moment of ironic symmetry in Mr. Armani's long career. Four decades ago, his first job was as a window dresser. Now, at 66, he heads a company with $850 million in reported annual sales, the most profitable fashion business in Italy. In many senses, Mr. Armani is the proprietor of a very big store.
The new Armani place itself is built on a Virgin Megastore scale. At 315,000 square feet, it features separate departments for the designer's jeans, his higher-end lines, an art-book shop, a florist, an Emporio Armani boutique, an Armani Home department, a branch of the restaurant Nobu and a Sony electronics section.
All told, it occupies three levels of a historic building by Enrico Griffini, a proponent of the Fascist architectural style. Mr. Armani spent $62.5 million for the building and another $10 million on a restoration, a year in the works, designed by Michael Gabbelini.
If any of this caused Mr. Armani to suffer from the newly fashionable Milanese complaint, stress -- "sono stressatissimo," is heard here almost as often as "ciao" -- you would not have guessed it from his demeanor throughout the day.
"He thrives on chaos," someone from within his organization said. "Chaos and control."
In the hours that followed the morning window critique, Mr. Armani showed his spring 2001 collection in several consecutive presentations to accommodate the hordes of buyers and fashion journalists, who are particularly alert to the fact that he has been preoccupied by a forthcoming 25-year-career retrospective at the Guggenheim Museum in New York, which opens later this month. He also presided over a front-row celebrity petting zoo that included Phil Collins; the mayor of Milan; a gum-chewing Sarah Ferguson, the Duchess of York, with her new boyfriend, Count Gadda della Gherardesca; a dour Robert DeNiro; and both the "new Sophia Loren," Maria Grazia Cucinotta, and the original Sophia Loren, still capable of putting imitators to shame. Then Mr. Armani slipped upstairs in his palazzo on Via Borgonuovo, casually changed into his trademark muscle T-shirt and returned to his store to serve as host for a four-hour party for "tutta Milano," all of Milan.
"People think of Pucci as psychedelic prints, but my father designed not just scarves but a universe," said Laudomia Pucci, who has the title image director for the House of Emilio Pucci, on a muggy morning this week. A few days earlier, a new store had opened on Via Montenapoleone, showcasing designs drawn from the archive of the late Florentine marquis with an amazing eye for design and women, and with a less predictable nose for business. Emilio Pucci was invariably described by a lap dog press as a Florentine of ancient lineage, an ace skier, a dashing prototype for jet set lady-killers.
It was less often remarked that he was an adroit designer (of capri pants, for one thing, adapted from island fishermen's clothes), an experimenter with fabrics (he pioneered stretch materials) and a man with an extensive and highly dubious Fascist past. Early this year, Ms. Pucci, the designer's only surviving child, entered into a deal with LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the luxury conglomerate, which acquired a 66-percent share in Pucci for the chance to resuscitate a neovintage brand and to revive the aristocratic dressmaker's design ethos.
"It's not a matter of Puccis are in and colors are in," Ms. Pucci said, explaining that the aim is to expand the Pucci customer base beyond the socialites who are prone to flashbacks of that kooky shift Mummy wore to cocktails at the Slocums' in Newport. "We can't look back all our lives to the 1960's."
Ms. Pucci, who came to fashion by way of degrees in politics and economics, added: "The most precious thing my father left to me was not his archive but his spirit.
"We intend to make this a durable fashion brand."

HEADLINE: Putin Joins India in Vow On How to Use Atomic Plants

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Oct. 5

 BODY:
President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today took a high-profile tour of India's leading nuclear research center, where reactors and bombs are designed, and promised to work with India in developing peaceful uses for atomic energy while encouraging India to sign the nuclear nonproliferation and test ban treaties.
Mr. Putin's hour-and-a-half visit to the Bhabha Atomic Research Center in Bombay was the last stop on his four-day trip to India. It suggested how far India has come in regaining international acceptance since it conducted nuclear tests in May 1998. 
 Mr. Putin described the research center as a "temple of science and technology."
In a joint statement, Russia also struck a note of tolerance for India's decision to hold off on signing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
"Russia welcomed India's voluntary moratorium on nuclear testing," the statement said, "and appreciated the Indian government's efforts to develop a broad national consensus" on the treaty.
Mr. Putin's trip here, the first by a Russian head of state in seven years, renewed ties between two countries whose friendly relations date from the cold war era, when the United States tilted heavily toward Pakistan, India's archrival.
Over the last few days, India and Russia signed military procurement deals, agreed to combat terrorism emanating from Afghanistan and declared that they would strengthen their cooperation on the peaceful uses of nuclear power.
Historically, most of India's military hardware has been of Russian origin, and Russia's role as India's chief military supplier was sustained on this visit.
The calculus is simple. Russia, which is in deep economic trouble, needs to sell its job-generating military products. And India, whose military was built with Soviet equipment, needs to buy them.
Looking to strengthen its conventional forces after a conflict last year with Pakistan in Kashmir, India announced that it would buy 310 T-90 tanks from Russia and produce 140 SU-30 fighter aircraft with Russian technology. Russia said it would give India a carrier, the Admiral Gorshkov, which will be refitted and modernized in Russia at Indian expense and equipped with Russian-made helicopters and other aircraft.
"Whether India likes it or not, India cannot shake off the Russian connection, as far as military hardware is concerned," said P. R. Chari, director of the Institute for Peace and Conflict Studies, a research organization here. "If 70 percent of your military equipment is of Russian or Soviet origin, you are symbiotically linked to them for spares and ancillary equipment."
India and Russia also announced a common front to combat terrorist violence committed by militant Islamic groups based in Afghanistan and said in their joint statement that the areas of Afghanistan ruled by the Taliban -- that is most of the country -- "had become the breeding ground for religious extremism and international terrorism."
Neither country suggested offering military aid to the opposition forces that are fighting the Taliban. Defense experts here said Russia and India could improve sharing their intelligence and work with other major powers, including the United States and China, to bring greater diplomatic pressure on the Taliban.
In his speech on Wednesday to Parliament, Mr. Putin said the same groups, even the same individuals, were plotting terrorist acts "from the Philippines to Kosovo, including Kashmir, Afghanistan and Russia's northern Caucasus."
Russia and India also offered each other support in their struggles with internal unrest, Russia's in Chechnya and India's in Kashmir, which India and Pakistan have been fighting over for more than 50 years. Both conflicts are being fueled by Islamic militancy.
The two countries offered the least detail about the agreement to enhance their cooperation on nuclear energy.
A spokesman for the Indian External Affairs Ministry, Raminder Singh Jassal, said the memorandum of understanding on nuclear power would not be made public and offered no reason for the secrecy.
"In what form the cooperation will develop, it's difficult to anticipate," Mr. Jassal said. "Russia is already collaborating with India in the construction of a 2,000-megawatt nuclear power station in Tamil Nadu."
The United States does not share nuclear power technology with India, because of American laws that require receiving countries to consent to international inspections of all nuclear sites, a rule that India refuses to obey.

HEADLINE: Alcoa Expects Weaker Demand

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Alcoa Inc., the world's biggest aluminum maker, posted a 42 percent increase in third-quarter profit today but said that it expected fourth-quarter results to be hurt by higher energy costs and weaker demand from the transportation and construction industries.
Alcoa said that net income for the third quarter rose to $368 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $259 million, or 35 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales rose 55 percent, to $6.3 billion from $4.05 billion, mainly because of acquisitions. 
 The Aluminum Company of America, based in Pittsburgh, lowered its third-quarter forecast two weeks ago, saying sales in the building and transportation industries and higher energy prices were eroding profit. The results matched revised Wall Street estimates, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Alcoa had been expected to earn 50 cents a share before the revision. The average fourth-quarter estimate has dropped to 50 cents from 57 cents a month ago.
The company plans to cut $176 million in annual expenses in the fourth quarter, excluding the costs of higher natural gas and fuel prices.
"As long as the U.S. economy and global economy is in respectable shape, we think they'll work themselves out of this modest slump," said Arvind Sachdeva, a money manager at Dean Investment Associates in Dayton, Ohio.
Shares of Alcoa fell 13 cents, to $27.13.

HEADLINE: Fed's August Meeting Heard Concerns About Energy Costs

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee was unanimous in its decision to leave interest rates unchanged in August, although concerns were expressed about rising energy costs, meeting minutes released today showed.
The Fed's action at the Aug. 22 meeting left the federal funds rate -- the interest that banks charge one another on overnight loans -- at 6.5 percent, the highest in nine years. 
 In explaining its decision, the Fed cited further evidence of a much-needed slowing of economic growth.
Statistical data and widespread anecdotal evidence "pointed to a noticeable slowing in the expansion of demand and economic activity," the minutes said.
The slowdown, the Fed said, was led by a moderation in consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity, and in housing activity, another engine of the economy's robust growth.
On Tuesday, the Fed, for the third consecutive meeting, decided to leave rates steady, noting that the economy's growth was continuing to slow to a more sustainable pace. The minutes for that meeting will be released next month.
Since June 1999, the Fed has increased interest rates six times to slow economic growth and keep inflation under control.
At the August meeting, the Federal Open Market Committee, which includes Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, voted 10 to 0 to leave the funds rate unchanged. Policy makers also signaled -- as they did again on Tuesday -- that additional rate increases could occur down the road should inflation flare up.
Though they did not mention it in their public statement released after the Aug. 22 meeting, the policy makers cited "the potential for persistently higher energy prices to affect longer-run inflation expectations," the minutes said.
Nearly two months later, at Tuesday's meeting, Fed policy makers specifically said that rising energy prices posed the risk of "raising inflation expectations" in coming months.
At Tuesday's meeting, they cited that fear and oft-mentioned concerns that the nation's tight labor market could worsen inflation as reasons for continuing to hold the door open to more rate increases in the future.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES;
In Something of a Surprise, Europeans Raise Rates Early

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Treading a thin line between the risks of higher inflation and stifled growth, the European Central Bank made a surprise decision today to increase interest rates, reflecting its concern over rising prices caused by the weak euro and expensive oil.
The quarter-point increase represented the seventh time this year that the central bank had raised rates. It moved the same day that the Bank of England decided to hold British rates steady and two days after the Federal Reserve left American interest rates unchanged while noting it was still concerned about a risk of inflation. 
 Many economists had expected the European Central Bank to take no action. But after its meeting today, the bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, made clear that rising prices were primary on its agenda. Rate increases made by the bank, he said, "continue to aim at ensuring that upward pressure on consumer prices stemming from oil prices and the foreign exchange rate of the euro do not translate into more permanent inflationary tendencies."
The move came less than two weeks after the European Central Bank led a coordinated purchase of euros on the foreign exchange markets with the help of Britain, the United States and Japan to strengthen the currency, down more than 25 percent against the dollar since its introduction in January 1999.
Apparently seeking to keep the currency markets on guard, though, Mr. Duisenberg indicated today that further surprise interventions on behalf of the euro were possible. He said that the decision to raise rates today was consistent with the central bank purchases of euros on Sept. 22 and that the European bank would continue to closely monitor the currency's value and act "as appropriate."
But if today's move was supposed to build confidence in the euro, the effect was short-lived. The currency rose briefly against the dollar on the news, reaching 87.86 cents, then fell back late in the day in Europe to 87.43 and settled in New York at 86.92 cents, down from 87.45 cents on Wednesday.
Most indicators in recent weeks suggest that the pace of economic growth in the 11 European nations that adopted the euro may have reached a peak in the second quarter of the year. Higher oil prices, and protests including work stoppages at companies relying on oil, contributed to the shift in sentiment from a fairly upbeat mood that had prevailed until recently.
Many economists now expect European growth to slow to perhaps 3.2 percent in the second half of the year, against 3.8 percent in the first six months.
But Mr. Duisenberg was at pains to insist that the bank's action today would not result in a slowing of the economy. "On the contrary," he said, "we believe this rate hike and this monetary policy stance create the best conditions for the robust growth which is going on." Business expansion in Europe, he said, had reached "cruising altitude."
At the same time, inflation by most standards has remained subdued. The underlying rate of inflation, excluding food and energy costs, is modest -- at about 1.3 percent. Still, Mr. Duisenberg stressed that in the central bank's view, today's move put interest rates at an appropriate level to combat price pressures.
The bank's governing council increased its benchmark -- the minimum rate for two-week loans to commercial banks sometimes known as the repurchase rate -- by a quarter-point to 4.75 percent. That narrowed the gap between the European benchmark rate and that of the Federal Reserve to 1.75 percentage points, from 2.5 percentage points in January.
Many economists said they had expected the bank to raise rates in the last three months of the year, though some expressed surprise that the move came as early as it did. "We expected an increase in the last quarter, but not quite so soon," said Ulrich Ramm, chief economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt.
Mr. Ramm said the increase seemed part of a sustained operation by the central bank to deal with the problem of inflation as a threat to sustained growth both by dampening the pace of economic expansion and supporting the value of the euro against the dollar. That could help relieve inflationary pressures that result from European purchases of commodities like crude oil that are priced globally in dollars.
Mr. Ramm said the move "did not primarily have the euro as its cause, but because of the euro's weakness and its effect on prices."
Yet he and other economists said the bank was walking a thin line, seeking also to avoid slowing growth and the creation of jobs. European unemployment, though still high by American standards, has recently declined for the first time since the early 90's as a result of the Continent's economic upswing.
J. Paul Horne, a senior economist at Salomon Smith Barney in London, warned that "slowing the economy and job growth would be the kiss of death for the euro."
Public sentiment on the currency has recently been mixed, notably since last week's referendum in which Danes rejected an adoption of the euro by their country.

HEADLINE: SHOWDOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA: THE DIPLOMACY;
The Plan: He Steps Down, They Step Up, U.S. Lies Low

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5

 BODY:
With televisions in the White House tuned to the images of protesters seizing the Parliament in Belgrade, President Clinton stepped into the Rose Garden today to encourage them on, at once offering American support while making it clear that the considerable American military presence in the region would not intervene.
"I think the people are trying to get their country back," Mr. Clinton said, just as it was becoming clear that the security forces would stand back as protesters took over government buildings and the central television broadcast center. 
 "The people of Serbia have made their opinion clear," Mr. Clinton said. "They did it when they voted peacefully and quietly, and now they're doing it in the streets."
The consensus among United States intelligence officials, senior military officers and diplomats interviewed today is that the era of Slobodan Milosevic was coming to an end.
But they also said that they were awaiting formal announcements from the security forces -- in particular the Yugoslav Army and the Interior Ministry's special police -- that they supported Vojislav Kostunica as the winner of the presidential election last month. That, the officials said, would be definitive.
Samuel R. Berger, the president's national security adviser, warned that the biggest risk was that Mr. Milosevic could marshal some part of the military in a violent effort to roll back the protests.
"This was a dramatic day, and it is difficult for me to imagine how Milosevic might reconstitute his power," Mr. Berger said in a telephone interview. "But we have to speak with a note of caution because he is capable of making a last stand. I don't think this is over yet. But it will be awfully hard for him to put it back in the bottle."
United States officials said that Mr. Milosevic is probably still in Serbia, seeking refuge, temporarily at least, in one of the Camp David-style retreats or command bunkers built outside of Belgrade.
These officials said they did not believe that Mr. Milosevic had fled today for Belarus or any other country that might offer him a safe haven from arrest on charges of alleged war crimes issued by the tribunal in The Hague.
"We don't know where he is, but it's over, he's done," said one four-star military officer who was apprised during the day about developments in Yugoslavia.
The overwhelming emotion in the White House was one of joy. Mr. Milosevic's violent efforts at maintaining a Serb-dominated Yugoslavia had predated Mr. Clinton's arrival in the White House, but now he was on the verge of being forced out on the last days of Mr. Clinton's watch. "If you can't get Middle East peace," one senior official said, "this may be the next best thing."
Several senior administration officials said that their first priority was ensuring that Mr. Milosevic left the country -- even if his destination put him out of reach of international law.
"Ultimately there should be some accountability," said an official who had participated in the decisions to intervene in Bosnia and then Kosovo. "But you also have to be practical and clear about the sequence here, and first things are first. The first thing is for him to step down, and for the transition to take place peacefully, and for him to get out of the country. And we are not about to get in the way of that."
The official ruled out forcing down Mr. Milosevic's plane, should he try to leave the country. They said they had no evidence that he was aboard one of three Antonov-26 military transport planes that took off from Belgrade this evening, Belgrade time.
Mr. Clinton's declaration today that he would keep American forces out of the conflict, officials said, was an effort to prevent the resurgence of anti-American sentiments that Mr. Milosevic might be able to stir in a last-ditch effort to hold on to power.
Mr. Clinton's comments today -- first at the White House, then in asides during a speech at Princeton University -- were directed therefore at encouraging the popular uprising while making it clear that the United States was keeping its distance.
He explicitly ruled out using the approximately 11,000 American troops in neighboring Bosnia and Kosovo, or the naval and Marine forces that have been conducting exercises nearby in the Adriatic Sea. "I don't believe it's an appropriate case for military intervention," Mr. Clinton said, "and I don't believe that the United States should say or do anything which would only strengthen Mr. Milosevic's hand."
But Washington has hardly been shy about offering incentives to the people of Serbia to take the kind of action that unfolded today. The administration has funneled money to voter education groups and the independent news media in Serbia. Mr. Clinton has often said that he is willing to lift economic sanctions against the country as soon as Mr. Milosevic is gone.
"The people of Serbia have spoken with their ballot, they have spoken on the streets," Mr. Clinton said at Princeton. "I hope the hour is near when their voices will be heard and we can welcome them to democracy, to Europe, to the world's community. And when they do, we will move as quickly as possible to lift the sanctions and build the kind of responsible partnership that the people there deserve."
That would allow American and other international aid money to pour in, and permit investors to rebuild the shattered country. While the process could take years, officials today were pointing to the speed with which Eastern European countries turned from dumping dictators to opening factories.
But they made no mention of the latest parallel, the popular ousting of President Suharto of Indonesia in 1998. While celebrated at the time, it led to two years of ever-worsening economic and political chaos.
Still, the uprising in Belgrade was celebrated from the White House to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright's plane. Flying back from Middle East peace talks in Egypt today, she said, "The important point now is for Kostunica to be recognized as president."
She added: "I hope it turns out for them as it did in the rest of Central Europe and that they will be free from Communism. This is a fork for us in the road -- whether this will go in a peaceful way or not. I think the people of Serbia and Yugoslavia deserve a peaceful exit after a horrible two decades."
On the presidential campaign trail, both major party candidates expressed support for Mr. Milosevic's opponents in Yugoslavia.
Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican nominee, said, "Our country must work closely with our allies in Europe and the international community, including Russia, to pressure Mr. Milosevic to go."
Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic nominee, said: "We call upon Milosevic to get out of power. It will be taken from him if he does not, because the people of Serbia have spoken, and now they are rising up."

HEADLINE: Time Warner And EMI Halt Venture Plan

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 5

 BODY:
Faced with opposition from European antitrust regulators, Time Warner and the EMI Group of Britain withdrew their application today for a $20 billion joint venture to link their music businesses and said they would work to submit a revised plan.
The decision came on the day of a meeting of regulators in Brussels, at which the chief European antitrust official, Mario Monti, was expected to propose clearance for Time Warner's separate and much larger combination with America Online. 
 In a joint statement, EMI and Time Warner said they had informed the regulators that they were withdrawing their application for approval of the planned combination in recording, music publishing and online distribution. But they maintained that there was value for their shareholders in such a venture and said that they would explore concessions to allay the regulators' concerns "while preserving the economic merits of the proposed joint venture."
EMI's chairman, Eric Nicoli, said, "We continue to believe that a joint venture with Warner Music Group can create substantial value for our shareholders and benefit our artists, consumers and employees by bringing together two companies with complementary strengths."
The companies would now have the time, he added, "to reassess regulators' concerns and to pursue solutions simultaneously in Europe and the United States."
The proposed linking of Warner Music, the music division of Time Warner, and EMI into a joint venture controlled equally by both would have created a giant in the music business -- one with more than 2,500 musicians, including superstars like David Bowie and the Rolling Stones, and accounting for more than 2,000 new albums a year.
The deal, together with the proposed acquisition of Time Warner by AOL, was widely opposed by rivals in the arts and Internet businesses as a juggernaut, a company that could monopolize much entertainment as well as being the world's largest online information service.
Time Warner's president, Richard D. Parsons, said the two companies would "continue to explore ways to structure a combination that will make sense for the two companies and be acceptable" to European regulators.
European officials had opposed the planned combination largely because it would have reduced the number of global music companies to four from five -- also including the music division of the Sony Corporation, that of Bertelsmann of Germany, and the Universal Music unit of the Seagram Company, which has agreed to be acquired by the French conglomerate Vivendi.
It is unclear whether Time Warner and EMI can now find remedies that would satisfy both the regulators and their corporate strategies. Failure would throw into question much of the further consolidation that analysts have expected in the entertainment and Internet industries.
Antitrust regulators from the 15 European Union member nations met in Brussels today, but with the timely withdrawal of the planned combination by EMI and Time Warner, the main issue on the agenda remained Time Warner's deal with AOL.
Amelia Torres, a spokeswoman for Mr. Monti, said a final decision on that would have to be made by Oct. 24 by the European Commission, the executive arm of the European Union, on the advice of the officials meeting today. The commission, though, will most likely reach a decision at one of two meetings called for Oct. 11 and Oct. 18. Mr. Monti was expected to make a proposal to the regulators, who act as an advisory body, on the Time Warner-AOL combination. Ms. Torres refused to say what form his recommendation would take.
To allay European concerns, Time Warner and America Online have given assurances that they would refrain from discriminating against rival Internet service providers in the online distribution of music for five years. In addition, AOL said it would end a music distribution alliance with Bertelsmann by buying the 50 percent of the venture it does not own.
People in Brussels close to the proceedings said that given the withdrawal of the Time Warner-EMI proposal and the remedies suggested by Time Warner and America Online, Mr. Monti was expected to recommend approval of that merger.
Time Warner's spokesman in New York, Edward Adler, said the chances of European approval looked good. "Discussions with the commission are nearing the end," he said by telephone. "We are confident of a successful conclusion."
That huge merger is being reviewed in the United States by the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Communications Commission. And while European regulators have conferred on the deal with the F.T.C., it remains unclear what effect the European decisions will have on the deliberations in Washington. Concern in the United States, unlike that in Europe, has focused less on the possibility of collusion in music distribution than on dominance over cable television networks.
The move by Time Warner and EMI in effect starts the clock running anew in their dealings with the European regulators. In their efforts to allay concerns, the two companies initially agreed to shed their entire European distribution business, sell several record labels and reorganize their music publishing businesses.
In a last round of grappling with the regulators, Time Warner and EMI proposed the additional sale of two sizable assets, Virgin Records and the Chappell unit of Warner Chappell Music Publishing, according to people close to the discussions.
Earlier this week, it appeared that those concessions might have been sufficient for the European authorities to approve the joint venture. But people close to the discussions said they came too late. So faced with a rejection of the deal, Time Warner and EMI opted to withdraw the entire plan.
"We were very close, inches away," a person involved in the companies' strategy said, adding that the companies would now focus on re-examining the joint venture in light of the experience derived from the discussions with the regulators, in hope of ensuring success the second time around. A fresh proposal could come before January, that person said.

HEADLINE: Curbs Sought On Abusive Tax Shelters

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee proposed tough new laws yesterday to crack down on abusive corporate tax shelters and to impose hefty penalties on those who promote sham transactions to evade taxes.
The leaders, in a bipartisan move, called for tough new fines, which in some cases could not be waived, and for a drastic increase in penalties on the promoters of sham transactions. 
 The proposals show that the campaign by Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers to combat what he says is the most serious tax enforcement problem facing the government, costing it billions of dollars each year, is gaining currency among lawmakers.
Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, and the panel's ranking Democrat, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, adopted most of the recommendations of Treasury tax policy officials and of leading tax lawyers.
The proposal would create a new class of tax shelters, called highly abusive devices, in which a strict penalty of 40 percent of the tax evaded would be imposed. Highly abusive devices are defined as those that rely on techniques that the courts have already found to be shams and which lack economic substance or a business purpose other than evading taxes.
The proposal would increase a fine on promoters who fail to give the Internal Revenue Service a list of customers for a tax shelter from $50 to 50 percent of the fees they collected. Many of the most egregious abuses uncovered in recent years were sold by promoters whose fee was one-third of the tax savings, according to Treasury and Internal Revenue Service officials.
The proposal also seeks to curb the use of dubious legal and accounting opinions on tax shelters and to let corporations escape penalties only if they had truly independent advice on the merits of a deal.
The I.R.S. can impose a 20 percent penalty on companies with failed tax shelters. To escape this penalty under the proposal, a company would need to have obtained in advance an opinion that it was more likely than not to prevail in an audit. The opinion would have to come from an expert with no financial or other ties to the promoters that would compromise his independence, and the tax shelter would have to be disclosed when a tax return was filed.
The 20 percent penalty would be required unless all of these conditions were met.
Peter L. Faber, a New York tax lawyer who has been in the forefront of calling on the government to rein in abusive tax shelters, said that over all he was very pleased but that the proposal left one significant issue open.
The proposal takes aim at tax shelters that lack economic substance without defining that term, which he said could result in legitimate deals being disallowed.
"What happens if a transaction produces an economic gain to a company of $10 million, and a tax deduction of $500 million?" Mr. Faber said. "Clearly the tax benefits outweigh the economic gain, but $10 million is a lot of money."
The idea of enacting new legislation to curb shelters has concerned large corporations. Harvey Golub, the chief executive of American Express, wrote to the Treasury Department last month that the main concern of the Business Roundtable, which represents the country's largest corporations, "is to ensure that any action aimed at abusive corporate tax shelters does not impede ordinary business transactions."

HEADLINE: Complicated Maneuvering on Utah Paper

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
For decades The Salt Lake City Tribune has been the largest newspaper in Utah without a connection to the Mormon church. Now the news of talks between a Mormon-owned newspaper company and The Tribune's corporate parent have raised fears inside The Tribune that its independent voice could be eroded.
The dispute involves an unusual cast of characters, including AT&T -- which owns The Tribune through one of its subsidiaries -- as well as Senator Orrin Hatch of Utah, who became tangentially involved when executives of the church-owned newspaper sought advice from Mr. Hatch, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, on the antitrust implications of their plans. 
 The Deseret News, an afternoon paper in Utah owned by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, had held discussions with AT&T about buying the telecommunications company's 50 percent stake in a joint venture that manages the advertising, printing and distribution operations for both papers, according to people close to the talks.
The acquisition talks have worried some executives of the Salt Lake Tribune Publishing Company, which controls the editorial operations of The Tribune under a contract with AT&T, because they believe that their church-owned rival may be looking for a backdoor way to exercise editorial control over material the Mormon Church leaders may consider offensive.
"They are finding any way they can to get control of the paper so they can get control of the media in the state," said Thomas Kearns McCarthey, a great-grandson of Thomas Kearns, who bought The Tribune in 1901. Mr. McCarthey is currently a director of the Salt Lake Tribune Publishing Company.
Executives of the Deseret News Publishing Company, however, strongly deny they have any ambition to control the content of their competitor; all they seek, they say, is a chance for The News to compete head to head with The Tribune for morning readers.
Whatever the point of the battle, economic or editorial, the battleground is the joint agency that runs the noneditorial functions of both newspapers.
The News denies that it is now seeking control of The Tribune, but it does not deny that it once explored seeking control of the joint operational venture. L. Glen Snarr, chairman and president of the Deseret News Publishing Company, issued a statement yesterday saying, "Contrary to some media reports, the Deseret News Publishing company is not seeking in any way to control, own or interfere with the voice and content of The Salt Lake Tribune."
He added: "The Deseret News supports having two newspapers under separate ownership serving the community. We are not attempting to change that situation."
An executive at AT&T, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the company hoped to resolve the situation soon and would probably sell its entire stake back to The Tribune's management if several financial issues could be agreed upon.
If a deal is not struck, The News could win control of the joint operational agreement, this person said, though it would ultimately lower the value of The Tribune's editorial operations.
A spokeswoman for AT&T said The Tribune is not a core asset, but declined to comment on a pending sale, citing AT&T's policy not to comment on speculation about mergers, acquisitions or divestitures.
While both papers have coexisted in their joint venture for decades, longtime trends have weakened afternoon newspapers like The News and have often bred tension between newspaper partners in joint operating agreements across the country. These agreements, which first cropped up seven decades ago and were legally sanctioned by Congress in 1970, allow competing newspapers to merge advertising, printing and distribution operations while maintaining separate editorial voices. The Justice Department still approves the creation and dissolution of joint operating agreements for newspapers.
As afternoon newspapers lose circulation, they have become unequal partners in joint operating agreements. Some, like The Seattle Times, shifted to morning publication; some ceased publication; and some bought out, closed and replaced their morning rivals. The News, with a circulation of 65,000 -- about half that of the morning Tribune's 135,000 -- wants to move to morning publication, its executives say, to compete on a level playing field. Changing to a morning publication is a main reason The News is interested in fully controlling the printing and distribution operations.
But Mr. Snarr of The News and B. Lloyd Poelman, its lawyer, confirmed that it has been in talks -- first with Tele-Communications Inc. and subsequently with AT&T after the telecommunications giant acquired control in 1997 -- about control of the assets of the Newspaper Agency Corporation, the agency that publishes the two newspapers jointly. "We've had some discussions, yes," Mr. Snarr said, "we were looking at purchase of some business assets without any effort to control the voice of The Tribune or control the editing." He said the assets in question "included the N.A.C.," referring to the Newspaper Agency Corporation, but that those talks ended in 1999.
In the course of the talks, Mr. Poelman said, he attended a meeting late in 1999 at which Utah's senior Republican senator, Mr. Hatch, was briefed on these discussions. Senator Hatch had no comment on the issue yesterday. Christopher Rosche, his communications director, said: "Senator Hatch is not involved in any negotiations if they are taking place. He was never been involved in any negotiations that may have been taking place."
His only involvement, Mr. Rosche said, was to reply to constituents seeking advice on antitrust provisions of their plans.
Mr. McCarthey, a non-Mormon, said he had economic as well as editorial interests in the fight. He and his siblings and cousins are owner-directors of the Salt Lake City Tribune Publishing Company, which has a contract to manage The Tribune's editorial operations and has an option to buy back control of the newspaper -- and its 50 percent share of the joint operating agreement -- in the summer of 2002. At current market values, he said, that would cost them $175 million.

HEADLINE: Liberating Yugoslavia

 BODY:
The long tyranny of Slobodan Milosevic was crumbling in Belgrade yesterday. In a tumultuous day reminiscent of the anti-Communist revolutions of 1989, the leading symbols of Yugoslav government power, like the Parliament and the state television station, fell to opposition demonstrators as police resistance melted away. Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets and, refusing to be intimidated, demanded that the recent election of Vojislav Kostunica as president be respected. Their courage and determination impressed a watching world.
As the day ended, it seemed likely that Mr. Milosevic's tenure as Yugoslavia's leader would soon expire, perhaps in a matter of hours. Unless he can somehow assert command of the army and security forces for a desperate and doubtless bloody defense of his regime, his options will be few, including accepting an orderly transfer of authority to Mr. Kostunica or attempting to flee the country. After yesterday's decisive events, he can no longer count on support from the three main props of his 13-year rule: the security forces, the state-controlled media and the political and business cronies who have profited from his administration. Mr. Milosevic, who was indicted for war crimes by an international tribunal last year, should eventually be brought to trial. 
 It is appropriate that Mr. Milosevic's downfall is being engineered by his own people, not his many foreign foes. The Clinton administration and other Western governments are right to offer verbal encouragement but otherwise stand aside. President Clinton's promise to lift economic sanctions against Yugoslavia is a tangible incentive for change.
Russia has much to gain, and little to lose, by using its influence in Belgrade to speed Mr. Milosevic from power. President Vladimir Putin should abandon Moscow's neutrality on the outcome of the Yugoslav election and affirm Mr. Kostunica's victory.
Once they firmly gain power, Mr. Kostunica and his allies will confront the challenge of creating a democratic government and free society on the ruins of a collapsed tyranny. In some ways, they will have a simpler task than Belgrade's Central and East European neighbors faced in 1989. Yugoslavia already has a legitimately elected president and Parliament that can now assume legal authority. While a majority of the legislators elected last month ran as Milosevic allies, many may now transfer their loyalties to democratic government.
A crucial step will be to depoliticize the army and police, which have been agents of repression under Mr. Milosevic. Many commanders will have to be removed, and some should be brought to trial for their role in enforcing Mr. Milosevic's brutal policies. Encouragingly, important elements of the security forces stood aside as the protesters converged on Belgrade yesterday, indicating that their loyalty is to the Serbian people, not Mr. Milosevic.
The victory of democracy in Yugoslavia will have significance for all Europe. For nearly a decade, Mr. Milosevic's policies of military aggrandizement and ethnic persecution have blighted the Balkans and embroiled the United Nations and NATO. He brought war and suffering to Croatia, Bosnia and Kosovo, driving hundreds of thousands of people from their homes -- including many Serbs after these wars went badly for Belgrade and its allies. Once he has left office, Europe will at last be democratic and whole from the Atlantic to the borders of the former Soviet Union and beyond.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

European Central Bank Increases Interest Rates
Treading a thin line between the risks of higher inflation and stifled growth, the European Central Bank made a surprise decision to increase interest rates, reflecting its concern over rising prices. 
 The quarter-point rise, to 4.75 percent, was the seventh increase made by the central bank this year. The bank moved the same day that the Bank of England decided to hold British rates steady and two days after the Federal Reserve left interest rates alone. Page C6.

South Korea's central bank raised interest rates, alarmed by four consecutive months of rising inflation. World Business, Section W.
 
Tougher Tax Shelter Rules Proposed
Leaders of the Senate Finance Committee proposed tough new laws to crack down on abusive corporate tax shelters and to impose hefty penalties on those who promote sham transactions to evade taxes. C6.
 
September Retail Sales Rose 3.3%
Sales at retail stores open at least a year rose 3.3 percent in September, but many stores were offering deeply discounted prices, which will probably cut into profits for the quarter and for the year. C6.
 
Murdoch Son Named to a Top Post
The News Corporation said that Lachlan Murdoch, the oldest son of the company's chairman, Rupert Murdoch, had been named deputy chief operating officer, the No. 3 position at the company. Lachlan Murdoch, 29, left, has long been his father's heir apparent and is expected to one day run the media giant, in which the Murdoch family holds 31 percent of the voting shares. C6.
 
Stocks Drop on Earnings Worries
Stocks slid, weighed down by concerns about earnings. The Nasdaq composite index fell 51 points, or 1.5 percent, to 3,472.10. The Dow Jones industrials dropped 59.56 points, or 0.6 percent, to 10,724.92. The S.& P. 500 rose 1.96 points, to 1,436.28. C7.
 
Talks Raise Anxiety at Utah Paper
The Salt Lake City Tribune has long been the largest newspaper in Utah without a connection to the Mormon church. Now talks between a Mormon-owned company and The Tribune's parent have raised fears at The Tribune that its independent voice could be eroded. C2.

HEADLINE: Yugoslavia's Fate, and Europe's

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a senior fellow at the New America Foundation, is author of the forthcoming "Eastward to Tartary: Travels in the Balkans, the Middle East and the Caucasus."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Slobodan Milosevic's fall in Serbia can extinguish the last vestiges of the Communist Party in Eastern Europe that began with Red Army occupation in 1945. Though Tito's Yugoslavia broke with the Soviet Union in 1948, Yugoslav Communists in the Republic of Serbia did not succumb to the counterrevolutionary wave of 1989 that swept away other Communist regimes around them.
Instead, they adopted ethnic nationalism as a means to retain their villas, hunting lodges and other perquisites of power. Mr. Milosevic and his inner circle have been not only war criminals, extreme nationalists and mafiosi, but also apparatchiks with the bureaucratic knowhow to carry out lethal policies. 
 Mr. Milosevic's downfall could open many doors for the reconstruction of Serbia, and for Bosnia and Kosovo as well. Yet the real issue for the next administration in Washington will be less the former Yugoslavia than the integration of the entire Balkan peninsula, including Romania and Bulgaria, into Europe. For at the moment, there are two Europes, with the southeast part of the continent a bloc of unstable, impoverished countries where the political and economic trends are mostly bad, this week's revolt against Mr. Milosevic notwithstanding.
The victory of Vojislav Kostunica over Mr. Milosevic was another indication that the Dayton peace accords of 1995, despite their shortcomings, have worn extremely well. The collapse of the criminal regime of the late Franjo Tudjman in Croatia, if followed securely by Mr. Milosevic's in Serbia, would mean that Zagreb and Belgrade are no longer the axes for troublemaking in Bosnia that they were, making NATO's job there easier.
Croatia and Serbia will always seek to advance the interests of their ethnic compatriots in Bosnia, at the expense of each other and of the Bosnian Muslims, no matter who is in charge, democrat or autocrat. But if both are to be transformed into democracies, they must first consolidate their own power through the building of institutions, and help for that can come only from the West. And without Mr. Milosevic to help protect them, it might be only a matter of time before the indicted Bosnian Serb war criminals Radovan Karadzic and Ratko Mladic are captured.
Similarly, while the traditional enmity between Serbs and Albanians in Kosovo will not dissolve and could even escalate as ethnic Albanians continue to consolidate their own power and criminal networks, at least a democratic Yugoslavia would no longer be the instigator of trouble for NATO in Kosovo to the degree that it has been. NATO has truly become an imperial overlord in the former Yugoslavia, given that Russia's historic power in the Balkans has waned.
But the former Yugoslavia is only part of the troubled Balkans. The widening gulf between Central Europe and the Balkans is strikingly manifested by the different paces of development of Romania (which, with 23 million people, has a larger population than all of the former Yugoslav republics together) and its Central European neighbor to the northwest, Hungary.
Since the reunification of Germany 10 years ago this week, foreign investment in Hungary has been six times that in Romania, despite the fact that Romania's population is more than twice Hungary's. Hungary's average monthly wage is more than twice Romania's. Apart from a few city centers, Romania is a sea of poverty, unemployment, obsolete factories and subsistence agriculture.
Romania's first real democratic president since the early 20th century, Emil Constantinescu, is departing after four years in office with disappointing attempts at reform. In the November elections, the ex-Communists are favored to win. Unlike the former Communists who returned to power democratically in Poland, those in Romania are unreformed.
In Bulgaria the situation is equally bleak. Unemployment, corruption and the paucity of development are so severe that, according to a recent poll, only 4 percent expect their lives to improve; 67 percent of the population say they are living worse than before the Berlin Wall collapsed.
Since 1989, the economies of the Catholic and Protestant countries of Poland, Hungary, Slovenia and the Czech Republic have all grown faster, or at least have been less stagnant, than those of Orthodox Romania, Bulgaria and Macedonia, and largely Muslim Albania. The Balkans were always the poorest part of Europe, but never more so than now.
After the NATO air war against Serbia in 1999, in which Romania and Bulgaria showed themselves to be loyal allies of the West, providing military bases and rights to fly over their territory, hopes ran high in those countries that generous aid would be forthcoming. People there say they have been bitterly disappointed.
An end to the Milosevic era could bring new hope in the Balkans. Mr. Milosevic failed not only as the result of his own miscalculations and the desire among Serbs for a better life that could come only with a new regime, but because America's democratic ideals were backed up by Western military and economic pressure. The NATO air campaign, however ill-conceived it may have been, began a process that -- combined with economic sanctions and substantial Western aid to the Yugoslav opposition -- appears to have removed Serbia from the category of rogue states.
President Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright deserve credit for applying the realist principle that projecting power is a prerequisite for the spread of one's values. In the 1930's, it was the Nazis who were applying military pressure and supporting local political parties in the Balkans with money, intelligence, printing presses and other aid. Not surprisingly, fascist ideals were then ascendant.
We should not delude ourselves that the spread of open societies in the Balkans and elsewhere is necessarily a natural development: it is a direct result of the expansion of American imperial authority -- albeit soft and undeclared -- which local populations now see as their self-interest to get along with.
Of course, the world is too vast and its problems too complicated for it to be stabilized by American authority, but the Balkans, contiguous to NATO-led Europe, are a natural area for our expansion. It will be the job of the next administration to expand NATO to the Black Sea and prevent the Balkans from permanently rejoining the Middle East. The fall of Europe's last Communist dictator would offer an unprecedented opportunity, but not a solution to the current division of Europe.
