SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk

LENGTH: 2881 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
So You Can Buy Love After All

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
I ADORE the Met, there's no question about that," Alberto W. Vilar said. "I go into that place, and I get goose pimples. Wow, this is the Met! My rich friends laugh at me, because I sit in the same seat every night, in the first row. A101, that's my seat. I want to watch the conductor, the pit, the stage. Not only that, I hold court. My friends come up. They know where I am."
If anyone has earned -- or at least, purchased -- the right to hold court at the Met, it is Mr. Vilar, a 60-year-old Cuban-American investor and opera fan who has lately been parlaying his acuity in the world of high-tech stocks into a philanthropic boon for the opera world. A member of the board of the Metropolitan Opera since 1995, he contributed $25 million to the company's endowment fund, and he has pledged to underwrite 10 Met productions, at about $2 million apiece. So far, he has paid for the company's productions of "Cosi Fan Tutte," "La Cenerentola," "La Traviata" and "Le Nozze di Figaro." 
 The "Fidelio" that opens on Friday evening will be the fifth, and Busoni's "Doktor Faust," a co-production with the Salzburg Festival in Austria, is due in January. Next season, the $2.5 million production of Prokofiev's "War and Peace" that Mr. Vilar underwrote at the Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg comes to the Met, having been seen at Covent Garden in London and at La Scala in Milan, all on his tab.
Mr. Vilar has not been shy about demanding displays of gratitude commensurate with such gifts. At the Met, for example, an operagoer may now sit in the Vilar Grand Tier or dine at the pricey Vilar Grand Tier Restaurant. As a result, he has become an easy target for critical barbs, particularly in Europe, where the twin traditions of private philanthropy and the aggrandizement of donors have been dormant since the days of Ludwig II of Bavaria, but lately in the United States as well. "If this less-than-reticent entrepreneur wishes to compel his beneficiaries to splash his name all over their buildings and his face in their programs, fair enough," an unnamed critic wrote with thinly veiled hostility in The Wall Street Journal last month. "He has certainly paid his dues -- and everybody else's as well."
Indeed, Joseph Volpe, the Met's general manager, said recently that "if he's not our biggest donor, he surely will be in no time."
And that's just the Met. Last month, Mr. Vilar held a news conference in Beverly Hills, Calif., with the tenor Placido Domingo and the conductor Valery Gergiev, at which he announced $24 million in gifts to the Los Angeles Opera, where Mr. Domingo is the artistic director, and the Kirov Opera and Ballet, which Mr. Gergiev directs. Last season, Mr. Vilar contributed $17 million toward refurbishing the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.
Nor does he confine his largess to opera. Carnegie Hall is on Mr. Vilar's gift list for $5.6 million, some to restore the Seventh Avenue facade, some to support five years of Vienna Philharmonic visits. Unfazed by politics, musical or otherwise, he has given $6 million to the Salzburg Festival; he scoffs at the notion of boycotting the festival because of Jorg Haider's ascent to power in Austria. And as starry singers like Hans Sotin and Waltraud Meier were bailing out of the Bayreuth Festival in Germany after disputes with Wolfgang Wagner, the festival's embattled director, Mr. Vilar offered to pay for a production of "Tannhauser" in 2002, a gift that reportedly helped keep Mr. Wagner in power.
More personalized gifts spring from Mr. Vilar's deep pockets as well. Having spent $10 million to build the Vilar Center for the Arts in Beaver Creek, Col., where he maintains one of his nine homes, Mr. Vilar provides an annual $1 million for artists' fees. Similarly, he spends $2 million a year on the Vilar Distinguished Artists Series at his alma mater, Washington and Jefferson College, in Washington, Pa., so that students can attend classical-music performances at no charge.
And then there's the small change: grants of less than $1 million to John Eliot Gardiner's Monteverdi Choir (for its Bach Pilgrimage cantata series), the Lyric Opera of Chicago (to import Handel's "Alcina" from the Paris Opera) and Mr. Domingo's traveling Operalia vocal competition (which gives an Alberto Vilar Award).
All told, Mr. Vilar has given or pledged about $150 million to musical organizations in recent seasons. In return, the organizations that have received his largest grants have been glorifying him on plaques and building facades, in program books and even advertisements. In addition to the Vilar Grand Tier at the Met, there is the Vilar Floral Hall, a restored Victorian structure at Covent Garden. In Carnegie Hall's season prospectus, the hall's board "gratefully acknowledges the generosity of Alberto Vilar" beneath each of the three Vienna Philharmonic program listings. At the Salzburg Festival this year, his photograph greeted festivalgoers as they entered the main hall. Both Salzburg and the Kirov now devote a page in their program books to him, complete with color photographs.
RODNEY MILNES, reviewing the Salzburg Festival for The Times of London in August, noted that "the ubiquitous Alberto Vilar seems to have moved in in a big way," and lampooned the program book's tribute page. "I suppose it's good to have the price tags for such things established," he wrote, "but it's starting to look as though the future of opera will depend on the whim of a Cuban-American stock market investor with a love of music."
In Mr. Vilar's view, such criticism misses the point.
"I think the single most important reason for recognition is to set an example to other potential donors," he said. "When you have your name on a building, it says, 'Here's a world-class person who is giving money, and he chose us.' Isn't that a message?
"People say, 'Oh, rich guy, he's got to be pampered.' I think that's so unfair. You've taken Finance 102. What is the positive impact of my gifts? More people see opera. Costs are down. Productions are better. More people are trained. And for somebody to take a cheap shot at someone for having his name on the wall, that really gets my dander up. I think it's insane. It's destructive. It's perverse."
Yet for all Mr. Vilar's insistence that the required recognition is meant to set an example, there is a hefty measure of self-congratulatory machismo in his enumeration of his gifts, and he clearly enjoys his place at the head of the parade. An hourlong discussion at the spacious Park Avenue offices of his firm, Amerindo Investment Advisors, was speckled with reminders that his contributions are unsurpassed.
"We don't have data," he said, "but I think anyone will tell you that I'm the largest supporter of classical music, opera and ballet in the world." He is, he noted, "the biggest donor in the history of the Salzburg Festival" as well as "the largest single contributor" to Covent Garden's reconstruction. He gave "the first gift ever to Bayreuth" and is waging "a one-man campaign overseas to bring private philanthropy to Europe." Of the Kirov production that is coming to the Met, he said: "This 'War and Peace': $2.5 million, great opera. It will be shown in less than 18 months at four of the top houses in the world, paid for by one guy."
Gerard Mortier, the artistic director of the Salzburg Festival, doesn't regard Mr. Vilar's desire for recognition as a problem.
"No, no, no, no," Mr. Mortier said of reports that Mr. Vilar had demanded that the festival replace his entrance-hall picture with a bust. "He always wanted a picture, and for me this is fine. If he wanted a bust, that would be O.K. with me, too. I don't care. What I care about is that the right productions are supported and that we can do new things.
"In Salzburg, we have people who will support only Baroque music or Mozart concertos. And for me this is much more dubious than Alberto asking to have his picture in the hall. People like Alberto, and also Betty Freeman, support my entire policy and make no conditions. And that makes a lot possible."
Mr. Vilar does have priorities. He is, for example, increasingly interested in underwriting productions that will travel to several cities. The productions of "Doktor Faust" and "War and Peace" are cases in point, and in making his recent gifts to the Los Angeles Opera and the Kirov, he encouraged them to build productions that can be shared.
He is also passionate about the training of young artists. He makes an annual gift to the Met to support the Lindemann Young Artist Development Program. He is paying for a similar program at the Kirov. Part of his gift to the Los Angeles Opera is earmarked for young artists, and he is about to announce a $10 million young artists' program at Covent Garden.
Mr. Vilar professes an interest, too, in "seeding the market," making opera accessible to future fans. To that end, he is buying a multi language form of the seat-back libretto system the Met uses, for several European houses, starting with Covent Garden, Salzburg and the Vienna State Opera. He is also negotiating to buy a share in Figaro Systems, the company that makes the titles.
"He likes the idea of his money going farther and supporting more organizations," said Michael Kaiser, who recently resigned as executive director of Covent Garden and becomes president of the Kennedy Center in Washington in February. "He has certain priorities, concepts and ideas about what he wants to do. It's not just about buying the prettiest package we can buy this week."
IF Mr. Vilar's philanthropy has made him ubiquitous lately, only five years ago hardly anyone in the classical-music world knew his name. Born in Newark in 1940, the son of a Cuban sugar executive, he spent his first nine years in Cuba and the next nine in Puerto Rico. By the time he was 10, he had developed a fascination with classical music, and he dreamed of becoming a conductor, a career his father discouraged. Mr. Vilar moved to Pennsylvania to study economics at Washington and Jefferson.
After two years in the United States Army, he worked briefly for Citibank before becoming a portfolio manager for private investment firms, and in the late 60's, he earned a master's degree in economics from Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y. In the 70's, he became convinced of the economic promise of nascent computer technology companies, and since his employers did not share that enthusiasm, he and a partner started Amerindo. Thanks to his prescient stock picks -- he bought Microsoft, Cisco Systems, America Online and Yahoo when they were start-ups -- Amerindo now manages about $10 billion.
Along the way, Mr. Vilar became a billionaire. (He would not disclose his net worth.) And he adopted a jet-set existence, dividing his business time between New York and London; he thinks nothing of crossing the Atlantic to catch performances. In New York, Mr. Vilar, who is divorced, maintains a two-floor, 30-room pied-a-terre on the East Side, complete with replicas of the Met's rising chandeliers.
But he has made a point of sharing his wealth, and the arts are not his only cause. After his left arm was shattered in a skiing accident in 1996 and reconstructed at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, he donated $12 million to establish the Alberto Vilar Center for Research of the Hand and the Upper Extremity at the hospital. And besides covering the concert series at Washington and Jefferson, he paid for the school's $28 million Vilar Center for Technology, a computer-science facility. Now under negotiation are educational projects that may cost him $100 million and proposals from several hospitals. Within three years, he said, his donations to educational and health-care institutions will equal those for music.
How does he deal with all this, run a business and still have time to catch about 100 opera performances a year?
"I guess there's no question that I'm highly motivated," he said. "I have my company, which is 12 hours a day, five days a week. And how I do it is, first, I have a multimillion-dollar salaried expense for staffers who take care of my philanthropies. While I'm talking to you, there are six people around the world running up the meter doing things for me. Second, this is my life. I don't play golf. I don't go bowling. I go to performances. And third, I don't have any kiddies. These projects in music, education and health care are my kiddies. Music is my family, and it's my way to socialize."
While his musical tastes lean toward the standard repertory, he is quick to note that he has nothing against unusual opera. But he is cautious about it. Mr. Mortier, of Salzburg, once took him to see Messiaen's opera, "St. Francois d'Assise," in a vain attempt to persuade him to underwrite performances at the Lincoln Center Festival. Still, he has paid for productions outside the standard repertory, like "Doktor Faust," "War and Peace" and "Alcina." Charles Kaye, a London arts consultant who helps arrange Mr. Vilar's donations, pointed out that the Salzburg gift helped cover the new-music series as well as new opera productions.
"I will tell you, his taste is more advanced than that of most Americans," Mr. Mortier said. "He is very open-minded. He listens. He wants to discover new music and new stagings. When Robert Wilson came to New York with his production of 'Lohengrin,' Alberto was one of the few who liked it."
Because operatic philanthropy has come to occupy such a central part of his life, Mr. Vilar is irked by the biting remarks directed at him in the press. And increasingly, the kind of criticism leveled by Mr. Milnes has cropped up in the American press as well. That unsigned article in The Wall Street Journal last month echoed Mr. Milnes's worry about opera being subject to Mr. Vilar's "whim," accusing him of using his wealth to "manipulate world opera," with the Bayreuth gift as a case in point.
He has been known to flex his economic muscle. When the San Francisco Opera was searching for a general director to succeed Lotfi Mansouri next season, Mr. Vilar let it be known that he was interested in two candidates: Mr. Mortier, who is relinquishing his Salzburg post next year, and Sarah Billinghurst, the Met's assistant manager for artistic matters, whose previous job was at the San Francisco company. By his own account, Mr. Vilar told the company that "if either one of them went there, they could count on my support." When Pamela Rosenberg, the artistic director of the Stuttgart Opera in Germany, was chosen instead, he made the Los Angeles Opera his principal West Coast beneficiary.
But the fear that Mr. Vilar will make the opera world his personal plaything may be overstated. He is an enthusiast at heart and is in awe of the singers, conductors and directors who put opera on the stage.
"He doesn't interfere artistically," said Mr. Kaiser, formerly of Covent Garden. "He has never said a word to me about what we should be doing or not doing."
Mr. Vilar's own example of his hands-off policy is the Met's "Traviata." He underwrote it partly in the hope of seeing Roberto Alagna and Angela Gheorghiu in the lead roles, as originally planned. But when a dispute led Mr. Volpe to withdraw the singers' contracts, Mr. Vilar neither interceded nor threatened to withdraw his support. His laissez-faire approach stands in stark contrast to the demands made by Sybil Harrington, his predecessor as the Met's biggest contributor, who placed artistic conditions on her support.
"It's not that kind of relationship," Mr. Volpe said. "Sybil would say: 'I'll give my money if you hire this director or that director. I won't give you my money if you hire so and so." There's none of that from Alberto. He is the perfect underwriter in that sense. He doesn't come in to look at drawings. He sees the productions when everyone else does, and he's as nervous about them as everyone else is. I don't know anybody like him, and I don't mean that in a negative way."
That said, Mr. Volpe questions Mr. Vilar's theory that splashy expressions of recognition are necessary to lure new donors.
"I'm on the fence about it," said Mr. Volpe, who has been fending off suggestions from both the Met's board and its development department that donors of new productions should take curtain calls at the premieres and that their names should be included both on advertising posters and in the electronic titles.
"There are some people who give a lot of money and who don't want credit," Mr. Volpe said. "If you look back, in the last two or three decades a lot of money has come to the Met from people who do not wish to have their picture, credit and all those things. I do agree that he should get credit, that one should recognize what he is doing. And I think we have made some changes here to do that.
"But you know," he said, pushing a copy of the Kirov program, opened to the full-page tribute to Mr. Vilar, across his desk, "I don't think there's any likelihood that this is going to happen at the Met."
Would he refuse Mr. Vilar's request for a page in the program book?
"I didn't say that," he replied. "I'm saying that things take time here. So the likelihood of this happening while I'm still in this job is very low."

HEADLINE: In Evanston, Ill., a Downtown Revitalization

BYLINE: By JILL SCHACHNER CHANEN

 BODY:
AFTER languishing for more than 10 years, downtown Evanston, Ill., is experiencing a threefold increase in development this year with an estimated $200 million worth of new residential and commercial projects under way.
 Five buildings with a total of more than 350 condominium apartments have been started this year in the downtown area of this north shore Chicago suburb, which is perhaps best known as the home of Northwestern University, and two more buildings are planned. This is up sharply from 29 apartments last year and a total of 167 over the last five years, according to city officials. "Ordinarily, in a good construction season, throughout the city we will see about $70 million worth of construction, which includes residential, commercial and university," said James Wolinski, director of Evanston's Department of Building and Zoning. "This year it's $200 million." 
 Developers say the new residential development in Evanston is, in part, an outgrowth of a condominium boom in downtown Chicago, which is only 15 miles to the south. Buyers in downtown Chicago, where over 6,000 new condominium apartments have been built in the last five years, are paying upward of $275 per square foot for newly constructed condominium apartments. Evanston developers say they are taking advantage of the demand for condominium apartments and marketing their apartments to would-be city purchasers at prices that are lower by $50 to $75 per square foot. In Evanston, one-bedroom apartments are selling for an average price of $148,000, while a two-bedroom is selling for an average of $215,000.
 Also drawing buyers is the infusion of new commercial activity in downtown Evanston, including a soon-to-be-completed 18-screen movie theater, a Hilton Gardens hotel and more than 250,000 square feet of retail space, which will be anchored by a new Sears department store.
 Evanston is an ethnically diverse city that has long attracted a mix of affluent families and young single professionals because of its urban feel in a suburban setting along the shores of Lake Michigan and because of its proximity to downtown Chicago. The city's downtown, however, did not keep pace. In the mid-1980's, the Marshall Field's department store in Evanston was closed, leaving behind a smattering of small retail shops, restaurants and old office buildings. The department store's building was turned into a mixed-use development of loft apartments and retail spaces.
 Three years ago the city of Evanston set the stage for the downtown area's revitalization when it modified plans to convert a parcel of downtown land into a high-tech research park. The land was previously used as a sanitation yard and for storage facilities for the city and Northwestern University. Though four research buildings were built on the property, the city decided to use the remainder of the land for a mixed-use development to help infuse new life into the downtown. The property is now the site of the new movie theater complex, hotel and a soon-to-be-built residential high-rise building.
 WHEN they made the decision to change the research park, it was significant," said Jim Klutznick, a principal in Sherman Plaza Venture, a development partnership that plans to raze nearly an entire city block in the center of downtown and rebuild it with the 250,000 square feet of retail space that includes Sears. The project will also include an upscale 200-unit senior citizen's apartment building that will be operated by the Senior Lifestyle Corporation of Chicago. Construction of the retail space and parking lot is scheduled to being next spring and be completed by early 2002. Construction on the seniors' residence is to begin in 2002, according to Mr. Klutznick.
 Mr. Klutznick, like other developers, said that without these new commercial and retail developments, the residential projects might not have drawn as much interest.
 Thomas Roszak, a residential developer with three current projects in Evanston, agrees. "Downtown Evanston has really started to rejuvenate in the last five years with Starbucks, Barnes & Noble, brick paving on the sidewalks and new landscaping," he said. "You throw that all into the pot, and it really is a fabulous place to live."
 He recently sold every apartment in a 31-unit condominium building on Sherman Avenue at the southern tip of Evanston's downtown. The building occupies a once-vacant parcel that fronted the railroad tracks for the city's elevated train line. Prices for the units ranged from $118,000 for a 811-square-foot one-bedroom apartment to $274,000 for a 1,840-square-foot three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment, according to Mr. Roszak, principal of Roszak ADC in Chicago.
 Now Mr. Roszak is completing the construction of a 23-unit condominium apartment building on a property adjacent to his other project. All but two of those units have sales contracts, he said. Prices range from $153,000 for a 805-square-foot one-bedroom apartment to $445,000 for a 2,325-square-foot three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment.
 Later this year Mr. Roszak will begin construction on a 156-unit condominium apartment building just a couple of blocks from his other buildings. Mr. Roszak is selling these apartments in phases and, so far, 25 of the 54 units in the first phase are sold. Prices in this building range from $132,000 for a 600-square-foot studio apartment to $354,000 for a 1,625-square-foot three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment.
 This building, called Chicago Avenue Place, will also have a doorman and an indoor pool. Mr. Roszak said.
 Mr. Roszak believes that downtown Evanston is starting to lure buyers from Chicago because property is more affordable and the city now has more to offer its residents. "If you can get an apartment that is 10 percent to 15 percent less, people will make the move here because Evanston is so geographically close to Chicago," he said.
 Janis Battle, 53, a widowed empty nester, bought one of the three-bedroom apartments in Mr. Roszak's first project after debating whether to move into Chicago. Price was not an issue for her, but lifestyle was. She moved to Evanston this year from Wilmette, a neighboring suburb to the north of Evanston, after selling her single-family house there.
"I felt more comfortable living in Evanston because it had all the advantages of an urban lifestyle without all the congestion of the city," she said. "The other thing I like about living in Evanston is that it is pretty easy to develop a sense of community here. When I go into Starbucks, they know what I drink. I know the soup guy. You can get to know your neighborhood and recognize people on the street."
Ms. Battle fits the demographics of potential buyers for another new condominium apartment building that is part of a mixed-use development just blocks away from her building. Developers of the project at 515 Main Street expected to draw empty nesters from Evanston and neighboring suburbs as well as young first-time buyers looking for better values than they could find in the city of Chicago. Almost half of the buyers have come from within a five-block radius of the building, said Steven Maher, a sales agent with Garrison Partners of Chicago, which is marketing the building.
 The nine-story building will offer street level retail space anchored by a bank, indoor parking and 63 apartments spread out over the top seven floors. Prices range from $150,000 for a 900-square-foot one-bedroom apartment to $350,000 for a 1,500-square-foot three-bedroom apartment, Mr. Maher said.
 Construction is under way, with first move-ins expected in the spring. All 63 apartments in the building are sold

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Speculative Warehouses Head South on Turnpike

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

 BODY:
THE development of big boxy warehouses continues its march southward along the New Jersey Turnpike, most recently arriving at Exit 6A, where an industrial park is under way that will ultimately contain eight million square feet of space.
Construction is to start this month on two speculative warehouses, totaling 540,000 square feet, at the Haines Industrial Center. It is rising on 700 acres between the Delaware River and Route 130, one mile from the interchange, in Burlington and Florence Townships in Burlington County. 
 The planned buildings join two others, totaling 1.13 million square feet, developed at the center since it was started last October. The earlier structures have drawn National Freight and the B. J.'s Wholesale Club as tenants, according to the developer, the Whitesell Construction Company of Delran, an active commercial builder in South Jersey.
The project reflects the continuing strength of the state's industrial market, as well as efforts by Burlington County to revive the Route 130 corridor. The corridor, a thriving retail strip that has fallen on hard times, extends from Florence 16 miles south to Cinnaminson. "It is certainly key to the redevelopment of, and brings a new mix of uses to, the corridor," James K. Wujcik, director of the Burlington County Board of Freeholders, said of the project.
Officials in Florence and Burlington said they supported the development of the Haines center site but noted that it been a long time in coming. For years, the county envisioned the site as a regional food distribution center, which was never realized.
Robert A. Richards Jr. the president of Whitesell, which bought the site in 1998, said Haines Industrial Center would cost $300 million. "We expect to complete it in five years, with some luck," he said.
The Haines Industrial Center is the new kid on the warehouse distribution block in the state. It competes with the established northerly markets at Exit 8A in Middlesex County and Exit 7A in Mercer County for regional tenants seeking 300,000 square feet or more.
Such tenants will gravitate to those markets that can accommodate their size, which they need to expand or consolidate scattered operations under one roof as well as to set up central distribution hubs, said Frank V. Caccavo Jr., a senior director at the Iselin office of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services concern. His company says that there are at least six tenants with requirements of 300,000 square feet or more currently in the market.
John Horan, a senior vice president at the Laurence Harbor office of Coldwell Banker Commercial Feist & Feist, another brokerage, added, "The 6A market does not spell the end of 8A, which will continue to fill up, first because its centralized location can't be beat, particularly for tenants who want to be closer to Manhattan."
Speculative development at Exit 8A continues, as developers put up buildings to meet the demand for large modern warehouse space. Three such buildings are under way, totaling 1.6 million square feet and there are approvals in place for 2 million more square feet.
IN the last year, however, leasing activity fell to 1.1 million square feet from 2 million. Mr. Caccavo said the decrease "is due to the lack of completed new buildings in the first half of the year." He said activity would bounce back by the first quarter of next year as new buildings come on line. At the same time average asking rents rose by 15 cents, to $4.97 a square foot, a year.
In the Exit 7A market, where most buildings are being built for specific tenants, production is also brisk. For instance, at the 400-acre Northeast Business Center in Washington Township, three buildings are under way, totaling two million square feet, according to the developer, the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury, which is also among the larger developers in the Exit 8A market.
Alec Taylor, a partner at Matrix, said users were attracted by the availability of land and the dependability of approvals. Another factor, he said, is timing -- tenants want space ready when they expand or enter a market.
The question for Exit 6A, Mr. Caccavo said, is how much of a speculative market exists. Mr. Horan of Coldwell Banker Commercial added that Exit 6A "will snag its share of tenants" because of price.
Average rents at the Haines Center are $4.50 a square foot. Mr. Richards said the project offers tenants "more bang for their buck" because taxes, housing and labor costs are lower in South Jersey than in North Jersey.
In addition, he said the roads to the project make it "as accessible, if not more accessible," as an East Coast distribution hub than the more northerly interchanges. Along with the New Jersey Turnpike, where the Exit 6A interchange opened last year and connects to the Pennsylvania Turnpike, the site is accessible to Interstates 95 and 295 as well as Route 130.
Moreover, Mr. Richards said, it is also served by a freight train and is along the path of the 34-mile commuter light rail line from Trenton to Camden, now under way. A station is planned within the center. The $604 million light rail project, financed with state money, is to be completed by early 2003.
Those transportation links were not always at the Haines site, which sat dormant for nearly two decades. In the 80's, the state selected it for a regional food distribution center meant to spur economic growth in South Jersey.
Though the state abandoned the plan in 1990, the county pursued it. Under the plan, the county, using public money, would have bought the site, developed the infrastructure and attracted developers to acquire parcels within the center. But the county never finally acquired the site, which Whitesell ultimately bought for $12.5 million.
Mr. Wujcik, the freeholder director, said the county supported Whitesell's purchase because attracting a private developer was the ultimate aim. The current project, he added, is expected to generate the same amount of tax revenue as the food distribution center, which was projected at $7 million a year.
The mayor of Burlington, Joseph Foy, and the mayor of Florence, Michael Muchowski, said the project would help stabilize taxes in their communities.
It is also proceeding as other sites along Route 130 gain new life. An example is the renovation and expansion of one of 13 shuttered buildings that make up the former Willingboro Plaza, a 514,000-square-foot retail strip that fell into decline in the last decade.
The 160,000-square-foot building will be refurbished and expanded by 100,000 square feet for reuse as an automated mail-service pharmacy for Merck-Medco Managed Care of Franklin Lakes, a subsidiary of Merck & Company. It is the first phase of the redevelopment of the former mall into a mixed-use development, with up to 1.2 million square feet.
The 700 acres where the Haines Industrial Center is taking shape is the only site along the corridor for new development. Mr. Richards of Whitesell said knowing the turnpike exit and the light rail were realities influenced his company's decision to buy the site.
The company also owns adjacent land where it built 560,000 square feet of industrial space. "This is another step," he said of the current project.
The first two buildings have attracted tenants relocating from areas farther south. One building, with 504,000 square feet, was started on speculation last year and has been leased to National Freight of Vineland. The second building, with 603,000 square feet, is being built for B. J.'s Wholesale Club, based in Natick, Mass., which is expanding from a 300,000-square-foot warehouse in Bristol, Pa.
Ray Sareeram, senior vice president of logistics at B. J.'s, said his company had settled on the Exit 6A site after an 18-month search that included looking in the Exit 8A and Exit 7A markets. "Our president, Jack Nugent, gave a strong directive, 'find the best available location that would enable us to preserve our work force,' " Mr. Sareeram said. In relocating to the Haines Center, he said, he expects to retain all 200 current employees. The company, which will eventually double that work force, will occupy the building by March 2001.
Mr. Richards said the center "is still in its infancy." But, he added, with the next two buildings "the center could begin to take on a life of its own."

HEADLINE: Student Leaders Take Place on State Board

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS

 BODY:
TWO high school seniors have taken their seats this year on the 11-member state Board of Education. Jennifer Santiago, who attends Wilbur Cross High School in New Haven, and David Agrawal, a student at Rockville High School in Vernon, can't vote, but they are privy to the workings of the governmental body.
"I think it's an honor to sit down with people who have a say over Connecticut schools," Ms. Santiago said. 
 This is the third year that students have been appointed to one-year terms on the board. They join adult members who serve four-year terms. The arrangement was initiated by a student on the 30-member Student Advisory Council to the state board, who had heard about a movement around the country to appoint students to state and local boards of education. He met with state Senator Kevin B. Sullivan, a Democrat from West Hartford, and got the support of the Student Advisory Council for a bill to create student representation at the state level. It passed in the General Assembly in 1998.
"There was some discussion and debate about voting rights," said Thomas Murphy, a spokesman for the state Board of Education. He said the decision to bar students from voting stemmed from the nature of some of the board's responsibilities -- such as budget and policy decisions that could subject members to lobbying by interest groups; and discussing and voting on personnel matters that could result in litigation, such as revocation of teacher certifications.
Mr. Murphy added that some members of the Student Advisory Council felt they already represented fellow students on policy issues, and were worried that selecting only two students to sit on the board would decrease, not increase, student influence. He said the group met with Gov. John G. Rowland and the commissioner of education, Theodore Sergi; they agreed that the council would have a key role in choosing the student representatives and would advise them once they took office. It would also continue its direct advisory role to government leaders. Mr. Murphy said the group has discussed issues of critical interest to students, such as segregation and diversity, harassment, homework policies, student citizenship and responsibilities, and school violence and security.
School principals nominate students for the Student Advisory Council, and the education commissioner appoints the members. By law, the council must be balanced by gender, race, ethnicity and economic status. Created more than a decade ago, it must include students from each Congressional district in the state and students with disabilities.
Students who would like to serve on the state board apply to the Student Advisory Council, which conducts interviews and recommends five finalists; the governor selects two. The law states that two students be appointed, with no other specifications. Even without a mandate, in each of the past three years one male and one female have been appointed, from a broad geographic mix representing urban, suburban and rural districts and ethnic diversity that has included whites, Asian-Americans and Hispanics.
Eleven states have student representatives to their boards of education, according to David Kysilko, publication director of the National Association of State Boards of Education. In California, Maryland, Massachusetts and Vermont, the student members vote. The trend to include student representatives began a dozen years ago, Mr. Kysilko said, adding that the number of states to do so is growing slowly. His organization supports such efforts, because the response has been so positive from students and adult board members, he said.
At the first regular board meeting Ms. Santiago and Mr. Agrawal attended, on Sept. 13, one of the topics was proposed changes to the Connecticut Mastery Test. Ms. Santiago said the meeting was "very organized but kind of overwhelming." She said some people spoke in favor of emphasizing grammar more on the state tests, while others opposed that change for fear of curtailing students' creativity. The board is expected to vote on any changes in the Mastery Test at its next meeting.
Ms. Santiago said she just listened at her first meeting without expressing her own opinions. She said at first she didn't feel comfortable, because it was a new setting, "and I didn't know how accepting other board members would be about our opinions." She felt more comfortable by the meeting's end, she added.
As for the student representatives' lack of voting privileges, she said: "I think it doesn't matter that we can't vote. Some issues are so complicated, like teacher certification, we are probably better off not voting."
Marcel LaFlamme disagrees. He was the student representative last year to the Massachusetts Board of Education, where he enjoyed full voting rights -- which he said were critical to his equal participation on the board.
In 1974, the Massachusetts legislature established a statewide Student Advisory Council, with the chair of that group serving as a voting member of the State Board.
"There is only one student member on the Board each year, although the extensive network of state and regional Student Advisory Councils provides ample opportunity for the chair to consult with other student leaders," said Mr. LaFlamme, who is now a freshman at Harvard.
He doesn't think much of the Connecticut arrangement, which he said lacks respect for students' abilities to understand complicated matters. As for the concern about lawsuits, Mr. LaFlamme said that, as a member of the 1999-2000 Massachusetts Board of Education, "I am in fact being sued by teachers' unions on the basis of statewide exit exams and diagnostic content exams for teachers whose students have low math scores. Doesn't bother me. I'm proud to stand up with my colleagues for important, difficult decisions we made."
Having students on the board has been good for everyone , according to government officials and the students themselves.
"For the young people it's a great honor," Mr. Murphy said. "In schools, we separate people by age, and here we have a real-world experience where students interact with adults around issues that affect their world. The students develop study skills -- from all the material they have to read -- and debating skills."
He considers the teenagers who have served "brilliant. They're articulate and bring a lot to the table." He added that of the first four representatives, two went on to Harvard, one to Yale and one to Trinity College.
As for the adults on the board, Mr. Murphy said, "They've been inspired by the success of the students. Many times you focus only on the problems in public education. This gave them a chance to renew their faith that public education is working. They also felt a better connection to the classroom and the impact their policies have on students."
Mr. Agrawal said he has found adults on the local and state boards to be "good at listening to other people's opinions, even if they don't agree with them."
Ms. Santiago plans to major in criminal justice and political science in college and hopes to be a lawyer. Mr. Agrawal said he plans to go into law or government service. They both have goals for their tenure on the board.
Ms. Santiago said, "I hope to focus on closing gaps between students, helping lower-level students move up to a higher level and promoting more interaction between different groups of students."
Mr. Agrawal previously served on his town's board of education, where he said he learned about educational policy and procedure. He said on the state board he would like to focus on "maximizing student opportunity through smaller classes, technology, more challenging courses and more electives."

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: 35 Three-Family Town Houses in Melrose Commons;
New Homes for South Bronx

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI

 BODY:
On a vast, mostly vacant and formerly rubble-strewn expanse of the South Bronx, 35 three-family town houses, their two-tone facades set back behind modest gates and greenery, have been snatched up by eager buyers.
Franklin Delano Roosevelt apparently would have been pleased. 
 "It's been a long struggle within the urban renewal area called Melrose Commons," said Yolanda Garcia, director of Nos Quedamos (We Stay), a community group that has fought to retain residents in the 35-block area between East 156th Street, East 163rd Street, Brook and Park Avenues.
"It's 65 percent vacant, and it hasn't been looked after since F.D.R. came here in 1936 and made a grand speech about urban renewal," Ms. Garcia said. "Nothing happened." Until now. "This is the first project in the ground," Ms. Garcia said.
The 35 three-family homes, on Elton Avenue between 156th and 159th Streets, are called Plaza de Los Angeles. They were constructed with subsidies under the Partnership New Homes Program, a public-private initiative of the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development and the New York City Housing Partnership, with further support from the New York State Affordable Housing Corporation and the Bronx borough president's office.
Thirty-one of the homes have gone to contract, with 17 of those already closed, "and more than enough people who want the other four," Ms. Garcia said. The average price was $320,000; government subsidies provided $94,000, and the buyers paid the rest. Buyers had to have annual household incomes between $32,000 and $70,950.
Carol Abrams, a spokeswoman for the housing department, said each home has an owner's duplex and two rental units. "The owner's apartment has three bedrooms and two full baths," she said. "There is a one-bedroom rental on the second floor and a two-bedroom rental on the third floor," with buyers allowed to charge market-rate rents. Each home has a yard and parking in the rear.
Magnus Magnusson of the architectural firm Larsen Shein Ginsberg + Magnusson, which designed the houses, said: "It's common to see Partnership homes where the buildings are set back 25 feet to allow a car to park in front. We felt the street should be given to people, so we placed the cars in the back -- more like traditional New York town houses." The facades, he said, are part brick, part cast stone, "and the combination creates a lively front, so it's not monotonous."
Ms. Garcia said: "We ran workshops here on how people really want to live. You look at the houses and they accent everything we spoke about: light, air, quality design, color palate, trees."
One feature, aimed particularly at two-income families, she said, is country kitchens with large open counters, "so when the mother comes home from work she can keep an eye on the children, help with homework, while cooking the meal."
Other bright spots are envisioned for Melrose Commons. "The next project is already a hole in the ground for La Puerta de Vitalidad, a 61-unit apartment building on Third Avenue at East 158th Street," Ms. Garcia said. And 33 more three-family homes, a block from Plaza de Los Angeles, are on the drawing board. DENNIS HEVESI

HEADLINE: Philanthropist Rescues Center for the Poor

BYLINE: By ALLAN RICHTER

 BODY:
THE Hagedorn Family Resource Center in Hempstead has classrooms on each of its three floors, but no room symbolizes its far-reaching ambitions quite like the unfinished kitchen at the new facility for needy families and children.
The kitchen would not only serve meals to the 145 youngsters who would eventually fill the center's day-care and after-school programs, it would serve as a training ground for disenfranchised teens looking for careers as chefs. Parents dropping off their children in the morning could order dinners that they could pick up in the afternoon, said Carol Keepler, the center's director, to help them spend more "quality time" at home with their children instead of preparing meals. 
 "It will be everything for everybody," Ms. Keepler said of the center.
That is a lofty goal for any social services agency in Nassau County these days, with another round of cuts looming because of the county's fiscal crisis. But the Hagedorn center's chief benefactor is neither County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta nor the county Legislature nor the state financial monitors who rejected Mr. Gulotta's 2001 budget and four-year financial plan last week.
Instead, the Family and Children's Association, the county's largest human services agency, is expanding its services at the Hagedorn center through the facility's namesake, Horace Hagedorn, the octogenarian founder of the plant food company Miracle-Gro who pumped $1 million into the resuscitation of the former Catholic school.
"I'm 85 years old," said Mr. Hagedorn, who lives in Port Washington, where he founded his company 52 years ago. "I'm a little impatient and I can't wait 20 years. I like to do things where I can see the results."
In the center's parking lot, a 42-foot mobile pediatric medical office built atop a bus chassis began dispensing free care to low-income patients last month. It was partly funded with a $1 million donation from Sanjay Kumar, the chief executive of Computer Associates, the Islandia software giant, and his wife, Sylvia.
Increasingly, human services agencies that have endured cutbacks are relying on philanthropy and other help from the private sector to fill gaps. Charity events that were once the fundraising specialty of only the largest organizations are now being run by virtually every agency, said Richard Dina, chief executive of the Family and Children's Association, based in Mineola.
"It plays a major role in the future of any nonprofit," Mr. Dina said of the private contributions. "What's very clear to us is that the old dependence on government for all of your funding to do good work in the community is being broken, and the only way a nonprofit can serve is to look for other sources of revenue."
But human service officials are wary of signaling to the county or the state-appointed Nassau Interim Finance Authority that the private sector can carry the agencies and their programs very far.
Jack O'Connell, chief executive of the Health and Welfare Council of Long Island, an association of social services providers, said he was pessimistic about the the pressure that the state board could exert on the county to enact further cuts to social services. The board ordered the county to fill deficits that could reach $81 million next year.
"The only way you can look at private philanthropy is that it can pay for certain programs," Mr. O'Connell said. "But what they're eliminating at the county level, what Gulotta's proposing is a $20 million elimination. That's going to be impossible to make up. The cuts are too big."
Paul Engelhart, chief program officer at Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Rockville Centre, said it would be difficult for his agency to top the private-sector fundraising that already accounts for $4 million, or 17 percent, of the agency's $24 million budget.
"There are limits to what we can do over and above the commitment that the church and other individuals have already made," he said. Under this year's budget, Catholic Charities lost $214,000 to provide mental health services, representing about half of its government funding for the services.
The Family and Children's Association lost $1.2 million in the same round of cuts, Mr. Dina said. As a result, it closed an East Meadow substance abuse outpatient clinic, a Roosevelt youth program and a summer camp for learning-disabled children and scaled back 15 of its 50 programs.
The $1 million contributed by Mr. Hagedorn is earmarked for the new Hempstead center, and the other programs will not be revived. But Mr. Dina said the Family and Children's Association was garnering savings by consolidating and expanding programs in the center, which is quickly becoming a magnet for other public services in the village.
Ginny Hubert, development director for the Hempstead school district, said the community was "now able to refer families who might be in crisis to a one-stop shopping center for every possible service that has to do with families: youth services, chemical dependency services, anything that impacts the success of our students. That's a godsend because we have a lot of students in crisis in Hempstead."
The Hempstead school district also wants to expand its pre-K program, which lasts until 11:30 in its own schools, into a full-day program at the Hagedorn center with physical education and computer literacy enrichment programs that children do not receive, she said.
Mr. Dina said he hoped the center would fulfill its original premise as a means to take more parents, particularly single mothers, off the welfare rolls by providing day care while they train for jobs or study English as a Second Language. A few mothers are involved in the program in its early stages, while it is still running at only a half day.
Caroline Russell, 34, of Valley Stream, smiled as she watched her 2-year-old daughter, Winter, play with a toy kitchen set at the Hagedorn center last week. Mrs. Russell said it was the first day care the child had ever received.
"I took care of my daughter alone," Mrs. Russell said. "I made it to the park when I could and had a girlfriend who used to take her out when I wasn't feeling well. But she moved away. Then everything kind of broke up. My marriage situation fell apart..
"This," she said, "gives me that push: 'Get yourself in school. Get yourself focused.' " She said she wants to be a nurse.
As the agency awaits state and county approvals, some public funding is beginning to trickle in. Vincent Neefus, who heads the Hempstead Police Department's community outreach unit, said the police unit received a $45,000 grant last month from the state Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse for programs at the Hagedorn center.
Programs there would include after-school tutoring and classes in self-esteem, peer pressure and anti-gang awareness, Lt. Neefus said, and would help balance the sports-focused Police Athletic League programs in which youths at risk of joining gangs participate.
The mobile pediatrics unit is an extension of the one-stop shopping idea. The Family and Children's Association has an agreement with the North Shore-Long Island Jewish Health System, which is managing the unit, to park the bus at the Hagedorn center four days a week, said James Fagin, medical director of the unit and chief of general pediatrics at North Shore University Hospital.
"We would like to provide continuity of care," Dr. Fagin said. "The idea is not to deliver sporadic care, but to establish a medical home for the kids in these communities that never closes. Our intention is to stay at a site, and if it's very successful, ultimately we would like to establish a fixed site there inside the building or nearby and then move the bus onto another site and do the same thing."
Shalesha Ross, 25, applauded the attention as she sat in the medical bus last week. "This is a walk-in; at the H.I.P. center you have to make an appointment," she said. "I like this better. They take more time to explain what's going on with your children." Ms. Ross, who is unemployed, watched her daughter, India, cradle a toy kangaroo given by the bus staff and wipe away tears let loose by an inoculation.

HEADLINE: Q & A/Patricia Lucan;
Mutual Respect: Teachers and Board

BYLINE: By MELINDA TUHUS

 BODY:
ON July 1, Patricia Lucan took office as president of the 1,650-member New Haven Federation of Teachers. Ms. Lucan, a 53-year-old native of New Haven who now lives in Hamden, began teaching in 1969 and (with nine years off to raise her own children) has spent her entire career as a language teacher in New Haven public schools, at Lee High School and at Sheridan Academy middle school.
Ms. Lucan has a master's degree and a sixth-year administrative degree from Southern Connecticut State University. 
 At a welcome-back event for teachers in August sponsored by the New Haven superintendent, Reginald Mayo, Ms. Lucan was outspoken in demanding more respect for teachers, but also in admonishing them not to "whine and moan." She called for reinstatement of family health benefits for new teachers, urged administrators, including herself, to get back into the classroom, and promoted better school nutrition.
Following are excerpts from an interview conducted last month in Ms. Lucan's union office. She is a small woman, her dark hair pulled back in a no-nonsense style, who tended to whip her glasses on and off as she spoke -- a habit that resulted in flying spectacles, she said, on many occasions in the classroom.
Q. In your welcome-back address, you seemed intent on giving teachers and administrators notice that you're in charge of the union now. What kind of relationship would you like to have with Superintendent Mayo and the Board of Education?
A. One of mutual respect, and that means what those words say. I respect the position they are in. It's a difficult task to run any kind of a system, but I think people on top lose touch with what's going on at the ground level. What would be wrong with one day a week helping out in the classroom?
Q. Do you have a proposal for administrators working in the classroom?
A. I don't have a specific plan, but since we have 10 schools that did poorly on a state survey, those schools could really benefit by lowering class size with more teachers in the classroom. It would help with the teacher-shortage problem. But I'm not going to do it alone, and I doubt that any administrators agree with me. I hope something will come from my talking about it. It's like a wake-up call. I didn't say anything original but I said it publicly as a union president.
Q. In what ways do you think administrators don't respect teachers?
A. I have never seen it be effective, whether in teaching or something else, to overpower someone, to make them feel harassed or threatened. I'm going to follow up on every complaint a teacher makes. But the teachers are not always right; that's why I told them to stop whining and moaning.
Q. Education is one of the top issues in this year's presidential campaign. What is your opinion of their focus?
A. Politicians talk a good game about education, but when it comes down to getting in the trenches and getting kids to learn, it's not the top-funded priority. I hate to say money would fix all our problems with education, but money would help.
Q. What are some of the important economic issues for the union?
A. Many teachers in New Haven are being bought out, going to other towns with better pay and benefits. Taxpayers don't realize we are not on a par with other professionals who have even less education. New Haven is going to have to offer more money.
We have to lower the steps in the contract it takes to get to maximum and give more of an increase each year. And 35 years is too long to be in any job before retiring with full benefits, especially one as stressful as teaching.
Police and firefighters can retire with full benefits after 25 years, and teaching is at least as stressful as that. Now teachers who retire after 25 years get only a quarter of the average of their three highest-paid years. That's a quarter of $69,262. We have to get it down to 30 years, but that means changing a state regulation.
Q. How can you change the state regulation regarding retirement benefits?
A. We need to be very political. We need to lobby. We need to be part of a labor movement. We have to be more vocal about what we want and don't want.
Q. You've taken a high-profile position on school nutrition. Why do you think that's so important?
A. We worry about how our cars run, what kind of fuel we put in them, but what about our children? We could educate families on how to feed their kids better, but when they are at school we can do a better job ourselves. People say the kids won't eat healthier food -- let them go hungry until they do. There are foods that could be cut down in fat. We have kids who are grossly overweight, we have childhood diabetes, we have asthma.
We are setting ourselves up for long-term health problems. We teach them science, we teach them health, but then we don't practice it. It's hypocrisy. Kids who qualify for the reduced price lunch program then spend two or three or four dollars a day on junk. Then they get hyperactive and there are discipline problems and the blame falls on the teachers.
As president of the union, I don't want to see that. We privatized the food service a few years ago. I have no problem with that, but if you don't introduce junk to make money then the children won't buy junk.
Q. You organized to get more nutritious food at Sheridan. How did you do it?
A. We got the school nurses and some pediatricians involved. I bought one of every kind of junk food available at the school and put it all in a big box, and the school nurse took it to her supervisor, who's a physician. That made quite an impression.
A few weeks later the food service company sent a letter home saying the food would be more nutritious at Sheridan. If they can do it at Sheridan, why not at all the schools? I'll keep saying it at board meetings: remember nutrition.
Q. You have been very critical of the current union contract that excludes family health coverage for new teachers until they get tenure after four years. What can you do about it?
A. I think it's insulting that that would have been offered as a bargaining chip. It's like saying new teachers are not worth keeping in the system. This city is self-insured. I'd bet it would cost about $350,000 to give new teachers family health benefits. The mayor could do it. But he wants us to give something back, and I'm not giving anything back unless my executive board tells me to.
We already gave back a lot in the last contract, which included a wage freeze. The new contract created more steps to reach the maximum. It kept starting pay the same for four years. I was not involved in the negotiation and I'm not going to second-guess those who were. I just want to say not enough money was provided for an equitable contract.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
In Defense Of Columbus

BYLINE: By MARY ANN CASTRONOVO FUSCO

DATELINE: SOUTH ORANGE

 BODY:
THROUGHOUT time, treasure has typically been measured in trinkets and pennyweights, coins and carats. But to William J. Connell, a historian at Seton Hall University, "there's nothing more precious than a hard fact."
"The more you look for them," Mr. Connell says, "the more you see how many interpretations there are." Lately, the 42-year-old scholar has taken to weighing the facts about Columbus, who at 41 became the most famous treasure-seeker of all time. 
 The fact that the Genoese explorer was preceded by the Vikings no longer fires up a debate. Arguments over Columbus's ethnic origins -- various groups claim him as Italian, Spanish, Greek, and Jewish -- are as old and usually as good-natured as the celebration of Columbus Day itself.
But one controversy that has tarnished the seafarer's reputation persists, periodically fanned by prevailing political winds. Though many maintain that Columbus was a noble-minded visionary who opened up a new land of opportunity for the oppressed masses of Europe, others see him as a greedy imperialist who slaughtered and spread disease among the indigenous people and institutionalized the slave trade.
"On the one hand, we have people desperate to make him theirs," Mr. Connell said with a chuckle during a recent interview in his campus office, "and on the other hand, we have people who are trying to erase him from history."
Though Mr. Connell briefly flirted with a career in banking after graduating summa cum laude with distinction in history from Yale University, he made his life's work documenting facts, specifically those of the Renaissance. After earning a doctorate at the University of California at Berkeley, he taught history at Reed College in Portland, Ore., then at Rutgers.
In 1998 he became the first professor to hold the La Motta Chair in Italian studies at Seton Hall, where he is usually preoccupied with the Italian humanists and the political and economic strife of Italian city-states.
Mr. Connell, who was raised by parents of Irish, German, and Welsh descent in the Bronx and Westchester, has so enthusiastically embraced Italian culture that he reads fairy tales in Italian to his 16-month-old daughter, Zoe, at the Clinton home he shares with his wife, Nikki Shepardson, who teaches history at Rider University. His first book, La citta dei crucci (City of Sorrows), about a feud that destroyed the Tuscan city of Pistoia at the time of the Medici, was written in Italian and will be published next month in Florence.
And as a Renaissance man, Columbus fell within his area of expertise. Last year, Mr. Connell spoke on Columbus and the meaning of Columbus Day before both public school students in Elizabeth and the West Orange Rotary Club. This year, he will address the Columbus Day Dinner Dance in Hanover, sponsored by District 11 of UNICO, an Italian-American civic organization that spearheaded the campaign to endow the chair in Italian studies at Seton Hall.
"Certainly we don't want to downplay the tragedies that happened," said John Sebastiano, president of the Montville chapter of UNICO. "But for a lot of individuals, the symbolism of Christopher Columbus was that of a voyage of freedom. It really was the start of the globalization of our world."
As Mr. Connell noted, "When history is made in this kind of fundamental way, there are also costs."
The arrival of Dutch, Swedish and English to New Jersey in the 17th century, for example, led to smallpox and measles epidemics among the native Lenape communities, which had no resistance to Old World diseases. Although the Lenape, also known as the Delaware, were the first tribe to sign a treaty with the newly formed American government in 1778, most were pushed West and to this day live in Bartlesville, Okla.
Some Indians have urged that Columbus Day -- first celebrated in New York in 1792, the 300th anniversary of Columbus's arrival -- be rescinded as a holiday in their states. One hundred years later, Congress designated Columbus Day a national holiday to be celebrated each Oct. 12. And in 1971 Columbus Day became a federal holiday observed on the second Monday of October.
Throughout the years, Italian-American, Hispanic, and other groups have embraced the holiday as a occasion to celebrate their ethnic heritage, though some Indian groups prefer to refer to the day as "Indigenous Peoples Day."
Dee Ketchum, chief of the Delawares, said his tribe "recognizes various holiday events in North America and allows paid time off to its tribal employees, but Columbus Day is not one of them."
Other tribes are more vocal in their opposition. "We believe that Columbus came and conquered," Mark (Quiet Hawk) Gould, tribal chairman of the Nanticoke Lenni-Lenape Indians, said in a telephone interview, "We really think that it was like a genocide."
Roy Crazy Horse, chairman of the New Jersey Commission on American Indian Affairs and chief of the Powhatan Renape Nation, based at the Rankokus Indian Reservation in Westhampton Township, put it this way: "Why celebrate a man who started looking for India and landed in the Caribbean, who never put down his foot in the United States, who brought slavery to this continent?" Neither American Indian leader, however, is involved in protesting the holiday. Instead, they say they concentrate on educational programs.
The controversy over Columbus Day doesn't bother Mr. Connell, who said: "The whole discussion around Columbus Day has been useful to the extent that it has reminded us of many of the tragic consequences of the contact."
And he doesn't believe the holiday should be replaced with a celebration of ethnic diversity, which "sounds like a hodgepodge."
"We have ethnic diversity anyway; we celebrate it every day," Mr. Connell said. "It's one of the best things about this country."
As for doing away with the holiday, he said, "I don't think that it should go to the point of taking away from the tremendous achievement of Columbus."
Though modern textbooks no longer state that Columbus discovered the New World, his arrival marks "where we as a country and as a hemisphere began our identity," said Mr. Connell. "It's a question of the contact that matters. There wasn't a significant or important tradition that survived from the voyages of the Vikings."
On the other hand, he noted, Columbus's contact with the New World had a profound effect, largely because of the time -- an era when Europe was still reeling from the psychological effects of the Black Death of 1348, fierce competition among the various monarchs and the newly invented printing press, which enabled accounts of Columbus's findings to spread rapidly.
"Columbus strikes me as a person of his time," said Mr. Connell. "He was eager to push the envelope to go farther, to take the skills and the learning of the Renaissance in order to do something glorious."
As a man of the Renaissance, Columbus operated under a set of assumptions that "sound terrible to modern ears," Mr. Connell allowed. "He justified slavery in the Caribbean as being a way of bringing people into the Christian faith."
But the European concept of slavery was rooted in the Aristotelian concept that "if a person is captured in war, they're legitimately a slave," he explained. "There was nothing racial about it."
Moreover, widely spread accounts that Columbus's followers wiped out the Taino people of the Caribbean were inaccurate, says Jorge Estevez, himself of Taino lineage, who is a program coordinator at the National Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan. Mr. Estevez says that although many natives were murdered, fell victim to European diseases, or were taken captive, others intermingled with the Spanish settlers. And the settlers who were given Tainos as slaves were required to pay taxes on them, resulting in the undercounting of the Tainos as a form of tax evasion and leading to reports of their eradication.
"Columbus didn't start slavery," said Mr. Connell. "He brought the entrepreneurial form of slavery to the New World. It was a phenomenon of the times. With all great figures of the past, we need more understanding, critical understanding that sees the person's flaws and the inaccuracies and myths that have arisen around him, but we shouldn't forget the tremendous changes that they created."
The scholar went on: "I think we have to be very careful about applying 20th-century understandings of morality to the morality of the 15th century."
That said, Mr. Connell does not consider himself an apologist for Columbus. 'I'm just doing my job as a historian," he said. " 'Celebrate' is a word we could use for Columbus's genius, his persistence against the odds in getting people who were much more powerful than he was to back him in a risky enterprise that had results way beyond anyone's imagination. We can celebrate his enterprise and ingenuity. A more appropriate word for what happened would be 'commemorate.' "

LENGTH: 1073 words

HEADLINE: THE CITIES;
Is Jersey City Too Alluring?

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, the word blighted aptly described the Jersey City waterfront.
To lure developers to the crumbling west bank of the Hudson River, Jersey City took advantage of the state's tax abatement law, and since the 1980's, more than 30 buildings have been completed or are under construction, including over two dozen high-rise offices and apartments, two hotels and a mall. 
 Today, the New Jersey waterfront is increasingly attractive to businesses and residents who want to be near Manhattan -- but not in it -- because of its exorbitance.
As a result, a growing chorus of critics say there is no longer a need to be as generous. Abatements have become so common that Secaucus, North Bergen and Bayonne are suing Jersey City, claiming they have to make up for more than $4 million in Hudson County taxes that otherwise would have come from properties that have benefitted from this city's abatements. In addition, many homeowners here are fed up with the abatements, which they feel they are subsidizing with their property taxes.
Spurred by such criticism, Mayor Bret Schundler has recently begun taking steps that he says will open the process by which abatements are granted.
Apart from New Jersey's relatively low corporate taxes, labor costs lower than those across the river, swaths of vacant land and properties ready to be knocked down and rebuilt, what has also fueled the current boom is a diminishing supply of office space in New York City. Developers, corporate executives and city officials there say the shortage has challenged New York's ability to attract new businesses and stanch the flow of dozens of others -- including some of the leading investment houses -- across the Hudson.
Against this backdrop, abatements continue unabated.
"There's nothing left in Manhattan," said Mia Scanga, one of 40 homeowners here seeking a referendum to rescind an abatement recently granted to the 43-story Millennium Towers apartment planned at the base of the Palisades. "And we're giving out tax abatements."
Last Tuesday, the group gave City Clerk Robert Byrne a petition with 3,343 signatures -- about 800 more than the number required to hold a referendum.
"The minute they heard abatement they signed," said Robert Duval, vice president of the Sergeant Anthony Neighborhood Association, a member of the coalition.
Mr. Byrne said that if the petition was certified, the referendum would be the first ever held to repeal an ordinance in the 40-year history of the city's present form of government.
Currently, there are 89 properties here receiving tax abatements, making payments in lieu of taxes that total $48 million in revenue for the fiscal year 2001, up from $17 million in 1992, said Tom Gallagher, chief of staff to Mayor Schundler.
Were the abatements not in place, the revenue generated for the same properties in fiscal 2001 would amount to close to $100 million. Of course, proponents of the abatements argue that without the inducements, the properties would not have been developed.
A common perception is that abatements are mainly granted to waterfront office towers, and indeed, the number of those has grown to 19 from 11 in 1992. Moreover, office abatements generally involve the most money -- and the biggest savings for the recipient. But by far the most common type of abatement is for affordable housing projects, which account for 39 of the 89 abatements, Mr. Gallagher said.
Despite the rising revenue, critics have complained that while abatements need the approval of the City Council, they are only presented to the full council after terms are negotiated privately by developers and members of the Schundler administration.
City Councilman Robert Cavanaugh, who plans to run for mayor next year, said that he is not against abatements per se, but "when you have the hottest economic development area in the country, you've done what the original legislation intended to do."
Whether the proposed procedure will be approved by the nine-member council is unclear. Council President Tom DeGise, a probable mayoral opponent of Mr. Cavanaugh in the spring, said he opposes the change because it would weaken the council's role.
Critics of the waterfront abatements are not limited to political opponents of Mr. Schundler, who plans to enter the Republican race for governor.
Donald Eisen, exective managing director for New Jersey operations of Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate consulting firm, said that although the abatements had been "very, very helpful" in attracting developers, "it's been such a long time that these abatements have not been necessary."
The increased demand for waterfront office space is reflected in several indicators. For example, in the market that includes the Jersey City, Hoboken and Weehawken waterfronts, last week there was only 10,500 square feet of vacant prime office out of an inventory of more than 9 million square feet, said Mark Field of Cushman and Wakefield.
In the same market, which is dominated by Jersey City, the current amount of total office space, which includes prime space and less desirable properties, is 12.3 million square feet -- with another 3 million square feet expected to be added within about a year -- as against 9.26 million in 1991, Mr. Field said. During that same period, he added, office rents have increased 40 percent, to about $35 a square foot from $25.
Mr. Gallagher said in an interview that the administration had toughened its negotiating stance with developers seeking tax abatements in response to the changing market. He cited a new policy limiting the life of an abatement for residential property to 20 years, down from the previous 30 years.
The Schundler administration has recently begun drafting a plan to revise the abatement process, Mr. Gallagher said.
Essentially, he said, the plan would create a committee made up of two council members -- including Mr. Cavanaugh -- representatives of the tax collector, the tax assessor and the business administrator's office, the city Department of Housing and Economic Development, the Law Department, the Office of Economic Opportunity, and a member of the public.
The committee would hold public meetings during which it would question developers and discuss terms of the abatement before making a recommendation to the mayor. If the mayor accepted the arrangement, he would submit it to the full council for approval.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Ever the Foe of Market Guesswork

BYLINE: By RICHARD TEITELBAUM

 BODY:
INVESTORS in index funds should circle Dec. 31 on their calendars.
That date will be the 25th anniversary of the incorporation of John C. Bogle's grand invention, the First Index Investment Trust, today known as the Vanguard 500 Index, the largest stock mutual fund in the United States. And the pioneering fund company that Mr. Bogle founded, the Vanguard Group, has grown apace, with some $575.5 billion in assets under management at quarter's end. 
 And Mr. Bogle himself? Nearly five years after a heart transplant, the wiry, irascible evangelist of common-sense investing keeps quite busy writing, researching and giving speeches. He gave up most of his day-to-day responsibilities at Vanguard last year and now, at 71, he presides over his own organization, the Bogle Financial Markets Research Center. In an interview, he spoke of some abiding concerns, especially indexing and the hyperventilating market, and shared thoughts about his latest projects. RICHARD TEITELBAUM
 
Q. Though it has gained wide acceptance, indexing as a fund strategy still comes in for criticism -- that indexes like the Standard & Poor's 500 are too narrowly focused on large caps, for example. Do the critics have a point?
 
A. I'm not bothered with the S.& P. 500. The S.& P. 500 represents 75 percent of the market, and in the long run I would be flabbergasted if it didn't have the same return as the Wilshire 5000 Total Market index, because of the reversion to the mean -- large caps do better for a while and then small caps do better. Returns have been identical.
 
Q. What is the right question to be asking about indexing?
 
A. "Do we have the right indexes?" You don't need to structure an index so that it throws out a stock when it gets too big. So we're thinking about whether there are better ways to index.
 
Q. You don't see yourself as a market forecaster, but you do make forecasts. How do you approach the task?
 
A. I believe profoundly that earnings and dividends are the only long-term, long-term determinants of stock prices. P/E is a short-term, speculative determinant, although there may be a little upward bias as our economy has gotten more stable. What I do is challenge investors to say: "Don't tell me what the market return will be. Tell me what you think the fundamental return will be, and then we'll guess together at what the speculative return will be." That makes thinking about the market a rational exercise, rather than just a guessing exercise.
 
Q. Seen that way, where is the market headed?
 
A. Earnings are growing 8 percent, more or less, and the dividend yield is a little over 1 percent. That gives you a fundamental return of a little over 9 percent. The market P/E is 30, and if it reverts to the mean I'd say it's likely to be about 20, leaving an investment return of about 5 percent going forward.
Of course, the market never returns the same two years in a row, so it is more likely that you'll see a period of significant decline, and then higher growth rates from then on.
 
Q. You gave up your seats on the boards of Vanguard's funds nearly a year ago. Do you miss that part of the business?
 
A. No, I'm having the time of my life. I talk about the differences between relinquishing your intellectual and moral power, which I couldn't possibly relinquish such as they may be, and relinquishing your power over the person -- your power to manipulate people and things of that nature. I don't miss those kinds of power at all. I'm doing what I want to do, and I'm hoping that with the five extra years of life that the Lord has given me, I'm still doing things for shareholders.
