HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
A New Fund Banks on Technology

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
Talk about fast out of the gate. The newly hatched Merrill Lynch Focus Twenty fund took second place in the performance rankings for the third quarter, with a return of 22.8 percent. So it is not surprising that Focus Twenty has already gathered $1.7 billion in assets.
The fund, started on March 3, holds 20 stocks, 17 of them in technology. "Technology is driving the economy, so that's where most of the growth ideas are now," said Jim McCall, the manager, who is 47. He also runs the $256 million Merrill Lynch Premier Growth fund and the Merrill Lynch Mid-Cap Growth fund, introduced on Sept. 26. 
 Mr. McCall aims for a balanced portfolio; when a single stock accounts for more than 10 percent of it, he starts trimming it back. His winning stock for the quarter, Extreme Networks, up 117 percent, is not quite there yet, at 8 percent of the portfolio. But, judging from his expectations for the stock, it may require trimming soon.
Extreme Networks, in Santa Clara, Calif., manufactures high-end, commercial switches for local area networks, or LAN's, which can link personal computers around an office or around the world.
Why the triple-digit growth for the stock? "It's a next-generation technology that's starting to displace less-efficient technology," Mr. McCall said. "There's intelligence built into the semiconductor chips used in the switches that lets them identify packets of data quicker and move them along more quickly to where they have to go."
Revenue more than doubled compared with the third quarter a year ago, he said, while earnings growth lagged slightly, at 80 percent, because of a recent acquisition.
Will the company be able to sustain such astounding growth? "As best as we can tell, yes," Mr. McCall said. CAROLE GOULD

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Betting on the Old Economy Puts Three Managers Ahead

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
AFTER a wild ride during the third quarter, many mutual funds ended up about where they started. But some of the smallest and narrowest funds gained more than 20 percent.
This time, such gains in technology funds were the exception. Instead, several top-performing funds owned shares in old-economy energy companies that benefited from rising energy prices, and in the financial services sector, which was aided by mergers and stabilizing interest rates. 
 Managers of three top-performing funds talked about what drove their outstanding performances -- and they took a stab at predicting the months ahead.
 
A Bet on Alternative Energy
Energy stocks with a green hue propelled the $56.5 million New Alternatives fund, in Melville, N.Y., into first place among 3,635 diversified domestic equity funds for the third quarter, with a return of 32 percent.
Maurice L. Schoenwald, 80, started this quirky fund in 1982 with his son, David J. Schoenwald. The fund holds shares of 34 companies that the managers say improve the environment and promote clean energy. Their biggest winners were solar power and fuel cell companies, which rose sharply despite measly earnings, if they had earnings at all.
An example was FuelCell Energy, a Danbury, Conn., maker of fuel cells, devices that use electrochemical reactions to produce electricity without combustion. The company's cells are used to produce power for a single building or as much as an entire community. Its stock rose 179 percent during the quarter.
"I think there's a sense that this is a new technology that's about to be commercialized," David Schoenwald said, "and it comes at a time of concern about energy, the availability of electricity and the environment."
Another holding, the Calpine Corporation of San Jose, Calif., rose 59 percent. Using natural-gas-fired turbines and geothermal energy, Calpine produces electricity that it sells to mainstream power grids.
"It's an ongoing enterprise with tremendous earnings growth, and it's operating in an environment of energy shortfalls," Mr. Schoenwald said.
The consensus of Wall Street analysts is that Calpine's earnings will grow 81 percent this year.
The fund also benefited from its shares of El Paso Energy, a natural gas production and distribution company in Houston, up 21 percent. "The stock price was driven by the sharp increase in the price of natural gas," Mr. Schoenwald said, "and partly by companies like Calpine that use gas to generate electricity."
El Paso Energy is acquiring the Coastal Corporation, another natural gas company, in a deal that is expected to be completed by year-end. As for social responsibility, Mr. Schoenwald said, "it's not Ben & Jerry's, but we think natural gas is a clean fuel."
Impressively, the fund achieves its ranking despite an 18 percent cash position, held since January. "We're not superenthusiastic about the stock market in general," Mr. Schoenwald said. "There's been a huge gap between prices of hot stocks and value stocks that seems absurd."
 
Capitalizing on Mergers
Mergers and acquisitions among financial services companies pushed the $35 million Titan Financial Services fund into 14th place among the 5,801 domestic equity funds, including sector funds, with a gain of 25 percent.
"We clearly saw the trends toward consolidation and M.& A.," said its manager, Gilbert R. Giordano, 72, who is a former senior executive at First Virginia Bank. "Now European banks are picking up U.S. brokerages. A few months ago they were steals, but they are still selling at low fundamentals."
One of the biggest winners in the sector was FleetBoston Financial, up 15 percent. Unlike most banks, Fleet earns more than half its revenues from continuing fees generated by its brokerage and mortgage servicing businesses, making it much less vulnerable than its competitors to interest rate swings, Mr. Giordano said.
In addition, acquisitions of Quick & Reilly and Robertson Stephens expanded Fleet's traditional brokerage business into discount brokerage and electronic trading, Mr. Giordano observed. Fleet sells for 12 times earnings, he added, far below his projection of 18 or 20.
The fund also succeeded with Bear Stearns, up 52 percent for the quarter. "We think it's an excellent acquisition candidate at $110 a share," Mr. Giordano said. "The board has indicated that it is willing to consider an acquisition at $120. I don't think that's obtainable, but it's just a question of time."
Lehman Brothers was another winner, up 57 percent. The company has exceeded earnings estimates for each of the last five quarters, Mr. Giordano said, but still trades at 12 times earnings, well below a peer, Merrill Lynch, at a multiple of 17. He figures that Lehman, widely regarded as a takeover candidate, will increase its book value to $60 a share by year-end, justifying a takeover price of $200 to $220 a share.
Mr. Giordano remains bullish on financial stocks. "We're at the beginning of a consolidation that will promote mergers and acquisitions with tremendous speed because of the economies built into one-stop shopping, and because of the demolition of the Glass-Steagall Act," which generally kept banks and their affiliates from underwriting securities.
 
Return of the Small Caps
After almost two years in which their investing style could hardly have been less fashionable, George A. Henning, 53, and Thomas H. Hanson, 50, saw their $7 million Pacific Advisors Small Cap fund come back into favor in the third quarter. It gained 22 percent over the period, fourth among domestic diversified funds in a ranking that includes such small funds.
"After the market correction in March and April, we began to see money flow into the small-cap value market probably for the first time since late 1998," Mr. Henning said. "People began to realize that Internet-related company valuations couldn't be justified on earnings, and a lot of aggressive investors began looking for other sectors where they could get good returns. Small-cap stocks have traditionally fulfilled that role."
One winner was East West Bancorp of San Marino, Calif., a full-service regional bank that specializes in the Asian-American market, which gained 36 percent in the quarter. The bank has solid earnings, Mr. Henning said, but its small size and narrow focus had held its share price down before the fund began buying in the spring of 1999. "Now people are looking beyond that," he said.
He also made money in Genesco Inc. of Nashville, up 5.5 percent. Genesco is the parent of Johnston & Murphy, which sells high-end men's shoes; Jarman, which focuses on shoes for a middle-income market; and Journeys, which caters to young men and women. The Journeys brand has been particularly strong, Mr. Henning said, and Genesco has been adding stores around the country. Earnings in the second quarter were up a third from the previous year, he added.
Another favorite is ITT International Educational Services, in Indianapolis, which offers programs for high school graduates in electronics and computer science in about 30 states. Because growth in the company's programs had slowed, the stock price fell from a high of $42 in 1999 to $10 in February, when the fund bought shares. The stock rose 55 percent during the third quarter, as the success of its new programs became apparent, Mr. Henning said.
Mr. Henning is cautiously optimistic, about both the market and his favored small-cap value sector. "I suspect we might have some correction through October, and then see some sort of a year-end rally," he said. "After that, the economy will continue to grow, although at a much slower pace."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 4; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 999 words

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Keeping the Faith in Boom Times

BYLINE: By PETER DUFFY

 BODY:
THE life story of John Levi Washington Jr., the editor in chief of Street News, reads like an amalgam of a Beat novel, missionary tract and down-and-out version of "The Front Page."
Known to everyone as Indio, a name he says was "given to him by the Great Spirit" during a session of meditation, Mr. Washington has led Street News, the newspaper sold by the homeless, since 1996. Once homeless himself, he seems perfectly suited to his job, a colorful personality who easily slips from street slang to publishing jargon. 
 "A lot of people who write about homelessness haven't been there and done that," he said. "I've been there and done that, and I don't want to do it again."
With the economy booming, Mr. Washington finds it hard to draw people's attention to the homeless. But he is dedicated to keep the struggling newspaper alive to shine a light on a problem he says is as bad as it was in the late 1980's and early 90's.
"If you come around 10:30 at night and go to the front of 100 Centre Street, you'll see them out there," he said of the homeless, whose numbers are notoriously difficult to gauge. But, he added, "The newspapers and television stations aren't concerned with homelessness, and the majority of people listen to the news media."
The paper was founded by a charity-minded musician in 1989, at the height of public concern about homelessness, to give street people something to sell as an alternative to panhandling. Although it once printed as many as 250,000 copies every two weeks, Street News now publishes only 9,000 papers, which are sold by about 40 homeless people on the streets and, illegally, in the subways, Mr. Washington said. Just five issues have been distributed so far this year.
The newspaper once had offices in Manhattan but is now edited out of Mr. Washington's apartment in Kew Gardens Hills, Queens. The hands-off owner, Sam Chen, president of Expedi Printing, cheerfully admits that it is not profitable, even though publishing an issue costs just over $3,000.
Then again, his editor receives no salary.
That does not seem to bother Mr. Washington, 61, who said he lives off a city pension. Despite a limp caused by an arthritic hip, he chases down advertisers, lugs copies to the five newsstands in Manhattan and Queens where homeless vendors pick them up, and cajoles articles out of his unpaid writers, some homeless, some not.
"He represents what Street News strives to be," said Jon Hart, a freelance journalist and former Street News editor who hired Mr. Washington as an advertising salesman in 1993. "He lifted himself out of the gutter, and he's being very productive and helping people. I think about him every time I try to achieve anything."
Mr. Washington was born in Harlem to a father from the Virgin Islands and a mother who was Cherokee and Seminole. As a teenager, he trawled the city with the Harlem Lords, a street gang. After marrying, he worked at a glass and shade company and sang in doo-wop groups.
In 1971, he began selling drugs and eventually spent two years in prison.
After his release in 1975, Mr. Washington, by then divorced, continued a life of crime, selling cocaine and operating a brothel. Then he had what he calls a semiconversion. In 1977, he was ordained a minister of the nonsectarian Universal Unity Life Church and began working as a counselor for social service groups. He also got a master's degree in education from Fordham.
Throughout the 1980's, Mr. Washington stayed out of trouble. But after his second marriage fell apart, he had a breakdown and found himself a broken man on the streets. "It was like a nightmare," he said. "When you are doing bad, when you are down and out, there's very few people that will help you."
For three years, he slept in Tompkins Square Park and used drugs, for which he was jailed again. Eventually, he was drawn to Street News, which he had sold when he was on the streets. Mr. Hart remembered when Mr. Washington first arrived.
"He was persistent and we needed help," he said. "The place was a shanty, with people sleeping on the floor. But he came to work and treated it like it was Conde Nast. He wore a suit and tie. He brought in sandwiches for fellow employees. He cut out clips from newspapers and put them on the wall."
Another editor, Lee Stringer, was less impressed.
"I was originally against hiring him," said Mr. Stringer, who after leaving the paper wrote the acclaimed book "Grand Central Winter: Stories From the Streets." "He wasn't a great salesman, but he made himself infinitely useful by taking jobs nobody else wanted."
In the next few years, as money dried up because of waning interest in the homeless, Mr. Washington and Mr. Stringer worked to keep the paper going. In 1996, the paper moved to Mr. Washington's Queens apartment. When Mr. Stringer entered drug rehabilitation, his partner took the helm.
It hasn't been easy. A new issue is published only after all copies of the previous issue have been sold. And it's tough to manage the homeless vendors, who buy copies for 60 cents apiece and sell them for whatever they can get, pocketing the difference. But Mr. Washington, who says his only vices are cigarettes and the occasional beer, has a rapport with them.
"He's a very, very sharp brother," said the formerly homeless Christopher Boyd, who started selling the paper eight years ago and now lives in a subsidized apartment. "I am very grateful for everything he's done for me."
The most recent edition was published last weekend. It had 44 pages and included essays, a column by Mumia Abu-Jamal, who is on death row for killing a Philadelphia police officer, testimonies from homeless vendors, self-help columns and a few examples of the writings of Mr. Washington.
"The best part is reading the first issue that comes off the presses," said Mr. Washington, sounding like any newspaper editor. "It's like a new baby. And then you see a mistake and you want to kick yourself."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: John Levi Washington Jr. edits Street News and sells it too. Above, the search for customers at Eighth Avenue and 42nd Street. (Photographs by Edward Keating/The New York Times)
 
Chart: "VERBATIM: Not Just a Job But a Roof Overhead"
 
The early days of Street News are recounted in lively fashion by a former editor, Lee Stringer, in his 1998 memoir "Grand Central Winter: Stories From the Street":
 
"It turned out there were all sorts of forces working against Street News beyond the remedy of lively prose and a sharp blue pencil. But not knowing this at the time, I was full of passion, and I suppose that this -- coupled with the fact that I was the genuine article, a living, breathing creature of the streets -- got me the job.
That and my willingness to work for peanuts.
It also got me a place to crash."
 
 "I know that once I say "Street News," it's no longer about what I have to sell. It's about charity. Not that people mind a little charity. But when you petition them expressly on behalf of your own need, they tend to find it presumptuous.
"It sells for only a buck," I go on. "And if any of you would like a copy, please know that I'd be very happy to serve you."
Nothing.
 Not even a curious glance.
Sometimes it's like this.
But I know what to do.
"Now, now," I continue cheerfully. "There's no need to push and shove. I have plenty to go around. Please form an orderly line."
The humor nets me a few awkward chuckles and two sales."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
In a Productivity Surge, No Proof of a 'New Economy'

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
NOTHING has been harder for economists to explain than the prosperity that burst upon the United States with magical suddenness in late 1995. In the absence of explanation, there was phrase-making. A "new economy" had arrived, and the words became a banner for all sorts of optimism. Only now is a realistic definition of the new economy coming into focus.
The computer, of course, is at its heart -- but not as a miracle machine spinning a golden future comparable to the industrial leap forward that came in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Then, the electric motor, the light bulb, the internal combustion engine, petroleum, natural gas and numerous new chemicals all came on the scene -- rearranging the economy and making it vastly more productive. The electric motor alone made possible the factory assembly line and mass production. 
 Enthusiastic voices today -- in business, politics and journalism -- proclaim that the computer and its offspring are giving America a similar great leap forward. That is not true, at least not yet. What the latest data and the most recent research show is this: Computers have indeed lifted the economy, but mainly through the manufacture of the computers themselves and the production of semiconductors, communications equipment, software and other computer-related devices.
"You have this relatively small sector -- collectively known as information technology -- that is enormously productive," said Kevin J. Stiroh, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and co-author with Dale W. Jorgenson of Harvard of one of several recent studies on the subject. All of them find that the new economy is still narrowly focused on the computer industry and its siblings.
The ripple effect across the broad economy, in sum, is still rather small, although it might be much greater a decade or two from now. Biotechnology is an example of that effect, a new science that computers facilitate, and it may in time bring huge advances in medicine, the sort of radical change that developed from the cluster of inventions that appeared a century ago.
Or, the new economy may be much more modest. The phrase may come to mean simply a speeding up of what we were already doing. Computers ease or automate shopping, ticket buying, hotel reservations, information gathering, banking, data processing, trade, manufacturing. But these activities always existed.
No one can know what the future holds. All this column can do is inject some skepticism into the current euphoria by chronicling what has happened so far. The latest contribution to our collective knowledge has come from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. In a report last month, the bureau listed the reasons for the surge in productivity since 1995, to an average annual rate of 2.5 percent or so, after more than 20 years of never rising above 1.6 percent.
Productivity is all-important. What lifts an economy is the output of its workers. The more they can produce without working longer hours, the more an economy can grow without shortages and excessive inflation. Workers increase their output through new tools, like a faster computer or more robots, or through a new way of organizing work, like the assembly line. Sometimes a new technology, like the internal combustion engine, also has the ripple effect of creating a new industry, like trucking. Trucks in turn expanded the marketplace. A bicycle factory could step up production, confident that the new trucking industry and the growing highway network could deliver bicycles quickly and inexpensively to stores and customers in more cities.
The report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics made clear that the recent surge in productivity came not from such broad ripple effects, but narrowly from computers. Only about 25 percent of the robust productivity growth since 1995 came from the use of computers, software and other information processing equipment. This is the ripple effect -- computers applied to biotechnology and e-commerce, for example.
The biggest shot in the arm came from within the computer industry itself, mainly from the manufacture of ever faster, more powerful computers and semiconductors. This was the source of more than 40 percent of the nation's accelerated productivity growth. Ways were found, for example, to etch more circuits onto tiny chips without adding manpower or cost to the manufacturing process. As a result, computer power plummeted in price, and sales soared.
"Wherever productivity is surging today, it is narrowly related to computers," said Robert J. Gordon, a Northwestern University economist.
What is ahead? Well, information technology is now everywhere, and even if prices stop falling and computer power levels off, just making better use of all the new equipment already in place should continue to give some boost to productivity "until everyone is fully adapted," said Joel Mokyr, an economics historian at Northwestern.
Mr. Mokyr, an optimist, expects information technology to be the source of another great leap forward. Ultimately, however, the new computer-based technologies might not pack the wallop of the electric motor and the internal combustion engine. "We won't know," Mr. Mokyr said, "until 50 years from now, when we can look back."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
New Yorkers Like to Work Here, But Say the Living Isn't So Easy

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Is life in the city getting better?
For half the New Yorkers who responded to a City Council poll, the answer was a resounding "not really." 
 But the results of the poll, which were released Wednesday, were not all gloomy. Eighty-three percent of the 2,100 respondents to the random telephone survey rated the city as a good or excellent place for economic opportunity. Sixty-eight percent gave the same positive rating to the city as a place to live.
The survey, sponsored by the City Council and conducted in August by researchers at the Baruch College School of Public Affairs, was the first of what the Council expects to be an annual poll of public opinion about the performance of city government. The survey had a 3 percent margin of error.
(Despite the fact that those polled were kept on the phone for almost half an hour, 80 percent of the people called agreed to participate.)
Respondents cited education, crime and housing as issues that should be the top priorities of city government. Issues like police misconduct, taxes and the environment, which often make their way into headlines and mayoral politics, were low on the list of concerns.
Perhaps most surprising were findings on more narrowly drawn questions about life in the city and the quality of government services. Respondents clearly indicated that they worried about the cost of housing, with 31 percent saying they were paying more than they could afford, and 45 percent saying they had seriously considered leaving the city because housing costs were so high.
Among the most bothersome problems cited were an unexpectedly long list of seemingly minor complaints: broken pay phones, overflowing public trash containers, suspicious tap water, dim street lights, waiting on hold for a 911 operator, littered sidewalks, the lack of public toilets, and taxicabs that ignore waiting passengers.
The City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, said of these findings: "New York is a first-rate city with a booming economy. We should expect that our trash baskets don't overflow and that our pay phones shouldn't all be broken."
Public libraries and parks were the services that got the highest marks.
When those polled were asked how they felt about the people running city government, 46 percent said they had "some confidence." Another 27 percent said they had either "very little confidence" or "no confidence at all." THOMAS J. LUECK

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS;
Obsessive? No, Just Looking for a Parking Space

BYLINE: By LESLIE BERGER

 BODY:
AS a regular alternate-side parker, Janet MacAdam is likely on any given weekday to be hunkered down in her old Chevy wagon in the middle of the day, reading the daily papers or marking up book galleys as she awaits the end of street sweeping and preserves her claim on the curb. She is half of a somewhat bohemian couple, a chef and a writer, and they are the sort of veteran West Siders for whom paid parking is anathema.
But just how invested they were didn't become evident until Ms. MacAdam casually mentioned that whenever they leave their farm in upstate New York to return to the city, they do so early enough in the morning to be back by 1 p.m., in time to find a space before street sweeping and double-parking end at 2. 
 "You go down at 1:30, you're out of luck," Ms. MacAdam explained. "If you do it right, you only have to do it on Mondays and Fridays."
The problem is that once she finds a good space, she is loath to give it up, whereas her husband likes to use their car to tool around the city. "The biggest arguments my husband and I ever have is when he'll say he wants to drive downtown to visit a friend on Eighth Street," she said. "I'll say, 'You're not moving that car when it took me hours to find a space!' "
If Ms. MacAdam is the nester and her husband the adventurer in their domestic parking rites, you could say that Sandy Marcus is the hunter while her husband, Charles Zimmerman, is the hoarder-gatherer. They are parking foils. not unlike those couples -- all too common in the city -- in which one partner will cruise endlessly in search of a space while the other will happily pull into a garage after a few minutes of fruitless searching.
Ms. Marcus, a speech pathologist who teaches in the South Bronx, is a self-described Type A predator when it comes to finding on-street parking at the end of a long day. "I go through red lights if I see another car looking for a spot and think it's going to make a turn before me," she admitted. Her artist husband would rather not deal with parking at all; he's just too impatient, she said. Sometimes, though, when Ms. Marcus has parked her car but finds a better space nearby, she will have Mr. Zimmerman stand in front of it and hold it for her until she can repark their silver 1984 Nissan Maxima.
Does she feel this is ethical?
"Yeah, I do," she said. "Because I saw the spot, so just like in two seconds I'd be there. I don't think I'd do that if it was three blocks away, but if it's just on the other side of the street and I can be there in two seconds. . . ."
Neuroses are not uncommon in New York, and especially when it comes to parallel parking, a life skill so fraught with angst and comedy it was destined to inspire a dream sequence in at least one Woody Allen movie. (Remember "Bananas," in which two competing crucifixion processions dissolve into a brawl over a place to park their crosses?) The distinctive parking styles of New Yorkers stand out in especially high relief in a day when there are fewer places than ever to negotiate for, as the growing number of cars in the city and static number of parking spaces indicate.
"Traffic has been growing generally about 2 or 3 percent a year, and you can just conclude that those cars need some place to park," said Elliot G. Sander, the former city transportation commissioner, now a private consultant and director of the Rudin Center for Transportation Policy and Management at New York University.
Samuel I. Schwartz, the former deputy city transportation commissioner-turned-consultant, whose many hats include that of Gridlock Sam, the traffic columnist for The Daily News, concurs. "It's harder and harder to find spots," he said, "and you have to be more and more creative."
Although the consensus among several experts on transportation in the city is that the strong economy has made parking tougher than ever, Deputy Transportation Commissioner Michael Primeggia disagreed. Mr. Primeggia said that more on-street parking was available, thanks to new, multispace meters the city had installed in critical shopping districts, along with relaxed alternate-side parking regulations.
He also noted that not every car entering the city needs short-term parking and that not every part of the city was equally saturated. "In our neighborhood in Brooklyn, my wife and I manage to find parking every day for two cars and we don't change our life around to do it," he said.
Even as the debate continues, several advocates of public transportation say the time has come for all city parking to be of the paid variety, even if that means installing meters on every block and charging by the minute in loading zones.
"The answer to this is called congestion pricing," said John Kaehny, executive director of Transportation Alternatives, a nonprofit watchdog group. "Capitalism says that when there's a shortage of something, prices go up."
How that idea would go over with parkers like Ms. MacAdam and Ms. Marcus is predictable enough. Besides, Ms. MacAdam said, on a few desperate occasions lately, she has even had trouble finding paid space in local garages.
IT helps to be a dare-ya kind of driver like Eric Greenberg, a high school history teacher who commutes daily from Manhattan to East Meadow, on Long Island. Mr. Greenberg boasts that he can nudge his way into spaces even shorter than his silver Ford Taurus station wagon.
"If I see a space that's two inches bigger than my car," he said, "I barely consider it a challenge."
"One macho thing a lot of people do is wait behind someone trying to get into a tight spot," he added. "You put them under pressure. You just wait behind them; few will try more than twice to fit in. I particularly get a lot of satisfaction from a person with a subcompact who can't get into a spot and I know I can get into it with my station wagon."
Like many city parkers, Mr. Greenberg looks not only for open spaces but for people with keys in hand, hopefully on their way to move their car. Others take this strategy a step further, enlisting strangers in their quest for a parking space.
"You have to beg them," said Ms. Marcus, who uses this approach. " 'Please do me a favor and don't leave your spot till you see my car coming!' "
Luckily, Ms. Marcus has never met Sandy Carp, a high school guidance counselor from Kew Gardens, Queens, who has little tolerance for such guerrilla maneuvers. Ms. Carp said she had twice encountered people physically blocking parking spaces near her home. In the more recent incident, she returned about 10:30 p.m. to find three generations -- a father, a grandfather and a young child -- standing in a parking space they were saving for an unseen relative.
"They're all lined up, the three of them, and I said, 'Excuse me, I'm going to get into this space,' and they said, 'No, you can't,' " Ms. Carp recalled. "And I said, 'You really aren't allowed to save the space.' There was no car in sight. And the old man said, 'Who's going to make me?'
"This time, I had a cell phone, and I said, 'Well, the police will make you.' So as I'm trying to dial they sort of all drift off somewhere."

HEADLINE: The World;
How to Succeed in the Kidnapping Business

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS

DATELINE: BANGKOK

 BODY:
IN the security business, there is a technical term for the Muslim rebel kidnappers of the southern Philippines, draped in new gold chains, conspicuous in pristine Nike sneakers and Ray Ban sunglasses, racing around on -- and often falling off -- their new motorcycles. The term is "decadent guerrillas."
Having taken their remote region's age-old avocation of kidnapping for ransom to new heights this year with the abductions of dozens of foreigners, they now have more money than they may ever have dreamed of or, clearly, know what to do with: some $15 million for two dozen hostages. 
 Cash rich, these few hundred rebels are buying sophisticated weaponry and recruiting new followers, and they have acquired a speedboat faster than anything in the Philippine navy. They are even kidnapping, and then paying "dowry," for new brides. Clearly, they are more interested in their decadent new luxuries than in their fight for a separate Muslim state.
And they may live to enjoy their spoils. A two-week-old military offensive against the kidnappers, who call themselves Abu Sayyaf, or Bearer of the Sword, appears to have accomplished little besides leveling several villages on the remote island of Jolo.
Not a bad business proposition for local bandits in one of the poorest regions of the Philippines -- or for a growing number of hostage takers around the world. More and more these days, dollar amounts are being placed on human lives.
"It's clear that this is a growing industry worldwide, though there is disagreement about how fast it is growing," said Paul Wilkinson, director of the Center for the Study of Terrorism and Political Violence at the University of St. Andrews in Scotland. "And it's affecting many parts of the world, like the former Soviet Union, that have been relatively free of it in the past."
Statistics are elusive in an arena marked by secrecy, corruption and sometimes the collusion of government authorities. Most often cited are the surveys of the Hiscox Group, a London-based insurer that tallied 1,789 kidnappings for ransom last year worldwide, almost all of them in 10 high-risk countries. That number shows a 6 percent rise from the previous high of 1,690 in 1998.
Brian Jenkins, an expert on terrorism at the RAND Corporation, a research and policy group based in Santa Monica, Calif., said Latin America accounted for two-thirds to three-quarters of the world's ransom kidnappings, with Colombia making up about half, followed by Mexico and Brazil. The next largest area of concentration is in Asia, he said, with the largest numbers in the coastal cities of China and in Pakistan and India. The former Soviet republics make up the next block, especially, he said, in the Caucasus. (The United States records fewer than a dozen ransom kidnappings a year.)
Security firms and anti-terrorism agencies increasingly focus on kidnapping, and kidnap and ransom insurance now generate $150 million a year in premiums worldwide, though companies that take the insurance are cautioned not to tell their employees for fear it might make them more attractive targets. Such policies provide money for ransom, and can also pay for the fees of kidnap negotiators -- which can run to $15,000 a week -- and even for psychiatric treatment for victims and their families.
As foreign embassies step up their precautions, experts say, kidnappers are looking for "softer" targets. As more business travelers and tourists venture into out-of-the-way areas, they say, more are being seized for ransom in what one analyst called "the dark side of globalization."
"I do think it's fair to say that with respect to terror as a whole we are going to see a major shift from government targets to the private sector -- to tourists or businessmen," said the analyst, Frank Cilluffo,at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington.
Some kidnappings are intended to publicize a political view. These -- like the Iranian hostage-taking of American diplomats two decades ago -- can draw the most publicity. Other goals are to gain concessions from an enemy, to sow terror or even to dramatize a personal grievance. But in most cases, experts say, the bottom line is money, sometimes for a political cause but more often simply to enrich the kidnappers.
In the southern Philippines, for example, after seizing 21 mostly foreign tourists and workers from a diving resort in April, the kidnappers at first couldn't seem to make up their minds. They demanded a separate Muslim state, a renegotiation of fishing rights, the release of imprisoned terrorists in the United States and even a local ban on Christmas celebrations. After weeks of talks they reached their bottom line. What they wanted -- and received -- was money.
 THE great playground of decadent guerrillas is Colombia, where Marxist rebels control huge areas of the countryside. "They are free to do their stuff apparently untrammeled by security forces, who are not allowed to enter, and they are making vast sums of money out of the kidnapping business," said Mr. Wilkinson.
Kidnapping techniques are changing, too, spawning a colorful new jargon among security experts. Increasingly common, particularly in Latin America and southern China, is "express kidnapping," said Neil Gane, a division manager with the Hong Kong-based security firm Hill & Associates. Kidnappers take victims from one automatic teller machine to another, withdrawing the maximum amount of cash each day until the accounts are empty. Then the victims are freed.
In "tiger kidnappings," which have grown particularly common in Britain, illegal immigrants are held -- sometimes in groups -- while ransoms are demanded from their relatives at home, Mr. Gane said. "Bad-on-bad kidnappings" are an emerging tactic in business disputes among rival criminal groups, particularly in Asia: just grab some of the other guy's men and hold them until he agrees to your demands.
Security experts say the most difficult category is what they call "amateur kidnappings," in which freelance opportunists try their hand, oblivious to unwritten rules that can help assure a safe release. "They are more erratic, more dynamic and therefore more difficult to deal with," Mr. Cilluffo said. "You don't necessarily know what's going on in their minds and they may be itchier with the trigger finger."
The Abu Sayyaf kidnappers have behaved like amateurs, but they seem to have profited from it. They changed their demands, squabbled among themselves and beheaded two hostages -- both Filipinos -- when the mood took them.
But they grasped a fundamental principle of the kidnap business: hostages are not only a source of revenue but a human shield against retribution. Even as they released some hostages, and even after the military launched its attack last month, the Abu Sayyaf rebels seized more victims.

Around the world, kidnappers are usually driven by the desire to force concessions from governments or to make money - or both. As many as 75 percent of kidnappings are intended to force political change, according to Brian Jenkins, a terrorism expert at the RAND Corporation. About 30 percent are for financial gain, he said. HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
Extravagant Evil And the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL; Alan Cowell is the London-based financial correspondent for The Times.

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
FIRST Seattle, then Prague. The recurrent images of clashes between hooded demonstrators and police officers defending the barons of global capitalism have become a powerful motif for the protests and preoccupations of a new millennium.
At first blush, the demonstrators' rage may bewilder many Westerners. After all, whether the body under assault is the World Trade Organization, the International Monetary Fund or the World Bank, the institutions' stated aims are surely laudable: liberalized trade, economic rescue and development. 
 But the protests -- seizing on targets as disparate as finance ministers' gatherings and McDonald's outlets -- have touched a raw nerve at a time when the gap between rich and poor is widening, when many poor countries labor under unpayable debt inherited from the politically driven international lending of the cold war and when trade, for many, means little more than an uneven exchange of expensive Western goods for cheap commodities.
Nowhere are these issues more evident than in Africa. And as Michela Wrong's "In the Footsteps of Mr. Kurtz" (Fourth Estate) appears to suggest, no single African country has taken the bizarre interface of ill-fated international lending and corrupt politics to the same extremes as Congo, the former Zaire.
As the title suggests, this is not a "business" book or a dry academic study. It is a journalist's fast-paced account of the final years of the regime of the late President Mobutu Sese Seko, whose blend of greed, corruption and hunger for power fascinated generations of reporters from his rise to power in 1965 to his ignominious demise in 1997.
It is a book whose time is right, because it illuminates much of the current debate underlying the protests in Seattle and Prague. (Published in London, the book will be issued in the United States by HarperCollins next May.) It points an accusing finger at the readiness of the International Monetary Fund to almost encourage the errant ways of a political elite that it was avowedly rescuing from itself. And, not least for anyone who contemplates greasing the wheels of business in pursuit of a quick deal, it demonstrates the perils of corruption -- a force that, in Congo's case, led directly to a national implosion.
Mr. Mobutu was hardly a stranger to harsh scrutiny. No visitor to Kinshasa, the capital, in his heyday in the 1970's and 1980's could avoid the twin frisson of revulsion and bewitchment that the country inspired.
Here was a dictator -- as this reporter can attest -- who kept caged leopards in his garden, dined off gold plates and repelled insurgents with the ready help of the United States Air Force and the French Foreign Legion, even as the African bush seemed to be reclaiming his decaying capital.
Then as now, Congo drew outsiders into its heady web of bloodshed, absurdity and evil -- distant massacres offset against fine restaurants patronized by the elite, the pony-tailed pianist at the Hotel Intercontinental who played "As Time Goes By" and presidential extravagance on a scale as grand as the broad sweep of the Congo River.
All this imbues the rich, anecdotal tapestry in the book, starting with a description of Mr. Mobutu's henchmen fleeing the capital, carrying machine guns and Louis Vuitton luggage as rebels advanced. (The absence of the pianist in May 1997, Ms. Wrong says, signaled that the end was nigh for Mr. Mobutu.)
BUT Ms. Wrong takes the debate much further with her keen understanding of where, exactly, the Mobutu regime was coming from as the ultimate heir to a Belgian colonial administration founded on the awesome chutzpah of King Leopold II, who in the 19th century simply took over the Congo -- a country the size of western Europe -- as a personal fief.
Ms. Wrong, who covered the final Mobutu years for Reuters and The Financial Times, has woven her title from an allusion to Kurtz, the central figure of Joseph Conrad's "Heart of Darkness," whose dying words -- "the horror, the horror" -- have inspired legions of journalists and moviemakers.
She is quick to point out that those words have often been presented as an indictment of African ways rather than Kurtz's own acknowledgment of his own fall from grace. "Conrad was more preoccupied with rotten Western values, the white man's inhumanity to the black man than, as is almost always assumed today, black savagery," she writes.
And that brings her to the central theme. If Mr. Mobutu was the archvillain of his nation's tragedy, he was not a simple caricature, or, indeed, a man without a context. "The momentum behind Zaire's free fall was generated not by one man but by thousands of compliant collaborators, at home and abroad." This is no exculpation of Mr. Mobutu, but, in the present debate over the role of international financial institutions, it helps explain just why Congo -- and many other African countries to a less dramatic degree -- got into such an enormous financial mess.
Indeed, it evokes a central question for the international institutions and donors of today as they contemplate the morass left over from the cold war: where is the morality in imposing yet more fiscal hardship on nations burdened by the same debts as those the "compliant collaborators" in the international community helped to create?
Zaire is a particularly glaring example. But, as Ms. Wrong points out, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank were complicit -- by default at the very least -- in creating this monster. From 1975 to 1997, Zaire received $9.3 billion in foreign aid, much of it at the height of the cold war and much of it from the I.M.F. and the World Bank, at a time when the United States and other Western powers were determined to keep Mr. Mobutu in their camp.
Yet throughout this period -- and particularly after the I.M.F. installed its own representative, Erwin Blumenthal, at Zaire's Central Bank in 1978 -- those institutions knew full well that Mr. Mobutu was stripping the state coffers not just of aid income but also of receipts from Zaire's fabled riches in copper, cobalt and diamonds. Mr. Blumenthal subsequently reported ample evidence of corruption, but any effort to restrain Mr. Mobutu was thwarted by bigger geopolitical considerations. In the thinking of the time, Ms. Wrong writes, "No one wants to be the official remembered as having 'lost' Zaire, Kenya, Zambia or Tanzania."
Only in recent years have those same international institutions come to acknowledge that aid and other forms of assistance are inseparable from "governance issues" -- meaning that there is no point in trying to help people who are, literally, helping themselves to the state's riches. But, of course, the damage has been done. Debts have piled up, but forgiveness is hard to come by, usually involving wrenching economic reforms that look for signs of macroeconomic health long before they benefit ordinary people. And, in the bulk of sub-Saharan Africa, it is the ordinary people who have become more and more destitute.
Not all of their leaders were corrupt. Often enough, in nations like Zambia and Tanzania, misguided economic stewardship did almost as much damage as Mr. Mobutu's kleptocracy -- the term that came to be applied to the robber regime.
That, of course, is where the protesters in Seattle and Prague come into the picture, taking up the cudgels -- it could be argued as uninvited champions -- on behalf of those millions in many parts of Africa who have neither voice nor prospects.
Ms. Wrong does not, however, oversimplify or sentimentalize the argument. Her account of Mr. Mobutu's interaction with wealth is far more nuanced, pointing out, for instance, that state corruption is an expensive business. Anyone looking for Mr. Mobutu's rumored hidden stash of looted billions, she suggests, will be disappointed: if he stole from the state, he did so in part to finance a network of complicit and equally corrupt lieutenants, ready to repay largess with loyalty.
Neither is the issue made any simpler by the post-Mobutu regime of Laurent Kabila that seems a continuation of rather than a break with the history of venality. The protesters in Seattle and Prague might take note or, at least, cast a more searching look over those who lead the people that they champion.

HEADLINE: THE BUSINESS WORLD;
In a Weak Ruble, Strength for Russian Timber

BYLINE: By JOHN VAROLI

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

 BODY:
UNTIL a few years ago, the small town of Sokol in the Vologda region of northwest Russia was largely idle. Now, thanks to a timber plant that was nearly bankrupt, Sokol is coming to life again. Logs are brought in constantly by rail. Large tractors haul loads of wood. Even more important, employees are paid real money for real work -- a not-so-common arrangement in Russia's economy.
After a decade of decline, Russia's forest-products industry is bouncing back, revived by a weak ruble and rising domestic demand. 
 The industry is finding the sale of processed wood especially lucrative. In 1999, the country produced 110 million cubic meters of processed wood, up 25 percent from 1998. At the same time, timber companies are investing hundreds of millions of dollars in new processing plants.
The Sputnik Group, based in Moscow, and ZAO Ilim Pulp Enterprises, of St. Petersburg, are leading the resurgence. Ilim Pulp, which accounts for nearly 35 percent of Russia's pulp and board volume and exports 70 percent of its output, says it will invest $140 million over several years to modernize its processing centers in northwest Russia and in Siberia.
The weakness of the ruble, which was devalued in August 1998, has bolstered the industry by pricing foreign goods out of the local market and making Russian wood more competitive abroad. The weak currency has also prompted mergers within the industry.
Ilim Pulp, in fact, owes much of its current size to the 1998 devaluation. Founded in 1992 as a trader of pulp and paper products, the company slowly began to buy pulp and paper manufacturers in 1996. After the currency crisis, that strategy accelerated.
"These companies became cheap to buy, especially for us, because our company was, and is, earning hard currency from exports," said Svatoslav Bytchkov, Ilim Pulp's communications director.
Since then, sales have soared. They doubled from 1996 to 1999, when they reached $800 million. While the acquisition of timber companies caused some of the sales increase, the industry's revival explains a big chunk of it, Ilim Pulp executives said. They said plans include taking the company public and selling American depository receipts on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sputnik, an investment company controlled by Boris Jordan, an American financier, has spent $30 million over the last two years to build up its National Timber Company. The company is centered in the Vologda region -- it owns the plant that has revived Sokol's economy -- and it sells logs and sawed timber to Russian and European markets. Sputnik says it will invest at least $50 million in the venture over the next three to five years.
"Our main goal is to create a vertically integrated timber company made of units which are located in various regions of Russia," Mr. Jordan said. "We plan to acquire more timber companies, to implement modern production technology and attract more investment to this sector."
The company is riding a surge of orders for sawed wood as Russian furniture makers and construction companies respond to growing consumer demand. Sputnik estimated that National Timber's sales would reach $70 million in 2000-2001, up from $25 million in 1999-2000.
FOREIGN companies, including International Paper of the United States, Ikea of Sweden and Stora Enso, a Finnish-Swedish concern, are also investing in northwest Russia. Last year, International Paper opened a $35 million paper plant in Svetogorsk, 90 miles north of St. Petersburg.
More recently, Sweden's Sved Wood, a subsidiary of Ikea, said it would begin processing wood outside of St. Petersburg. And Stora Enso, one of the largest wood-processing and paper companies in Europe, said it would invest $40 million in a packaging plant in the Nizhni Novgorod region on the Volga River.
Some analysts are optimistic.
"Sputnik and others like it have good chances of being successful," said Lev Savulkin, senior analyst at the Leontief Center for Social and Economic Research in St. Petersburg.
But there are risks, he cautioned. Besides the chance that the ruble will become stronger, Mr. Savulkin said, "the growth of the Russian timber sector will depend on the situation on world markets -- whether or not demand will remain high."
"If the world economy slows," he added, "then Russian exports will suffer."
After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Russia's wood-processing industry was devastated as domestic orders dried up and financial institutions stopped providing credit and investment. In 1989, the country produced 375 million cubic meters of processed wood. By 1998, that figure had dropped to 88 million.
Although Russia has the world's largest timber reserves, with 1.9 billion acres of forest, or 22 percent of the world's total, the country accounts for only 2.3 percent of world output, according to Russia's Ministry of Economics.
The Vologda region is one of Russia's timber centers. Private timber companies have invested about $200 million in production there since 1996, said Viktor Gratchev, head of the regional government's forestry department.
Nearly 75 percent of Russia's timber reserves are in Siberia, but a lack of road and rail connections there keeps most of these resources out of reach. Vologda, however, has rail links to the port in St. Petersburg and the markets in Moscow.
Most important, business executives say, they can do business with Vologda's leaders -- a rare situation in Russia's provinces, where many leaders are suspicious of outside investors.
"The government of the Vologda region is trying to improve the investment climate in the region, and is ready to work with investors," Mr. Jordan said. His company, he added, cultivates close relations with the government and contributes to local social-service projects.
Alexander Zubkov, a former forestry official in Karelia in northwest Russia and now a timber businessman, suggested that such an approach was prudent. He said, "The government gives out licenses for cutting timber and can control organs such as the Tax Inspectorate, which can cause a lot of problems for those doing business."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
The Plain Janes, at Center Stage

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
IN the stock market's new world order, boring is beautiful and the dazzlers have been dimmed.
That, at least, was the story in the third quarter. After years of outperformance, most of the stock market's raciest shares were overtaken by the mundane. Value funds beat growth funds almost across the board, and big-company stock funds lagged behind those that invest in smaller companies' shares. Even more unusual, Treasury bonds outperformed most growth stock indexes. 
 Perhaps most distressing to investors who have poured money into technology stocks, the gains of tech funds were far outpaced by funds that bought financial and health care stocks or real estate assets. Even funds that invest in electric utility stocks, as prosaic as the stock market has to offer, walloped the technology funds during the quarter. Only one group of glamour stocks -- the biotechnology sector -- continued to shine.
While the average diversified stock fund investing in United States companies gained 2.31 percent in the quarter, large-company growth funds fell 0.44 percent. Value funds investing in large-company shares gained 4.87 percent, but those buying shares of middle-tier companies surged 8.43 percent.
Of course, all of those returns were much better than the performance of the broad market indexes. The Standard & Poor's 500 lost 1.2 percent for the quarter and 2.2 percent for the first nine months of the year, while the Nasdaq composite index declined 7.4 percent and 9.75 percent, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 1.94 percent for the quarter but down 7.4 percent for the nine months.
Still, investors have a right to be stunned by the recent turnabout in the mutual fund sweepstakes. Growth stocks are still ahead over the past 12 months, but at the current rate of change, the one-year totals may reverse soon, too.
Christine A. Callies, the chief United States investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said she believed that the shift in the market's leadership reflected a new aversion to risk and a greater appreciation of value.
"The market's struggle with the issue of fair value is nowhere more evident than in the technology sector," Ms. Callies said.
She noted that six months ago, many investors believed that the technology companies with the highest price-to-earnings ratios were invulnerable. But the prices of many of them have since plummeted.
Another aspect of the shift, according to A. Marshall Acuff Jr., a market strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, is that the strategy of concentration -- in which a fund manager bets on a small number of stocks -- appears to be less profitable than that of diversification. "Since this spring, the number of stocks rising in price has been increasing," Mr. Acuff said. That represents a big change from previous years, when a tiny raft of stocks was responsible for all the gains in the broad market indexes.
"Back in March and April we began to see a rational rebalancing of the excesses in the market." he said. "We're seeing a continued play-out. We're still going to have some high-priced stocks, but the reality is we continue to see almost weekly shortfalls in growth expectations."
Recently, such diverse but humdrum groups as tobacco, oil services and financial services have been pulling ahead.
ROBERT ADLER, president of AMG Data Services, which tracks fund flows, confirmed that investors were seeking a broader focus. "Equity inflows have been declining in technology and index funds but have stood up fairly well in the large-cap growth area," Mr. Adler said. "Investors are giving portfolio managers surrogate power to move beyond technology to those sectors that are performing well. Technology no longer reigns as a specific focus."
In the first quarter, for instance, technology stock funds received 28.3 percent of mutual fund inflows, Mr. Adler said. That figure fell to 11.7 percent in the second quarter and 9.7 percent in the third.
Unfortunately for investors who have grown used to buying funds that mirror the performance of a broad market index, this strategy, too, has been lagging behind. For many years, this passive and appealingly low-cost approach trounced the stock-picking of so-called active fund managers. But in the third quarter, active management triumphed. The Standard & Poor's 500, the basis of most index funds, lost 1 percent in the third quarter, compared with the gain of more than 2 percent for the average diversified stock fund.
Even among active managers, many winners and losers have been trading places, reflecting the depth and breadth of the market's shift. The most successful active managers of recent years are beginning to falter, and picking future winners based on funds' past performance is becoming more difficult, according to statisticians at Morningstar Inc. who studied performance over the last decade.
For each year, the researchers chose the 25 top performers -- based on their previous three-year gains -- and looked at how they performed the next year. On average during the 1990's, they found, these funds ranked within the top one-third of all funds in performance. But for the first nine months of 2000, the three-year leaders, including past favorites like Janus Twenty and Rydex OTC Investors, have settled squarely in the middle of the pack.
Topping the winners' list among diversified stock funds in the third quarter was the New Alternatives fund, which invests in small-cap companies. It rose 32.04 percent. Among the value funds turning up in the top 20 were Seligman Large Cap Value A, up 17.55 percent, and Vontobel U.S. Value, up 17.25 percent.
One diversification method that did not work well in the third quarter was investing abroad. The average international stock fund lost 6.7 percent of its value, largely a result of sharp declines in the values of the euro and the Japanese yen against the dollar. But economic woes in Asia also contributed to the dismal returns. The average fund investing in the Pacific Rim, including Japan, lost 12.58 percent of its value. Those investing in Japanese stocks alone fell 9.93 percent, on average.
With all the major market indexes registering losses for the first three quarters, some market strategists have wondered how the declines will affect investor and consumer behavior. After all, the stock markets have been delivering historically high returns for the last five years.
As for investor behavior, equity fund inflows have been declining throughout the year, Mr. Adler said, from $113.7 billion in the first quarter to $50 billion in the second quarter and $36.7 billion in the third.
The effect on consumers is less clear. Stock gains have obviously helped keep shoppers on spending sprees, which in turn have kept the economy moving. Will investment losses make them reign in their spending, threatening world economic growth?
Judging from one barometer, a considerably larger market tumble will be needed to scare away consumers. According to an annual PaineWebber/Gallup survey, involving 1,000 Americans, those with investable financial assets like securities and cash say their portfolios would have to fall 27 percent before they would feel it necessary to reduce spending.
Many market strategists note, too, that in each of the last two years, a weak third quarter has set the stage for a strong final quarter. In the third quarter of 1999, American stock funds lost just over 4 percent of their value, on average. Then they rebounded mightily, rising 21 percent in the final quarter.
The story was similar in 1998. A nasty, 13 percent loss in the third quarter gave way to an almost 20 percent gain in the last three months of the year.
WILL the past be a prologue? Charles H. Blood, Jr., managing director at Brown Brothers Harriman, said he believes so. As it becomes clearer that the Federal Reserve's interest rate increases have achieved a slowdown in economic growth, he said, it will also become more obvious to the Fed that it can lower rates late this year. And when that change in monetary policy becomes clear to investors, Mr. Blood said, he expects the broad market indexes to rally.
For the moment, however, investors who have grown used to following the leaders, or simply throwing money at an index, have work to be done and a new crowd to assess. While many investors may be tempted to hunt for bargains in technology, few strategists believe that these shares will turn in the type of returns that they did when the economy was racing. And even though many of the hottest stocks have cooled, most of the former highflyers remain expensive by traditional valuation methods.
If an economic slowdown unfolds as Mr. Blood expects, some of the same companies that have done well in recent months should continue to shine. Electric utilities will benefit if the Fed cuts rates, as will financial services and companies investing in real estate. So taking up with the new stars in the mutual fund firmament could prove rewarding in the future, too.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1992 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT;
Where Else to Gaze When a Star Falls to Earth?

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

 BODY:
FEW grins were brighter than Thomas H. Bailey's pearly-white wattage a year ago on the cover of Forbes magazine.
Posing against a Rocky Mountain backdrop, Mr. Bailey, the founder and chief executive of Janus Capital in Denver, had little reason to fret. Janus was hauling in the largest net sales of any money manager in the mutual fund industry. Powered by huge bets on technology and telecommunications, its funds were topping the performance charts. "The Janus Touch" -- as the Forbes story was labeled -- was producing, in some cases, triple-digit annual returns. 
 Fast-forward one year. Janus's favorite stocks, the likes of Nokia, Apple Computer and Microsoft, are stumbling. The company's highflying performance has been grounded. Critics say the firm has been bloated with more money than it can effectively manage -- the Janus Twenty fund, which once had about 20 stocks, should now be called the Janus Forty-Five. Not helping any were the recent retirement of James Craig, the firm's respected chief investment officer, and a feud with its corporate parent, Kansas City Southern, over how it would be spun off.
Investors' doubts about Janus became evident in September, the first month in more than two and a half years that more money was removed from its funds than was put in.
But where else should investors go? In today's manic markets, even a major fund company can fall from atop the charts to mediocrity in a matter of months. As a result, investors have rediscovered a degree of caution. According to AMG Data Services, which tracks fund flows, more than half the new money that they put into equity funds in the third quarter went into large-cap growth funds -- not exactly the most conservative haven, but safer than sector funds, especially in technology, where they were more prone to take a chance earlier in the year.
A new collection of fund groups, meanwhile, has replaced Janus at the top, and their success suggests two strategies. Investors seeking some safety could choose a group like the Wasatch Funds of Salt Lake City. Its practice of value-oriented investing has kept it searching for unloved and undervalued companies and sectors.
Samuel S. Stewart Jr., president of Wasatch and lead manager of its Wasatch Core Growth fund, said his success this year was a matter of patience. Last year, instead of buying Internet stocks, he bought small- and medium-sized health and financial services companies he saw as undervalued. And his performance lagged behind market averages.
THIS year, that strategy turned into a trifecta. Health and financial services are two of the hottest sectors, and smaller-company stocks are outperforming large-company shares by the biggest margin since 1993.
"It's tortoise and hare," Mr. Stewart said. "What did the tortoise do different that put him in first place? Nothing. The hare sat down."
But some of the hares are still hopping. Granted, Internet stocks in general have yet to recover from the hammering they took in April. The average technology fund was down 1.7 percent in the third quarter, while telecommunications funds, technology's high-octane twin, were brutalized, falling 7.2 percent. Still, two of the top-performing fund families of the year -- the Van Wagoner Funds of San Francisco and the Turner Funds of Berwyn, Pa. -- lean heavily on technology and telecommunications, according to Morningstar Inc.
Both groups are frenetic traders, and both have dumped the older technology champions in favor of the newest. "There's a real changing of the guard in the technology business," said Garrett Van Wagoner, president of the Van Wagoner Funds."The desktop companies -- Intel, Microsoft, Dell -- are becoming old-economy companies. The desktop isn't sexy anymore. Bill Gates is kind of an old fogy. He's 43 with a zillion dollars and kids."
The most pronounced move of the third quarter was a surge in value funds, which closed the gap with growth funds for the year.
The technology boom of last year was ruled by growth investors, who look for companies with accelerating earnings, with less regard for price. As a result, the Internet-shy strategy of Mr. Stewart at his flagship Wasatch Core Growth fund failed to bring Janus-like returns. The fund, which Morningstar categorizes as a combination of growth and value investing, gained 19.3 percent last year, two percentage points behind the Standard & Poor's 500 index.
Through the first nine months this year, however, it is up 23.2 percent, compared with the 2.4 percent decline of the S.& P.
Last year, Mr. Stewart said, he found growing companies selling at 10 to 15 times earnings, "and that's an awfully attractive price." But to many people, he said, a company with steady 20 percent earnings growth was boring.
"People said you could always come back to it, so they jumped from high quality to chase after Internet stocks," he said.
The Wasatch Core Growth fund, with $290 million in assets, had an especially strong third quarter, gaining more than 13.7 percent. Surges in some of its financial services holdings propelled it into the top 1 percent of small-company funds that blend value and growth styles, according to Morningstar. One top pick, and the fund's largest holding, was AmeriCredit, a Fort Worth-based lender to people with low credit ratings. Though subprime lending has become something of an investor untouchable, especially after First Union's shuttering of the Money Store earlier this year, Mr. Stewart said he believes AmeriCredit is simply a well-managed company in an out-of-favor industry. In the quarter, the stock gained nearly 70 percent.
"We haven't done a whole lot different this year than in previous years," Mr. Stewart said. "Some years, the market is more generous to us."
Make that many years: Wasatch Core Growth ranks in the top 20 percent of its peer group for the last decade.
Value investing, though, has certainly been no cure-all, given how much better growth funds, especially in technology, have done in previous years.
"It's a little bit of a victory for the old economy," said John Rekenthaler, director of research at Morningstar. "They need about 30 more quarters like this to make up for 1998 and 1999. It's like a team giving up four touchdowns to the St. Louis Rams and getting a few six-yard runs and a first down. No value managers should be crowing."
As the Van Wagoner and Turner groups show, some of the most successful funds continue to chase the sort of technology stocks that cause value investors to quiver. Mr. Van Wagoner and Robert E. Turner, the chief executive of Turner Funds, both rearrange their portfolios far more often than the average money manager, seeking stocks whose earnings and price gains have the greatest momentum. Mr. Turner said that turnover in his technology fund was about 1,000 percent a year.
While such an approach has the potential to generate high tax bills, this year it has also given them high returns.
"Momentum has been tricky, but it has worked for some people," Mr. Rekenthaler said. "It's a matter of execution. It was a tough quarter to be a long-term buyer."
FIVE or six years ago, most technology funds had similar casts: Microsoft, Intel, Compaq, I.B.M. But no longer. The breathtaking expansion of technology and telecommunications has made it harder to predict what one might find in such sector funds. It has also made it more difficult for professional and amateur investors alike to navigate the possibilities.
"Last year was a lay-up for individual investors," said Mr. Turner, whose firm also runs the $599 million Vanguard Growth Equity fund and $49 million Mercury Select Growth, part of the Merrill Lynch family. "This year is more sobering, a wake-up call. It's also a wake-up call for the big investment funds. The buy-and-hold strategy doesn't work."
Buy and hold, that most venerated of investing dictums, does not work? Mr. Turner says many large growth funds that are fueled by technology have kept some of their prized holdings too long.
"The really big blue-chip tech stocks have done horrible," he said. "There's new-economy tech stocks and there's old-economy tech stocks." He noted that personal computer companies saw earnings growth fall from 30 percent annually five years ago to about 15 percent this year.
Investors who avoided the largest computer-related stocks helped themselves during the third quarter. Intel's revenue was well below expectations. Dell's revenue growth rate slowed for the third consecutive quarter. And Apple warned that fourth-quarter earnings would be well short of expectations.
Mr. Turner and Mr. Van Wagoner both contend that larger funds -- those with tens of billions of dollars in assets -- are caught in a trap. They say such funds have grown by leaning heavily on the largest technology companies, but now they find it difficult to switch, or to keep up with the market's sharp turns.
"Volatility is huge," Mr. Turner said. "The Nasdaq trades at 2 percent swings 50 percent of the time. Guys with hundreds of billions of dollars can't do it."
In other words, they cannot move their money around without causing stocks to jump or dive, or without tipping off competitors. "You see their trades; their footprints are all over the place," he added.
Mr. Turner said his firm had sold many technology and telecommunications leaders, including Nokia, a Janus favorite.
So what has he been buying? "The common theme is that all companies need to buy servers, software and storage devices and create networks," he said, which is why he buys companies that provide those products and services.
He likes Juniper Networks, the maker of network switches and routers that is an upstart competitor to Cisco Systems. But his investment in a stock can be quite fluid. He bought Juniper at its offering in June 1999. After a big run-up, he sold the Turner Technology fund's entire position in March and reduced his other funds' holdings. Then, after Juniper fell more than 50 percent during the technology pullback in the spring, he bought back in.
Mr. Van Wagoner also favors providers of Internet services and expertise. "Most of the companies are involved in Web-ifying the G.M.'s, bringing the big companies up to speed," he said.
His firm invested last year in Interwoven, a Silicon Valley builder of software for corporate Web sites, while it was still a private company. Interwoven went public last October at $17 a share, and the firm trimmed its position in February, when it was as high as $80.06. When he jumped back in, during April, it was in the $20-to-$30 range.
For the record, investors should not count out Janus because of a disappointing year. Of the 14 equity funds that have existed since the beginning of the year, 8 have lost money. But the millions of investors who were with Janus at the beginning of last year still have excellent returns, and most appear to be giving its fund managers the benefit of the doubt, or at least more time to right the ship.
FOR all the risks of the Janus investing strategy, its executives are not interested in becoming another Fidelity Investments, a full-service investment firm with a broad menu of offerings. They intend to stick with a relatively small collection of funds that aim to top the charts.
Scott Schoelzel, manager of Janus Twenty, said that after several strong years, Janus's weaker performance this year should be no great surprise.
"I expected this to be a tough year," he said. "You had a fairly precipitous rise in rates by the Fed, a move in oil that surprised most people. Look at our funds over 3 years, 5 years, 10 years or 15 years. It's become fashionable to take shots at Janus."
With no false modesty, he compared Janus to another champion who goes through mild slumps only to come back mightier than ever.
"We're Tiger Woods," he said. "We've gone six months without winning a tournament."
